As if He said: They give the Jizya in return for your favors upon them, and as compensation for them. *Al-Yad* in His Almighty's saying has been carried upon something like this: (So they returned their hands to their mouths). It was said its meaning is: They rejected Allah's favors upon them by their denial, rejection, and belittling. Close to it is His saying, Mighty and Majestic: (They want to extinguish the light of Allah with their mouths). It is possible that the intended by *Al-Yad* is power (*Quwwah*), from their saying: "La yada li bi-kadha" (I have no hand/power in such), i.e., no power. The meaning would be: They pay the Jizya consequent to your superiority. It is possible it is the limb, and it has been used expansively. The meaning would be: They give the Jizya after acknowledgement to you that your hands are above their hands, and showing humility in their dealings. *Al-Jizya* in their speech: The tax imposed. It was named *Jizya*: because it is a repayment (*Qada'*) for what it is taken for. It is said: *Jaza 'anni kadha*, i.e., paid/satisfied. In the Quran: (And fear a Day when no soul will compensate (*tajzi*) for another soul anything), i.e., will not pay nor avail. From it the demander of payment is called: *Al-Mutajazi*. In the Hadith: "There was a man who used to lend to people and he had a scribe and a Mutajazi (collector)."

Issue from Traditions containing types of benefits
It was narrated in the report that the Prophet, peace be upon him, and the Muslims, may Allah be pleased with them, on the Day of Uhud, when Abu Sufyan and his party said: "Rise Hubal!", they said in their answer: "Allah is Higher and more Majestic (*A'la wa Ajall*)." Some asked saying: How is this speech permissible? *Af'al* in the chapter of Preference (*Tafdil*) is placed to come for preferring one over a group he is part of. Therefore, it is added to them, or to an indefinite singular substituting for them. You say: This is the best of the people, and Zayd is the best of men. The meaning is that he is one of them whose merit exceeds their merit. Likewise if you complete it with *Min* (from/than) which necessitates sharing in what the preference occurs in. You say: Zayd is better than Amr. The meaning: His merit exceeds Amr's merit. If you said: Humans are harder than stones, it would not be permissible due to the difference of the two genera. If the placement of *Af'al* in preference is like this, then the Prophet's speech, peace be upon him, cannot be for preference because of what occurs in it of Hubal sharing with Allah Almighty in Highness and Majesty, even if Allah Mighty and Majestic is preferred in the speech. Nor is it permissible that the intended by *A'la wa Ajall* is: Allah is High and Majestic (*Aliyy wa Jalil*), as Ubayd said:
*So that is a path in which I am not one (*bi-awhad*)*

Meaning 'by one' (*bi-wahid*), because the speech would exit from being situated as a counter and opposition to the disbelievers' speech. If both aspects are prevented in it, then what is it carried upon? The answer: When the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, saw the disbelievers balancing him when he called them to Allah Mighty and Majestic and to faith in Him, or sought victory from Allah Almighty against them and sought fulfillment of His generous promise regarding him, by mentioning Hubal, and claiming in competing and emulating him that they have a god they return to in the issue and rely on for answering, and that they hope for his highness, conquest, and manifestation—until they said to him: You worship our god a year and we worship your God a year, then we alternate on that, so Allah Mighty and Majestic revealed: (Say, "O disbelievers, I do not worship what you worship" the Surah)—and found Abu Sufyan and his companions rode that path in opposing him and countering his actions that day, he said by way of transcendence (*Tanzih*), magnification, exoneration, and aggrandizement: "Allah is Higher and more Majestic." Meaning: He is too High for anything to be mentioned with Him, and too Majestic for any mentioned thing to compete with Him. This is as it is said: So-and-so is too trustworthy (*awthaq*) to be stopped [for questioning], and too just (*a'dal*) to be judged. If it is so, Hubal's sharing with Him in praise falls. In this way is the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic: (He is not questioned about what He does, but they will be questioned). Meaning His actions in perfection, correctness, and running in the path of wisdom are such that they are not tracked by questioning about them and searching for their locations, while they are questioned due to the possibility of error upon them and the permeation of defect in their actions. This is apparent. It prevails in my mind that Al-Farazdaq intended by his saying:
*A house whose pillars are mightier (*a'azz*) and taller (*atwal*)*
This meaning, i.e., mightier than to be competed with, and taller than to be outdone. And that he did not intend: mightier than others, due to what is in the first of transcendence and grandeur. So know it, Allah Almighty willing.

Issue
Some asked about the saying of the speaker: "Ihmil al-mala awwala awwala" (Carry the money first first). Its syntax and meaning. The answer: Know that the Arabs have two doctrines regarding repeating the like of this. Some of them build them both together, treating them like *Khamsata 'ashara* (fifteen), as they did in their saying: "Huwa jari bayta bayta" (He is my neighbor house to house), and "Laqituhu kaffata kaffata" (I met him face to face/palm to palm?), and "Sabaha masa'a" (Morning evening), and "Yawma yawma" (Day day). So he says based on that: "Ihmil al-mala awwala awwala" [indeclinable on Fatha]. The intent in all is the intention of the preposition, and implicating the two nouns its meaning. The original was: "Huwa jari baytun li-baytin" (house to house), or "baytun ila baytin" (house to house), and "Laqituhu kaffatan li-kaffatin", and "Sabahan li-masa'in", and "Yawman li-yawmin". When the preposition was deleted and the two nouns implicated its meaning, building (*Bina'*) became necessary. Just as *Khamsata 'ashara*, when its original was *Khamsatun wa 'asharatun*, then the conjunction was deleted and the two nouns implicated its meaning and were made like one noun, building became necessary. Likewise your saying: "Ihmil al-mala awwala awwala", i.e., a first for a first, or a first added to a first. As if he does not wait for every first to have a second, but carries it hastily, until every carried thing becomes a first for a first, or a first added to a first. On this basis: "Alqa mata'ahu akhwala akhwala" (He threw his goods scattering?). The poet said:
*Its horn drops its trained [dogs] from it ... the dropping of the smith's iron, one after another (*akhwala akhwala*).*
Imru' al-Qays said:
*We inherited richness and glory, elder from elder (*akbara akbara*).*
i.e., An elder from an elder, and an uncle from an uncle (*akhwal*). Some of them do not intend the preposition, nor make the two nouns one noun, so he says: "Sumtu Ramadana yawman yawman" (I fasted Ramadan day by day), and "Qabadtu al-mala dirhaman dirhaman" (I received the money dirham by dirham), and "Ahmilu al-mala awwalan awwalan". The meaning is: I carry it thing by thing, and batch by batch, i.e., consecutively. If you enter the Fa' it is good and excellent speech and comes according to its origin. You say: "Ihmil al-mala awwalan fa-awwalan". Sibawayh claimed that the predominant usage in this entire chapter is that its accusative case is from one of two aspects: State (*Hal*) or Adverb (*Zarf*). If you enter Alif and Lam and say: "Udkhulu al-awwala fa-al-awwala" (Enter the first then the first), you must not count them [as defining?], and its accusative is also as State. The estimation is: Enter one by one. Sibawayh likened it to their saying: "Ja'u al-jamma'a al-ghafira" (They came the massive crowd), and "Ja'u qaddahum bi-qadidihim" (They came their cut with their cutter/all together): in that it is definite but occurred in the position of what should be indefinite, which is the State.

Verse of Meaning
He recited:
*I say to Amr while the gazelles are Sanihs (passing right to left) ... and they are for us the saddles and the game is worn out.*
*Behold, indeed the dates you are eating ... are the Isb and the cheapened, the torn.*
*So shoot their eyes (*'anhunna*) or shoot their posteriors (*isbib*) for that is an archery ... by which you will profit with the tanners of Tihama.*

This man is mocking another for being a hunter, and that he buys dates with the skins of wild beasts to eat. His saying: "Fa-'anhunna", meaning hit their eyes (*'uyunahunna*). It is said: "'Antu al-rajula", I hit him with an evil eye, or I shot his eye and hit it. His saying: "Fa-isbib" means hit their posteriors (*subbatahunna*) with arrows and on the backs. This is something by which the skill of the archer is described, because if he hits their eyes and posteriors, the skins are safe from holes, so they don't lose value in selling. It was recited regarding some of them:
*If they turn away, we hit their posteriors (*sabaynuhum*) ... and if they advance, they are [hit] from the chest/navel (*min nasr*).*
*Nasr*: We shoot their navels (*sururahum*) and hit them. Likewise it is said for all limbs of the body. It is said: "Wajahtuhu" and "Batantuhu": i.e., I hit his belly and his face. And likewise all limbs. It is said: "Nibtuhu", i.e., I hit his canine (*nab*), because it is from Ya-roots, just as it is said: "Bi'tuhu" (I sold it). And "Suqtuhu", i.e., I hit his leg (*saq*), because it is from Waw-roots, like: "Qultuhu" (I said it). And he says: "Ra'aytuhu", i.e., I hit his lungs (*ri'atayhi*). And "Fa'adtuhu", i.e., I hit his heart (*fu'ad*), so he is "maf'ud" (heart-struck).

Issue
Some asked about the saying of the speaker: "'Adhiri min fulan" (My excuse/supporter against so-and-so), and "Man ya'dhuruni min fulan" (Who will excuse me regarding so-and-so), and about its position in speech and its utility. Know that this phrase, I mean "Man ya'dhuruni min fulan", can be replaced by: "Man 'adhiri min fulan", and "'Adhiruka min fulan", and "Man 'adhiri min fulan". As for "Man ya'dhuruni min fulan", Al-Khalil said about it: Its meaning is who will blame so-and-so and not blame me. It is said: "'Adhartuhu 'udhran wa 'udhuran wa ma'dhiratan wa 'udhratan wa 'udhran wa 'adhiran". And "A'dhartu" is used in the meaning of "'Adhartu". You say: "Man 'adhiruka min fulan", and the meaning is: Who excuses you regarding so-and-so. Some recited:
*O people, who is my excuser (*'adhiri*) regarding the maiming (Jada'ah).*
And he also recited the saying of Amr ibn Ma'di Yakrib:
*I want his gift and he wants my killing ... Your excuse (*'adhiruka*) regarding your friend from Murad.*
And it is recited:
*The excuse (*'adhir*) of the tribe regarding Adwan ... they were the snake of the earth.*
Abu Sa'id al-Sirafi, may Allah have mercy on him, mentioned regarding the saying of the speaker: "Man ya'dhuruni min fulan", that it is interpreted in two ways. One is that the meaning is: Who excuses me in my tolerating him despite what I tolerate from him. The second: That its meaning is: Who mentions so-and-so's excuse to me. Then he mentioned that Al-Mufaddal ibn Salamah the linguist objected to Sibawayh when he made "'Adhir" a Masdar (verbal noun) and considered his method in it weak. He said: Masdars on [the pattern of] *Fa'il* are the category of sounds, like: *Sahil* (neighing), *Nahiq* (braying), *Shahij* (wheezing), *Hadir* (rumbling), and the like. And that in other than this category it is rare. So according to his method, "'Adhir" must be an adjective not a Masdar, because that is the most common usage outside of sounds. So *'Adhir* and *'Adhir* would be like *Shahid* and *Shahid*, and *Qadir* and *Qadir*. So it is as if the speaker, when he says: "'Adhiruka min fulan", means: Bring your excuser, and present your excuser, and bring whoever excuses you. Likewise if he says: "Man 'adhiri min fulan", the meaning is: Who is my excuser.
Know that one of the two ways Abu Sa'id narrated in interpreting "Man ya'dhuruni min fulan", which is: Who mentions so-and-so's excuse to me, is remote, as I did not find in the language: "I'dhirni min Zayd" meaning mention his excuse to me. As for the other way he narrated, which is: Who excuses me in my tolerating so-and-so, that is its path, except that you say: "'Adhartu fulanan" if you elaborated his excuse, and "A'dhartuhu" too. What Al-Khalil interpreted "Man ya'dhuruni min fulan" with, i.e., Who blames so-and-so and leaves blaming me, is the chosen view in interpreting this phrase. Do you not see that Al-Khalil said that they say: "Ala ta'dhuruni min fulan"? He said: Its meaning is that a man is wronged by so-and-so, so it is as if he sought excuse from his addressee in advance in complaining about so-and-so, and clarifying his own excuse regarding the punishment that will come from him, if he chooses to punish him. And that it came in the narrated Hadith: "People will not perish until they excuse (*ya'dhuru*) from themselves." Meaning: Until they turn back with blame upon themselves due to the multitude of their sins, and excuse their Punisher and Adversary for what comes from Him. Some linguists interpreted this Hadith to mean: Until their faults and sins multiply. This man did not bring its explanation separately, nor its verification of the word, even if multiplying sins from them is necessary. As for what Al-Mufaddal ibn Salamah objected to Sibawayh, it is not objectionable, because Masdars outside the category of sounds have come on *Fa'il* frequently. That is: like *Al-Nakir* (denial), *Al-Lahib* (flame), *Al-Wajib* (throbbing), *Al-Rasim* (camel pace), *Al-Khabib* (trotting), *Al-Shamim* (height/smell?), and what is too broad to mention.

Abu al-Hasan al-Akhfash said regarding the saying of Allah Almighty: (And those [angels] who deliver a reminder. As justification (*'Udhran*) or warning (*Nudhuran*)) [Quran 77:5-6], that *Nudhur* and *Nadhir* are like *Nukr* and *Nakir*, in that they are Masdars. Based on this, *'Udhr* and *'Adhir* [are Masdars]. If this is so, then the meaning of "'Adhiruka min fulan" is: Establish your excuse regarding him, and bring your excuse. If a questioner says: How did Al-Khalil interpret: "Man ya'dhuruni min fulan" as meaning: Blame so-and-so and do not blame me? I say: The lying so-and-so treated him in a way that deserved blame, and required the speaker to hold him accountable and reckon with him. So he addressed the youth saying: Who excuses me regarding so-and-so, i.e., who elaborates my excuse regarding so-and-so who deserved blame in how he treats me? As if that one has no excuse, and this one, if he punished him, would be excused. In the blame of the addressee for that is the clarification of this one's excuse. So he said: Who excuses me regarding him. Likewise his saying: "Hatta ya'dhuru min anfusihim" (Until they excuse from themselves), because in their turning back upon themselves with blame is the clarification of the excuse of Allah, Majestic is His Majesty, in holding them accountable and punishing them. On this basis is the saying of Amr:
*I want his gift and he wants my killing ... Your excuse (*'Adhiruka*) regarding your friend from Murad.*
Because whether you make *'Adhiruka* in the meaning of *'Udharaka* (your cheek-strap/restraint?), or you make it in the meaning of *Ma'dhirataka* (your excuse), the path is one in that the meaning is: Seek who excuses regarding him, or bring the excuse regarding him. The meaning of *Al-'Adhir* regarding him is: whoever elaborates my excuse and attaches the blame to him. Therefore, the Commander of the Faithful, blessings of Allah be upon him, exemplified with the verse, because he meant: I choose good for one who plots against me while he seeks calamities. So who excuses me regarding him? i.e., who elaborates my excuse and attaches blame to him if I turn against him. If it is said: What is the difference between what you chose in interpreting: "Man ya'dhuruni min fulan"—who elaborates my excuse in my tolerating so-and-so despite what I tolerate from him—the reality of the speech and its correctness is narrowing/restricting his own excuse, and the interrogation would be by way of denial. As if he meant: I have no excuse in what I offer him of forbearance and overlooking given his persistence in what grieves me. And if it is interpreted as meaning: Blame so-and-so and do not blame me, its reality is negating the excuse for so-and-so and establishing it for himself in what he will take him by and in punishing him after that. If you contemplate the two methods, the merit will appear to you and be correct.

Issue of Syntax
Some asked about the difference between the speaker saying: "Anta afrahu 'abdan wa 'abidan" (You are more skilled as a slave and slaves), and his saying: "Anta afrahu 'abdin wa al-'abidi" (You are the most skilled slave and [of] the slaves). The answer: The meaning of "Anta afrahu 'abdan" is: You exceed in skill the skill of your slave over others. So the skill is "afrahu 'abidan" (more skilled than slaves) if his slaves are many. Even if your saying "'abdan" is for the genus to remove the illusion that he has one slave. Allah Almighty said: (Say, "Shall we inform you of the greatest losers as to [their] deeds? (*a'malan*)"), alerting that the increase of their loss is in deeds of different genera, not one genus. If you said: "Anta afrahu 'abdin" (You are the most skilled slave), the addressee is one of the slaves, and the meaning is: You are more skilled than every slave, if they singled out slave by slave. Likewise if you said: "Anta afrahu al-'abid" (You are the most skilled of the slaves), because the meaning is: You are foremost among the slaves. If you made "al-'abid" indefinite [in the second case], it would not be permissible in any way.

Issue from the Revelation
His Almighty's saying: (The companions of Paradise, that Day, are better in abode (*mustaqarran*) and fairer in resting place (*maqilan*)). Some asked saying: If *Af'al* in the chapter of Preference is placed to come for preferring one over a group he is in, then how is the import of the verse when the people of Paradise have no sharing between them and the people of Hell in anything where preference occurs? Know that Al-Farra said regarding this: The people of speech (Arabs), if a fool and a wise man gather for them, they do not permit saying: "This is the wiser of the two men," nor "the more foolish of the two men." They say: We do not say "This is the wiser of the two men" except for two wise men, one of whom exceeds his companion. We have heard the saying of Allah Almighty: (Better in abode), so He made the people of Paradise better in abode than the people of Hell, while there is nothing of good in the abode of the people of Hell. So know that from their discourse. End of Al-Farra's words. The method in the verse is that the intent is: The companions of Paradise are more increased in stability in goodness than to be balanced, and more beneficial in exchange than to be measured. This is for aggrandizing their matter and exalting their status. As for preferring one of two things over the other, and claiming increase for it in a meaning of which nothing at all exists in the other, that is far-fetched in both custom and reason, due to the removal of ambiguity from it, the clarity of the situation in it, and the fall of benefit in informing about it. Do you not see that if a speaker said: "Honey is sweeter than aloe," or "Vinegar is more sour than sugar," his report would be belittled, since there is no sweetness in aloe in any way so that honey's sweetness is said to exceed it, nor is there sourness in sugar so it is claimed that vinegar's sourness is more than it. So know it.

Issue from Morphology (Abniyah)

Sibawayh said: There is no *Fu'al* as an adjective in speech except in one word from the weak [roots], which is their saying: "Qawmun 'Uda" (Enemy people), i.e., enemies (*A'da'*). *Al-'Uda* may be strangers even if they are not enemies. The poet said:
*If you are among a people, strangers (*'Udan*), you are not of them.*
Added to it is the reading of some: "Dinan Qiyyaman" in the meaning of *Qayyim*. Sibawayh can be supported [by saying] that *Qiyyam* is reduced from *Qiyam* which is the Masdar of *Qama*, and it was placed in the position of the adjective. Added to it: "Makanun Suwa", i.e., level (*Mustawin*). And "Lahmun Ziyam" i.e., scattered. Zuhayr said:
*Upon crooked legs whose flesh is scattered (*Ziyam*).*
Al-Nabigha said:
*At Dhu al-Majaz observing a dwelling, scattered (*Ziyam*).*
i.e., scattered vegetation. And *Al-Thuna*: Below the master (*Al-Sayyid*). He said:
*Our 'Thuna' (middle class?) rules over others, and our 'Bad'' (leaders?) ... rules over all of Ma'add, no one repels it.*
And "Ma'un Riwa" in the meaning of much water (*Rawa'*). These are five words that escaped Sibawayh. Sheikh Abu Ali, may Allah support him, said: And *Al-Riwa* among them is from the strays which I found.

Verse of Meaning
*Naive ones (*Ghara'ir*), virgins, beautiful are their arts ... As if the eyes of the *Murshiqaat* (gazelles) are their eyes.*
*They visit the son of a mother who is not consoled for a deceased one ... his father, and he did not carry its fetus for offspring.*
*Ghara'ir Ashbah*: Meaning poems he likened to naive women (*Ghara'ir*), who are the pampered, heedless ones, singular *Gharirah*. *Ashbah*: i.e., all of them are choice ones resembling each other. *Al-Murshiqaat*: Gazelles extending their necks; he likened their eyes in their genus to their eyes. His saying: "They visit the son of a mother who is not consoled for a deceased one," i.e., they travel on a path, this is its description, until they reach the praised one. "Son of a mother": is the path. "Is not consoled for a deceased one": i.e., whoever perished in it, no one is consoled for him. "Nor did its fetus carry for offspring," because he only attributed motherhood and sonship to it metaphorically.

Issue from the Gharib
Ibn al-A'rabi narrated: That the Arabs say in their proverbs when belittling a thing and scorning it: "Zandan fi Muraqqa'ah" (Two fire-sticks in a patched bag?). They also say: "There is nothing in his quiver (*Jafir*) except two fire-sticks." *Al-Jafir*: The quiver. *Al-Zandan*: Two pieces of wood by which fire is kindled. It is said: "Waraytu bika Zinadi" (I kindled my fire-sticks with you), meaning: Allah strengthened my support through you. It is said of the stingy man: "Saldat Zinaduhu" (His fire-sticks failed to spark), i.e., he struck but did not kindle. The poet said:
*Your fire-sticks failed to spark, O Yazid, and long ... did you pierce your fire-sticks for the destitute (*Darik*) poor (*Murmil*).*
*Al-Darik*: The poor. *Al-Murmil*: The one whose provision ran out. It is said: He struck and failed to spark (*Aslada*) also: If it availed nothing. And the saying of Amr ibn Ma'di Yakrib:
*I did not panic nor was I impatient ... and my weeping does not return a fire-stick.*
He means that his weeping does not return the trivial thing of little value. The stingy one deprived of luck in good is called *Al-Muzannad* from this. As for the saying of Al-A'sha:
*And your fire-stick is the best of fire-sticks of kings ... A Markh [wood] met an 'Afar [wood] from them.*
*And if you spent the night striking a rock in darkness ... with a Nab' [wood], you would have kindled a fire.*
He has revealed the meaning. The Arabs say: "In every tree there is fire, and the Markh and 'Afar gloried [in it]." So he mentioned them. The meaning of *Istamjada*: took much fire. From it: The beast found the fodder plentiful (*Amjadat*). He describes the praised one with firmness of opinion, and attaining success in demands and victory. The *Yatam* (?) is not pierced due to its hardness, so he said: If you struck with it, you would kindle, i.e., your endeavor succeeds where others fail and toil.

Issue of Syntax
Our companions the Basrans say: The condition for the verb of wonder (*Fi'l al-Ta'ajjub*) is that it be from the triliteral only. If it increases, wonder is expressed from it using *Ashadd* and the like, which events are not free from. Likewise colors and physical defects (*Khalq*), because the condition for the verb from them is to be more than three letters. Sibawayh said: It is built from what is on [the pattern of] *Af'ala* as well. No one has the right to object to what they say with "Ma ahsanahu" (How beautiful he is), "Ma aqbahahu" (How ugly), "Ma atwalahu" (How tall), and "Ma aqsarahu" (How short). That is because beauty and ugliness are not of physical defects (*Khalq*) at all, evidenced by the fact that description by them is only stirred by the sweetness to the viewer or his dislike, not what the thing itself is upon. Do you not see that regarding what he says: "Zayd, how beautiful he is," he might say: "Amr, how ugly he is" without a change occurring in him or an alteration happening to him. If the matter is as we said regarding their separation from physical defects, likewise the description of tallness and shortness results from the juxtaposition of another to the one described with one of them, evidenced by the fact that the same thing about which he says: "How tall it is," he might say: "How short it is" without it shifting from the state it was on before. If that is so, then lameness, deafness, muteness, and the like of physical defects differ, because the one described by them or some of them is described by them however the matter turns, unless he exits the description by a change from his Creator.

It is not an objection to say regarding the poor: "Ma afqarahu" (How poor he is), and for the rich: "Ma aghnahu", and for the possible/enabled: "Ma amkanahu", and for the upright/straight: "Ma aqwamahu", even if the past verb from them is *Iftaqara*, *Istaghna*, *Istaqama*, *Amkana*, and *Tamakkan*, because they only derived it from *Faqura*, *Ghaniya*, and *Qama*, even if some of these were not used due to dispensing with them by others. Sibawayh said: They dispense with one thing by another. Do you not see they said: "Huwa yadharu" (he leaves) and "yada'u", but they did not say: "Wadhara" nor "Wada'a"; they dispensed with them by "Taraka". He also said in another place: And a thing may run according to what they do not use in their speech, like their saying: *Malamih* (features), *Madhakir* (penises), and *Mahasin* (beauties), and like diminutives that have no magnified form like: *Kumayt* and *Ku'ayt*, and other than that which is frequent.
There came in this chapter what has no *Af'ala*, they said: "Ma ashghalahu" (How busy he is), while he is *Mashghul*, and "Ma ajannahu" (How mad), while he is *Majnun*, and "Ma amlahu" (How full), while it is *Mamlu'*. As if they attributed the verb to these things, because they say: "Ma af'alahu" regarding what the verb comes from. Do you not see that they say: "Ma adrabahu" if he is beaten (*Madrub*). They only said these because they made the *Mashghul* a possessor of busyness, and the *Majnun* a possessor of madness, and the *Mamlu'* a possessor of fullness. So as if they made busyness, madness, and fullness belong to them and treated them as if they said regarding them: "It has done/acted" even if they did not speak it.
What facilitates this and brings it closer is that they might come with the adjective according to the analogy of the verb, while they do not speak with its verb. They said: A man *Azfar* for one with long nails (*Azfar*), and *A'yan* for one with big eyes, and *A'naq* for one with a long neck. Likewise a man *Ash'ar* (hairy) and a ram *Asaf* (woolly). As if they said regarding them: As if it has done (*fa'ala*) even if they did not speak with it. It is not an objection their saying: "Ma anwakah" (How foolish), "Ma ahmaqah", "Ma ahwajah", "Ma ar'anah", and "Ma a'ma qalbahu" (How blind his heart), because these things separated from physical defects (*Khalq*) evidenced by the fact that a human is blamed for all of them and rebuked.
If it is said: You claimed that what is triliteral or on *Af'ala* specifically according to Sibawayh's method, wonder is expressed from it by: *Ma af'alahu*. Yet they said: "Ma ashadda sukrahu" (How intense is his drunkenness), and the verb from it is *Sakira*, and they did not say: "Ma askarahu". Likewise they say: "Ma ashadda jawabahu" (How intense is his answer), and do not say: "Ma ajwabahu", and the verb from it is *Ajaba*. I say: The first thing in this is that what you claimed against us, we did not say. We said: The verb of wonder is not built except from what is on three letters or from *Af'ala* specifically. We did not say: Every triliteral verb, or on the weight of *Af'ala*, wonder is built from it definitively. Since it is so, what you wanted to compel [us with] has fallen. Moreover, we have presented that they dispense with one thing by another so they do not use it even if analogy requires it. If this is established, and their saying: "Ma askarahu"—if it were said—and "Ma ashadda sukrahu", and "Ma ajwabahu"—if it were said—and "Ma ashadda jawabahu", are expressions for one meaning like: "Ma adrabahu" and "Ma akthara darbah", and "Ma ahsanahu" and "Ma atamma husnahu", it would not be impossible that one is dispensed with by the other, as was the case in: *Taraka* and *Wadhara* and their counterparts. If it is said: How is what you based the speech on correct for you when they said: "Ma alsanahu" meaning: How clear and eloquent he is, as it is said: A man is *Lasin*, and he has become *Lasina* *Yalsanu* *Lasanan*. Likewise they intended by length of tongue fluency and eloquence, and do not intend the tongue [organ] and its length. Since the matter is as we said, the fall of this speech became clear and it appeared that it is a mistake from the questioner or a fallacy, and this is apparent.

Issue from the Revelation
His Almighty's saying: (And when it is said to them, "What has your Lord sent down?" They say, "Legends of the former peoples") [Quran 16:24]. Abu Umar al-Jarmi narrated regarding this that he heard Abu Zayd al-Ansari say about it: They did not acknowledge. The meaning of this is that when it was said to them: (What has your Lord sent down?), they did not acknowledge the sending down in it, but turned away from the answer and said: It is (Legends of the former peoples) and not sent down. So on this basis, it is not carried on being the predicate of the inchoative which is *Alladhi*, as if he said: That which He sent down is legends of the former peoples. But they abandoned building on this and implied "Huwa" (It is), turning away from the question, and saying: It is legends of the former peoples, because they rejected that it be sent down.
It is permissible to carry it on another aspect, which is: That *Asatir* is inchoative, and its predicate is implied. As if he said: Legends of the former peoples, He sent it down according to you and in your belief. So he brought the speech out as a quotation from them, as He said in another place: "O magician, invoke your Lord for us" quoting their speech.
Similar to the nominative in *Asatir* is your saying to a man: "Madha ra'ayta?" (What did you see?), so he says: "Khayrun" (Good [nom.]). And in answer to: "Kayfa asbahta?" (How did you become/wake up?), "Salihun" (Good [nom.]). And the saying of Labid ibn Rabi'ah on this:
*Do you not ask the man what he attempts? ... Is it a vow so it is fulfilled, or error and falsehood?*

And for *Madha* there is another position, which is that *Dha* with *Ma* are made like one noun, just as they made *Ma* and *In* a particle when they said: *Innama* and *Ka'annama* and *Haythuma* in the conditional. Based on this is His Almighty's saying: (What (*Madha*) has your Lord sent down? They said, "Good (*Khayran*)") [Quran 16:30], i.e., What thing did your Lord send down? They said: He sent down good. Abu Ali al-Farisi, may Allah have mercy on him, recited to us regarding making *Dha* with *Ma* like a noun, the saying of Jarir:
*O Khazr of Taghlib, what (*Madha*) is the matter with your women ... they do not cease towards the two monasteries, yearning.*
He said: Do you see that it does not bear in the meaning of the verse that *Ma* be made in the meaning of *Alladhi* in any way.

Verse of Mu'ayah (Riddle/Puzzle)
He recited:
*Take Abu Umm al-Ri'al, for ... his ostrich fled from a flaming cloud.*
He means by Abu Umm al-Ri'al: Qatari ibn al-Fuja'ah, because he was nicknamed Abu Na'amah (Father of the Ostrich), and the ostrich (*Na'amah*) is the mother of the *Ri'al* (ostrich chicks). His saying: "Ajfalat na'amatuhu" (His ostrich fled), he means he was defeated when they challenged him. It is also said: "Shalat na'amatuhu" (His ostrich rose/died?), and "Zaffa ra'luhu" (His chick hurried), and "Tara ta'iruhu" (His bird flew). He means by "Al-'Arid" a cloud of war, and intended by "Al-Talahhub" (flaming): the blazing of its fire and the shine of its weapons.

Verse of Syntax
He recited:
*Is it from the trace (*Rasm*) of a dwelling, a spring campsite and a summer one ... for your eyes from the water of tear-ducts, a flow?*
Some asked saying: To what does *Murba'* and *Masif* refer, in your saying: "Li-'aynayka min ma'i al-shu'un wakifu"? And by what are *Murba'* and *Masif* raised (nominative), if they are not the predicate of the inchoative? The answer: *Al-Rasm* here is a Masdar (verbal noun). The meaning is: Is it from the tracing (*Rasm*) of a dwelling [as] a spring campsite and a summer one that you weep? Just as you say: Is it from Zayd's eating of bread that you weep? The Masdar is added to its object as it is added to the doer. So *Dar* (dwelling), the added-to term, is in the position of the object, and *Al-Murba'* is in the position of the doer, just as the bread in the example we gave is in the position of the object, and Zayd is in the position of the doer.

Chapter: From the Anecdotes (Nawadir)
Abu al-Abbas Tha'lab narrated from Al-Farra, saying: It is said for what remains of water in the cup or other: *Al-Su'r* with Hamza. For the leftover of Nabidh in the bottle: *Al-Basil*. For what remains of musk in the vesicle: *Al-'Itrah*. For what remains in the vessel of honey: *Al-Jils*. For what remains of ash in the fire hearth: *Al-Uss*. For what sticks of bread to the oven: *Al-Quramah*. For what remains in the hive and mixes with what dies of bees: *Al-Maharin*. For what remains in the belly of food and does not exit with excrement: *Al-Thamilah*. For what remains in the nosebag of barley: *Al-Baghit*. For what remains of perfume in the oil flask: *Al-Suwar*. He said: A Bedouin said to his wife: Take care of the *Suwar* for your smell is *Naghilah* (bad). For what remains in the bowl of dough: *Farazdaqah*. For what remains in the platter of Tharid: *Al-Rukha*. For what remains on the table of dough after baking: *Al-Jahfah*. For what remains of flour on the table: *Al-Luwathah*. It is said: She mixed (*lathat*) her loaf with *Al-Liwath*. For what remains of water and is cut off from the sea: *Al-Khalij*. For what remains of it in holes and pits after rain stops: *Al-Husyy*. For what remains on the ground of pebbles if most is scattered: *Al-Julayhah*. For what remains of Henna and dye: *Al-Usom*. He said: A young girl sent to another: Send me the *Usom* of your Henna. For what remains of wool after the teasing of the teaser: *Al-Buqamah*. For what remains in the mill of flour after its flour is taken: *Al-Nubaghah*. For what remains on the palm tree after the dates are harvested: *Al-Kurabah*. For what remains in the trough of water: *Al-Farashah*. For what remains of cotton after teasing: *Al-Sabikh*. For the leftovers of sticks: *Al-Qusarah*. For what rubs off from the ear of corn: *Al-'Asafah*.

Issue from the Revelation
His Almighty's saying: (Allah has sent down to you a mention (*Dhikran*), a Messenger (*Rasulan*)) [Quran 65:10-11]. It is possible that *Al-Inzal* is in the meaning of creation (*Al-Khalq*), as He Almighty said in another place: (And We sent down iron, wherein is great military might) [Quran 57:25], and in another: (And He sent down for you from the grazing livestock eight mates) [Quran 39:6]. The *Dhikr* would be Muhammad, the Messenger of Allah (PBUH), and the speech would be on the deletion of the possessive noun (Mudaf), as if: The Companion of a Mention, a Messenger. *Rasulan* would be accusative as a description, or if you wish as a state (*Hal*). It is also permissible that it be carried upon another verb, as if He said: Allah sent down to you a Mention, and sent a Messenger, unless *Al-Inzal* means revelation, and *Al-Dhikr*: The Quran. It is permissible that *Rasulan* be accusative as being the object of *Al-Dhikr* (if interpreted as verbal noun), like His Almighty's saying: (Or feeding (*It'am*) on a day of severe hunger, an orphan (*Yatiman*)) [Quran 90:14-15], and like His saying: (Provision (*Rizqan*), a thing). What strengthens carrying *Al-Dhikr* on revelation (*Al-Inzal*) is His saying: (Indeed, it is We who sent down the Dhikr) [Quran 15:9], and in another place: (And We sent down to you the Dhikr) [Quran 16:44]. So just as *Al-Dhikr* is carried upon *Al-Tanzil*, so too it is carried upon *Al-Inzal*, and they are one meaning. So know it.

Verse of Meaning
He recited:
*The 'Najib' advances her when they compete ... when the 'Najib' needs the 'Najib'.*
He describes his she-camel saying: When the she-camels compete in marching and strive, this she-camel advances and obtains precedence over her companions, [by] her neck which is like a branch that has been peeled (*Nujiba*), i.e., its bark taken off. He only said this because length of neck and being stripped of fur is desirable in she-camels. His saying: "When the Najib needs", he means she does that at the time when the matter intensifies in pursuit or flight, so the noble thoroughbred (*Najib*) of camels needs the whip (*Najib*) and urging with it. So the first *Najib* refers to: The neck. The second *Najib*: The noble of camels possessing nobility. The third: The whip made of skin *Manjub*, i.e., tanned with *Nujab*, which is the bark of a tree; it is *Fa'il* in the meaning of *Maf'ul*. Similar to it is the saying of Isam al-Zamani:
*He traverses the desert with fatigue out of fear of a 'Najib' ... and he devours the excess of his rein with a 'Najib'.*
*Yandu*: i.e., crosses and passes. *Al-Mann*: Fatigue. i.e., Despite what afflicts him of weakness and exhaustion, he crosses the desert out of fear of the whip. *Yaghulu fadla zimamihi*: i.e., he stretches his rein and goes with it due to the length of his neck. So the first *Najib* in this verse: The whip, and the second *Najib*: The neck.

Issue from the Gharib
Ibn al-A'rabi mentioned from Abu al-Makarim, who is his teacher, regarding people's saying: "La tuballim 'alayhi" (Do not *tuballim* against him). He said: It can be praise and blame. If ugliness is intended by it, it is from their saying: The she-camel *Ablamat* if her vulva swelled from intense lust (*Dab'ah*), which is the ugliest thing. He said: And it is salted (*Yumallah*) so it increases in ugliness. Therefore it was said: As if his face is a salted vulva. It is narrated that Al-Farazdaq entered upon Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan. Abd al-Malik said to some of his boon companions: Provoke Al-Farazdaq so we see what he says. When the session settled, that companion said to him: O Abu Firas, as if your face is salted vulvas. Al-Farazdaq said: Look, do you see your mother's vulva in it? The companion was ashamed. This is the aspect of blame. If praise is intended by it, it is taken from *Al-Balma'*, which is the night of the full moon. It is said: His face is *Mublam* if it is filled with light and completed in beauty. He said: And that is called the halo (*Tafawah*) of the moon. They recited to us:
*As if he is the full moon in its halo.*

Issue from the Revelation
His Almighty's saying: (And what makes you perceive that (*Annaha*) when they come, they will not believe?) [Quran 6:109]. Some mentioned that it is not permissible to read "Annaha" with Fatha in it, because this speech is cut off from the first, and is an informing that those about whom the verse was revealed will not believe. Reading "Anna" with Fatha invalidates this meaning and gives them an excuse for leaving faith, and this is not permissible. So the [correct] way is Kasra of "Inna", and the meaning would be that with the signs, they are stubborn also, so they will not believe. The justification for Fatha is that "Yush'iru" (makes perceive) runs the course of "Yadri" (knows) due to their agreement in meaning, and "Anna" is made to mean "La'alla" (Perhaps), as the Arabs say: "I'ti al-suqa annaka tashtari kadha" meaning: Perhaps you will buy something. So the estimation is: And what makes you know, perhaps they (meaning the signs), when they come, they will not believe either.

Issue containing many benefits from Language, Revelation, and Poetry
Some asked about the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic: (O wives of the Prophet, whoever of you commits a clear immorality, the punishment will be doubled (*yuda'af*) for her twofolds (*di'fayn*)) [Quran 33:30], and about what was narrated from Abu Ubaydah regarding it and how people opposed him. And about the saying of Abu Dhu'ayb:
*I repaid you the like (*di'f*) of the love when I shared it ... and no one repaid you the like (*al-di'f*) before me.*
And Al-Asma'i's objection to him in what he said. This is an issue that necessitates expanding speech in its aspects, for it is hardly clear except by that due to the difference of its facets and overlapping of its paths. I will detail its sentences and explain its ambiguity by the power of Allah.
Know that *Al-Di'f* (Double/Like) in the language has three places: It can be the like by which a thing is multiplied. It can be: The multiplied thing. And it can be: The multiplication (*Tad'if*). For each of these facets there is a clear meaning and a metaphor. Al-Khalil said: It is said: *Ad'aftu* the thing and *Da''aftuhu* and *Da'aftuhu* if I made it two likes or more. It is said: *Da'aftuhu* with lightening in this meaning also, *Da'fan* so it is *Mad'uf*. Labid said:
*And they mounted a doubled (*mad'ufan*) and a single whose strings ... are pearls and coral piercing the joints.*
It became clear from his speech when he said: "And a single", that the *Mad'uf* is: What has a like placed with it and is doubled. If the matter is so, *Al-Da'f* with Fatha is the Masdar, and *Al-Di'f* with Kasra is the like by which another is multiplied. If this is established, it is valid to call the first, to which its like was added and thus multiplied, a *Di'f*, just as the like by which it was multiplied is called *Di'f*, due to their sharing in that each of them is a like of the other, and has been multiplied by it. This is as you say: *Thanaytu* the thing *Thanyan*, if you put a second with it. Then what the first was doubled with is called *Thinyan* with Kasra, and the first with which you double is also *Thinyan*. On this is their saying in numbers: One and Two (*Ithnan*), because One is that which has no second. When a second was made for it to be doubled by, it exited from being one, so the second was called *Thinyan* for doubling the first by it, and the first also *Thinyan* for their sharing in that each is doubled by its companion. So it was said: *Ithnan*, and the original is *Thinyan*.

So *Al-Da'f* with Fatha is a Masdar like *Al-Thany*, and *Al-Di'f* with Kasra is like *Al-Thiny*. If each of them separated from its companion and became singular, neither of them would be called *Di'f* nor *Thiny*. Tarafa said:
*Like the slackened tether, and its folded end (*thinyahu*) in the hand.*
For this reason they said: I found in its folds (*athna'ihi*) such-and-such and in its *ad'af* (doubles/folds), so they used them in one way, even though *Al-Di'f* implies being a name for the like of what it was multiplied with, with no increase, while *Al-Thiny* does not imply that. Similar to that is that they made the Masdar on *Fa'l* and the Object on *Fi'l* with Kasra. Their saying: *Naqadtu* the camel in travel *Naqdan*, so it is *Manqud* and *Niqd*. And *Dhabahtu* the bird *Dhabhan*, so it is *Madhbuh* and *Dhibh*. This is frequent. They have inflected this structure in another way. They said: *Da'aftu* the garment *Da'fan*, then they called the doubled garments *Di'fan* with Fatha on Dad and 'Ayn. This is as you say: *Nafadtu* the leaves *Nafdan* with Sukun on Fa, then the shaken off is called *Nafadan* with open Fa. And *Qabadtu* the thing *Qabdan*, then the grasped is called *Qabadan*. *Ad'af al-jawf*: Its layers, some above others. It is permissible that it is the plural of *Al-Di'f* and *Al-Da'f* both. Al-Khalil also said: It is said: *Da'aftu* the people *Da'fan*, I outnumbered them so you and your companions had the *Di'f* (double/multiple) over them, i.e., the multiplication. Allah Almighty said: (So those will have a recompense of the double (*Al-Di'f*) for what they did), i.e., the reward of multiplication or the doubled which you knew the measure of, i.e., they have the right to exceed by that. Do you not see that the exegetes said: He meant by *Al-Di'f* His saying: (Whoever comes with a good deed will have ten like it). Just as they put *Al-Di'f* in place of *Al-Tad'if* (multiplication), they also put *Al-Tad'if* in place of *Al-Di'f*. So they said: I found in its *Tada'if* such-and-such, just as they said: I found in its *Ad'af* such-and-such. Al-Khalil said: The yield of alchemy is called *Al-Tad'if*. Just as they made *Al-Di'f* mean the doubled, they made *Al-Thiny* mean the folded (*Al-Muthanna*). Al-Shammakh said:
*And all of them competes with the fold (*thiny*) of a shaken [rein] ... like the snake of the mountain, turning away not driven.*
i.e., a folded rein. This is the mention of the meanings of *Al-Di'f*.
As for the saying of Allah Almighty: (O wives of the Prophet, whoever of you commits a clear immorality, the punishment will be doubled (*yuda'af*) for her twofolds (*di'fayn*)), it has been read: *yuda''af* also. Sibawayh said: They are synonymous. Abu al-Hasan al-Akhfash said: The lightened one is Hijazi, and the strengthened one is Tamimi. Abu Ubaydah said regarding the meaning of the verse: She is punished three punishments, because she was due to be punished once, so if the one time is doubled by two doubles, the punishment becomes three punishments. He only said this, in my opinion, because he made the word *Al-Adhab* (punishment) refer to the amount deserved by the sin originally, then that exact amount was doubled twice. So *Di'fayn* according to this is placed in the position of *Id'afayn* and *Tad'ifatayn*, as He Almighty said in another place: (Who is it that would loan Allah a goodly loan so He may multiply it for him many times (*ad'afan*)). He means many multiplications. This which he said regarding the verse is not common in it, even if the language does not reject it, because *Al-Di'f* in the verse means the like (*Al-Mithl*), not the multiplied (*Al-Muda'af*), nor the multiplication (*Al-Tad'if*). For this reason, those after him opposed him. Abu Ishaq al-Zajjaj said: What he said is nothing, because the meaning of *yuda'af laha al-adhabu di'fayn* is making the punishment of her crime like the punishment of two crimes. The evidence for that is His saying: (We will give her her reward twice (*marratayn*)). So it cannot be that she is given two rewards for obedience, and three punishments for disobedience. The meaning of *Di'f* of a thing is its like which doubles it, so it is like *Mithlayn*. End of the quote.
The matter in the verse is as he said. The meaning is that since they witness deterrents that prevent falling into sins, it is expected from them more than from those who do not witness them. So whoever of them does not do that [abstain], the punishment is doubled for her. Like this doubling is His saying: (We will give her her reward twice). Whenever the punishment exceeds the reward, it exits equivalence. Exalted is Allah above that.
As for the saying of Abu Dhu'ayb:
*I repaid you the like (*di'f*) of the love when I shared it ... and no one repaid you the like (*al-di'f*) before me.*

What was narrated from Al-Asma'i regarding it is that he said: He was not correct in his saying: "Di'f al-wudd", because the meaning is "I doubled the love for you," so he should have said: "Di'fay al-wudd" (two likes of love). This which Al-Asma'i drove at, if he said it, would be correct on the basis that he named the original *Di'f* because it is doubled by it, and the increase added to it which is similar to it *Di'f* also for this meaning, then he dualized. Similar to it is the saying of Allah Mighty and Majestic: (Our Lord, give them double (*di'fayn*) of the punishment), because the meaning is: Double the punishment for them. However, Abu Dhu'ayb did not take this path. Rather, he intended by his saying: "Di'f al-wudd", the multiplied love, or the multiplication of love. i.e., I repaid you when I verified that I doubled the love for you. What indicates this is that he said: *And no one repaid you the like (*Al-Di'f*) before me*. He means no one other than me repaid you the multiplied or the multiplication. This is as Allah Almighty said: (So give them a double (*di'fan*) punishment of the Fire. He said: For each is a double (*di'fun*)). i.e., Give them multiplied of the Fire. He said for each is multiplied or multiplication. And as He said: (So those will have a recompense of the double (*Al-Di'f*) for what they did), i.e., the reward of multiplication. Just as it is far-fetched that *Al-Di'f* here is the like (*Al-Mithl*) so the meaning would be they have the reward of the like, it is far-fetched in Abu Dhu'ayb's verse that the intended is "No one repaid you the like before me".
If it is said: Then what is the intended meaning of the speaker saying: "Give him *di'f* of his due"? And what is the difference between it and the speaker saying: "Give him *di'fay* of his due"? I say: The intended by his saying: "Give him *di'f* of his due" is the multiplied of his due, and the double of his due, i.e., that which became doubled by adding the due to it. And the intended by his saying: "Di'fay* of his due" is two likes of his due. So if the due was a dirham, according to the requirement of both statements, he must give him two dirhams. If he said: "Give him *di'f* of what is with him," meaning two likes of what is with him, it would not be correct until he says: "Di'fay* of what is with him," intending two likes of what is with him. This is built on what we presented of the meanings of *Di'f*. So contemplate it, Allah willing.
If it is said: Did you not claim that *Al-Di'f* can be in the meaning of multiplication (*Tad'if*), and multiplication and doubling are for what exceeds two, evidenced by His Almighty's saying: (The example of those who spend their wealth in the way of Allah is like a grain which grows seven ears; in every ear is a hundred grains. And Allah multiplies (*yuda'ifu*) for whom He wills). So why didn't you carry it on that in these issues? The answer: Such issues and what enters into acknowledgments and wills and their likes must be interpreted from what is suitable for them to the lowest ranks and the least number, if stripped of context clues, if that is necessary, and not interpreted to the more and the higher except by evidence indicating it and necessitating it. Since it is so, diverting *Al-Di'f* to the meaning of the like (*Al-Mithl*), and the doubled to the dual, is the most appropriate until an indication is seen with it necessitating exceeding them to the many.
Al-Khalil and others said: *Al-Kifl* of reward and sin is *Al-Di'f* (double/like). Like His saying: He has two portions (*Kiflan*) of reward and upon him are two portions of sin. Similar to it is His saying, Mighty and Majestic: (He will give you two portions (*Kiflayn*) of His mercy). And His saying: (And whoever intercedes a bad intercession will have a portion (*Kifl*) of it). They said: And it is not said: "This is the *Kifl* of so-and-so" until you have prepared a like of it for another, like *Al-Nasib* (share). If you isolate, you do not say: *Kifl* nor *Nasib*. Some said: It is possible that *Al-Kifl* is from *Kafala fulanun fulanan* if he supported him and spent on him.

Issue of Syntax
Some mentioned the saying of the poet:
*In a night of Jumada possessing clubs (*Andiyah*).*
He said: How did *Nada* come as *Andiyah*, while *Af'ilah* is the plural of the extended (*Mamdud*) not the shortened (*Maqsur*)? You say: *Rida'* and *Ardiyah*, *Kisa'* and *Aksiyah*, *Qadha* and *Aqdhiyah*, *Raha* and *Arha'*. The answer: Abu al-Abbas said: It is the plural of *Nadan*, like the poet's saying:
*Two days: A day of assemblies (*Maqamat*) and clubs (*Andiyah*).*
The meaning: In a Jumada night, due to the prevalence of drought in it and the difficulty of time on its people, the rich take gatherings in it to manage the poor and prepare slaughtered camels for gambling (*Maysir*), and mending the people of poverty and misery. Abu al-Hasan al-Akhfash said: He pluralized *Nadan* as *Nida'*, like *Jabal* and *Jibal*, then pluralized *Nida'* as *Andiyah* like *Rida'* and *Ardiyah*. Some said: He pluralized *Fa'al* as *Af'ul*, like *Zaman* and *Azmun*, and *Jabal* and *Ajbul*, so it became *Andin* like *Aydin*. Then he feminized this *Af'ul* with Ta, so it became *Andiyah*, as it was said: *Fuhulah*, *Bu'ulah*, and *Hijarah*, to emphasize the femininity of the plural. So *Andiyah* according to this is *Af'ilah*. Some Kufans said: It is anomalous in plurals, and like it: *Qafa* and *Aqfiyah*, and *Raha* and *Arhiyah*. Al-Farra and Ibn al-Sikit narrated these two.

Verse of Meaning
It was recited for Al-Hutay'ah:
*You got angry at us because we killed Khalid ... with Banu Malik? Behold, this is a rain (*Mutr*) anger.*

The *Mutr* anger is that which is placed in other than its place. It is that the like of Mudar is mentioned with something disliked, so a man from Bal'am gets angry for it, while they are adopted sons in Mudar. So the speaker says: This is a *Mutr* anger, i.e., What are you to Mudar, and what is your share of Mudar? *Al-Mutr* originally: is that he comes from the sides (*Turar*) of the valley. In the proverb: "Atirri (take the side/edge) for you are wearing sandals."

Chapter
Anecdotes and Proverbs
It is said: "This is the first (*Rayyiq*) of the rain, so beware its main part." It is struck when a matter is feared for its harm and its beginning has appeared. It is said: "That was from him in the prime (*Rayyiq*) of youth and its *Rayq*," just as you say: *Hayyin* and *Layyin* and *Hayn* and *Layn*. The original is *Rawq* of youth. *Rayyiq* is *Fay'il* and it has been assimilated, because if Waw and Ya meet, whichever precedes the other with Sukun, the Waw turns into Ya then the first is assimilated into the second.
It is said: "The lied-to (*Makdhub*) does not know how to deliberate." Similar to it: "The lied-to has no opinion."
A man said to Al-Hasan: "I vomited while I was fasting." He said: "Did the vomit return (*Ra'a*) upon you?" He says: Did anything of it return after it exited.
Al-Asma'i said: I was told about Qash'am from the wise men of the Arabs, and he was a man of opinion, experience, and honor: "Where should your food be?" He said: "In the belly of a nursing mother, or in the belly of one who cuts ties of kinship, or a hungry child, or a humble elder, or a far-traveling wayfarer, or a humble captive."
Amr ibn al-As said: "The wise is not he who knows good from evil, but the wise is he who knows the better of two evils."
*Na'l Simt*: If it is not patched. *Na'l Asmat*, *Qamis Asmat*, and *Sarawil Asmat*: If it is unlined. This is like your saying: *Thawb Khalaq* and *Akhlaq*. The poet said:
*Upon trousers of his, unlined (*Asmat*).*
It is said: *Habl Armam* and *Aqta'* and *Armath*, *Burqah A'shar*, and *Thawb Akbas* for a type of linen. It is said: So-and-so intervened (*Takhallala*) with an arrow in the battle of such-and-such, if he was hit and his presence at that battle was out of arrogance. This is sarcasm, i.e., he was not in need of it, and by his meddling he fell into it. Similar to this course is the poet's saying:
*When they urinated, the horses' hooves were ... containers for the urine, and water was colder.*
He says: They were free from what they came to, and water would have been colder had they not exceeded it out of insolence. This is sarcasm and mockery.
So-and-so came and two men supported him (*Ibtaddahu*), if each of them took one of his sides. And what power does so-and-so have if his two sons or two brothers supported him.
*Al-Khalaf* voweled is: The substitute. If silent (*Al-Khalf*), it is: The offspring, whether good or bad. Allah Almighty said: (So there succeeded after them a successor (*Khalf*)). He said: *And I remained in a successor (*Khalf*) like the skin of the mangy one.* Some recited:
*And the battlefield of a chest from Rabi'ah is good ... and the *Washiz* and *Za'anif* flew among them.*
*Al-Za'anif*: Excess leather and what falls from its edges. *Al-Washiz*, singular *Washizah*, is: A small stick used to plug a gap in the drinking bowl if it cracked, not from it. It is said: *Washizah* and *Washiz* and *Washa'iz*. It is narrated that a man complained to Al-Farazdaq about his wife. He said: Clothe her with the *Muhrijat*. He says: Divorce her three times. It is said: *Ahrijha* upon yourself, i.e., divorce her.
*Al-Ahabish*: Mixed groups of people with no lineage uniting them. Among them are *Ahabish* of Kinanah, i.e., those whom people joined and allied with. They were singled out by this name, just as it was said for Asad and Ghatafan "The Two Allies", while in the Arabs there are many tribes that allied and were not singled out as "The Alliance". This fame has occurred in individuals; do you not see that whenever Ibn Abbas is said, the name does not race to anyone but Abdullah, and likewise if Ibn al-Zubayr and Ibn Abi Talib are said, Abdullah and Ali, peace be upon him, are intended, even if each of them had a brother sharing the lineage.
Ibn al-A'rabi mentioned that some of their eloquent ones were asked: Does the *Jadha'* (young camel) impregnate? He said: No, nor does he let alone (*Yada'*), meaning he sends [semen] but it is futile. It was said: Does the *Thiny* (older camel) impregnate? He said: Yes, and he is slow (*Aniyy*). It was said: Does the *Riba'* (four-year-old) impregnate? He said: Yes, by the placing of a cubit. He said: And it is said: If a *Riba'* and a *Qarih* (full-grown) gather in a herd, the *Riba'* expels the *Qarih*.
Al-Asma'i said: I heard a storyteller in Basra saying: The believer, his garment is an *'Ilqah*, his broth is a *Sulqah*, his fish is a *Shilqah*, and his lunch is a *Falqah*. He said: *Al-'Ilqah* and *Al-Baqir* are one thing, which is: The garment is taken and split then the man wears it, and it has no sleeves or gussets.
He said: I asked a woman of the Arabs about *Al-Shighaf*. She said:
*A fox that has no description ... By Allah, Khufaf does not take it.*
*He is unable or perishes or fears ... They seek her while she has a *Shighaf*.*
*Al-Shighaf* is a disease under the rib cartilages. He said: And it is said the kindling (*Diram*) of Fitna is speech. And it is said: I saw him eating the eating of the hungry, cold person.

Among their proverbs: Quenching (*Al-Ri*) is not by sipping (*Al-Tashaff*). He means quenching is not to drink everything in the vessel. *Al-Tashaff* is *Tafa'ul* from *Al-Shafahah* (lips? residue?). It is said: So-and-so, if he drinks, he sips all (*Ishtaffa*), and if he eats, he wipes clean (*Laffa*). It is said: He poured out his vessel (*Tasabba*), if he took its residue (*Sababah*). It is said: Nothing remains of the world except a residue like the residue of a vessel, its owner pours it out.
Names of the arrows (*Qidah*): *Al-Fadhdh*, *Al-Taw'am*, *Al-Raqib*, *Al-Hils* (and it is said *Al-Hils* on the pattern of *Al-Kitf* and it is the original), *Al-Nafis*, *Al-Musfah*, and *Al-Mu'alla*. These possess shares. *Al-Safih*, *Al-Manih*, and *Al-Waghd* have no shares, but whenever they come out, they are returned to the arrows to increase their number.
Al-Asma'i narrated, saying: A man from the Arabs entered a cave with brothers of his. The cave collapsed on them, so his brothers perished and he escaped. He married into a tribe of Arabs after that, and caused an event among them, so he feared them. He remained absent from them for a time, then returned to them. Recognizing his family was difficult for them. He began tracking the women's litters and saying: "Have you heard of the sons of a mother who died of grief except a youth who did not commit a deed, nor saw a maternal uncle do it nor a paternal uncle?" They would say: "Away with you!" He continued like that until he passed by his wife, and she recognized him. She threw his son to him—and the son had a mole—and said: "The one with the mole, take him. And our brother, pay his blood money. And the people, beware of them." He carried his son and departed. He said to the *Ashyam* (mole-possessor): "What do you see?"—and he is the one with the mole. He said: "I see a curved, long [neck?], the whip running on her upper chest." He means by *Labbat* the upper chest of the horse. *Al-Ghut*: A type of galloping and seeking. *Al-But*: Following the *Ghut*. He said to him: "Look, what do you see?" He said: "I see upon your neighbor one leaning (*Warik*), holding on or perishing." Then he said to him: "What do you see?" He said: "I see a swollen, full (*Hadrah Badrah*) from our horses or the horses of the family of Murrah." He said: "Dismount, swollen full (*Hadrah Badrah*)," i.e., swollen, hurrying.
From their proverbs: "Do that as long as your grazing herd is safe." The explanation of this is what some narrated that he said: So-and-so will not desist from such until Allah strikes him with a thunderbolt or a calamity from which his head (*Sha'wuhu*) flees. The poet has in his manner his saying:
*If the shepherd of the lambs is driven while the lambs are fleeing.*

Issue from Morphology (Abniyah)
Al-Khalil claimed that there is nothing in their speech on the pattern of *Fu'allah* except three words: *Humarrah* (intense heat), *Subarrah* of winter (intense cold), and *Zu'arrah* of character (bad temper). It has come: I came to him at the *Hiballah* of that, i.e., at the time of that. And he threw upon him his *'Uballah*, i.e., his weight. And the people came with their *Zuraffah*, i.e., with their group. *Zurafi* is also narrated, meaning groups. It is narrated from Al-Hajjaj that he said: "Keep me away from these *Zurafi*," i.e., groups. And this is the *Jurabbah* of So-and-so, i.e., his family if they are old. It is said *Jurabbah* also. Al-Asma'i recited:
*Jurabbah like the red donkeys of Al-Abakk ... there is no weak one among them nor a milker (?).*
And in it is *Mudharrah*: i.e., wasting wealth. And in it is *Du'arrah*: i.e., malice. From it is the *Da'ir* wood, which is smoky. And *Al-Humarrah* is dandruff of the head.

Chapter
On what Al-Khalil was attributed to misspelling or deficiency in
He claimed that the dotted Ghayn, Ha, and Mim do not gather in a word. He denied *Al-Hamigh* (Death), and said: It is *Al-Hami'* with 'Ayn. This is authentic, narrated. It is derived from *Hamagha ra'sahu*, i.e., crushed it. It is said: *Inhamagha* the thing, i.e., broke. And a sore *Munhamighah* i.e., wet. Darkness is called: *Ghayham* and *Ghayhab*. He mentioned in the chapter of Ha and Qaf: *Al-Qarih*: The bow whose string separated from its grip. Rather it is *Al-Farij*. In the chapter of dotted Kha and Sad: *Al-Khisb*, the snake. Rather it is *Al-Khidb*. In the chapter of undotted Ha: *Al-Habir*, the foam. Rather it is *Al-Khabir* with dotted Kha. The Hudhali said:
*They chewed at its edges the foam (*Al-Khabir*) ... its bag tore and it was spilled.*
*Taghadhdhamna* i.e., chewed. *Al-Khabir*: Foam. This is a metaphor he struck for clouds. Meaning: "Its bag tore," meaning its water, as if the earth permitted it and took it away. He said in the chapter of dotted Dhal and Ba: A thing *Rabidh* i.e., piled up. Rather it is *Rathid* with Tha and Dal. He said in the chapter of Zay and Ra with Ba: A ram *Zabir*, i.e., big-bellied, full, placing Zay first. Rather it is *Rabiz* placing it last. He said in the chapter of Kaf and Ta with Mim: *Al-Takmah*: The walking of the blind without a guide. Rather it is *Al-Takammah* from *Al-Akmah*, who is born blind. He mentioned in the chapter of Qaf and Ya in the Lafif: *Taqayya'at* the woman to her husband if she bent over him coquetting. Rather it is *Tafayya'at* with Fa. He said in the chapter of weak letters: *Al-Malaqat*: Top of the mountain on the pattern of *Maf'alah*, and its plural is *Al-Malaqi*. Rather it is *Al-Malaqat* and its plural is *Malaq* on the pattern of *'Alaqah*. He claimed that 'Ayn and Ha do not combine in a word with original letters, yet it has been found: It is said *It'anjaha* the water, meaning exploded.

Verse of Meaning

By Al-Kumayt ibn Zayd:
*I exited the exit of the arrow (*Qidh*), the arrow of Ibn Muqbil ... despite those barking ones and the setter [of dogs].*
*Upon me are the clothes of beautiful women, and beneath them ... a determination of an affair that resembled the drawing of a blade.*
Khalid al-Qasri had imprisoned Al-Kumayt. His wife attended the prison, so he wore her clothes and exited disguised as her and unrecognized, so he was safe and escaped. The arrow of Ibn Muqbil is used as a proverb for winning. Al-Kumayt struck it as a proverb for himself when he exited the prison. The arrow of Ibn Muqbil was a winner known for that; he had described it well in his poetry and repeated its mention. The Arabs used to hire it, borrow it, and take it as a good omen. Al-Hajjaj wrote to Zayd ibn al-Husayn, who was over Isfahan: "My likeness and your likeness is the arrow of Ibn Muqbil." Zayd did not know what he meant, until he met a Syrian man and asked him about it. He said: "He informs you that I will overcome you." When Al-Kumayt fled from prison, he joined Maslamah, and said:
*O Maslamah ibn Abi al-Walid ... for a dead man, if you wish, a reviver.*
*He crossed the deserts, crossing ... with you in the midday heat of Bajir.*

Issue of Syntax
Their saying: "Khalaqa Allahu al-zarafata yadayha atwala min rijlayha" (Allah created the giraffe, its forelegs longer than its hind legs). *Yadayha* is a substitute (*Badal*) for the giraffe. *Atwala* is accusative as a state (*Hal*). It was only permitted to be a state because it transitions in length, becoming longer bit by bit, as the poet said:
*And wealth with bunches of unripe dates, red (*ahmara*).*
He made *ahmar* accusative as a state, because the bunches transition into redness; otherwise it would not be permissible. As for His Almighty's saying: (And on the Day of Resurrection you will see those who lied about Allah, their faces blackened (*wujuhuhum muswaddah*)) [Quran 39:60], *wujuhuhum* is raised by inchoative (*Ibtida'*), and *muswaddah* is its predicate. It is like your saying: "Ra'aytu Zaydan abuhu afdalu minhu" (I saw Zayd, his father is better than him). It was only permitted in both because the pronoun refers back to the first from its cause. It is permissible to make *wujuhuhum* accusative by making it a substitute for *alladhina* (those who), and it would be like the speaker saying: "Ra'aytu mata'aka ba'dahu ahsana min ba'd" (I saw your goods, some of them better than others). There is no preventer preventing its permissibility, except that the readers agreed on the revelation of the reading with it [nominative] without a cause [for accusative?].

Issue from the Revelation
His Almighty's saying: (And every human, We have fastened his bird (*ta'irahu*) to his neck, and We will bring forth for him on the Day of Resurrection a record which he will encounter spread open. Read your record. Sufficient is yourself against you this Day as accountant) [Quran 17:13-14]. His saying: "Ta'irahu" means his deed of good and evil. The deed was validly named a "bird" only because it precedes its doer, so it is as if it flies from him, so he possesses no catching up or overtaking of it. Based on this it is said: "Fajrun mustatir" (spreading dawn), and "Ghabarun mustatar" (flying dust). Al-Khalil said: Such is the speech of the Arabs. Al-Ba'ith said:
*So a swift, strong she-camel folded with him a large [desert] ... When the glory of living was counted, she advanced between it.*
He means: She broke wind with it, and preceded with it. Resembling this is their saying: *Al-Furut*: What preceded of a deed or child for which you have a reward. It is said: "Farata lahu waladun", i.e., he preceded to Paradise. In supplication: "O Allah, make him for us a *Faratan*", i.e., a preceding reward. Its origin is: *Al-Farit* who precedes the people to the water. Labid said:
*So we arrived before the scouts (*Furrat*) of the sandgrouse ... Indeed part of my arrival is the early morning drinking.*
The meaning of (We have fastened his bird to his neck) is: We have fastened to him the recompense of his deed which he sent forth. So it is his predecessor, if good then good, and if evil then evil, hung on him and accompanying him. The position of his saying: "Fi 'unuqihi" (in his neck) is accusative as a state. They are fond of mentioning the neck (*'Unuq* and *Raqabah*) and use it as a metonymy for the whole human. This is their saying: "So-and-so freed a neck (*raqabah*)" regarding a slave, and "This trust is in his neck." They say: "The Sultan necklaced him (*qalladahu*) such-and-such in authority," and "He pledged his neck (*muqalladahu*) for such," just as they said: "He occupied his liability (*dhimma*) with such." Bishr said describing a treacherous woman, Hadir:
*And Ja'far necklaced her with the necklace of the pigeon.*
Al-Asma'i recited the saying of Ibn Abi Rabi'ah, having used metonymy for the neck:
*Indeed I have a need from you. She said ... Between my ear and my shoulder is what you want.*
i.e., in my neck. This which we mentioned is what most of the predecessors are upon, and I have explained it to my ability.

Some of them mentioned that the intended by "his bird" (*Ta'irahu*) is what flies to the human or from him of beloved or disliked things. He said: This is as the Arabs used to hold regarding augury (*Zajr al-Tayr*) and inferring occurring matters by it. Allah Almighty said, quoting a people addressing their Prophet when they saw bad omens, and in his answer to them: (They said, "We augur evil (*ittayyarna*) by you and by those with you." He said, "Your omen (*Ta'irukum*) is with Allah") [Quran 27:47]. On this basis is the saying of Muslims in disavowing augury: "O Allah, there is no bird (*Tayr*) except Your bird, and no good except Your good, and no Lord other than You." So the meaning would be: Every human, We have fastened the recompense of his omen to his neck. Its metaphor and explanation would be as I mentioned. This speech contains severe deterrence and eloquent restraint from committing sins, because if the intended knows his knowledge (deed) sticks to him and is certain of its falling upon him, he refrains from much of what he desires. Allah Almighty has explained that and clarified the situation in it by His saying: (And We will bring forth for him on the Day of Resurrection a record which he will encounter spread open). His saying: (We bring forth for him a record), "Kitaban" is accusative as an object. The evidence of the verse is His saying: (This, Our record, speaks about you in truth) [Quran 45:29]. His saying: (which he will encounter spread open) is in the position of an adjective for "Kitab". Its evidence is His saying: (And when the pages are spread open) [Quran 81:10]. As for His saying: (Read your record), it is on the implication of saying (*Qawl*), as if the meaning is: And We say to him: Read your record, or: And it is said to him: Read your record. It is narrated from Al-Hasan that he said: "He has been fair to you, O son of Adam, who made you the accountant of yourself." He, Majestic is His Majesty, only informed us of the matter of the Guardian Angels and those who count our deeds against us, as a piety-inducing deterrent (*Taqwa Al-Rawa'i*) from sins. His saying: (Sufficient is yourself against you this Day as accountant). If it is said: Why didn't He say "against you and for you", because the threatened record undoubtedly contains what is for him of good deeds and against him of bad deeds, and because if the threat is accompanied by fairness and built upon it, it is more eloquent in exhortation? The answer: The word "Alayka" (against you) can be attached to His saying: "Iqra'" (Read), as if He said: Read your record against yourself; sufficient is yourself as an accountant. The position of "Bi-nafsika" is nominative as the doer of "Kafa", and "Hasiban" is accusative as a state (*Hal*) or specification (*Tamyiz*). Were it not for avoiding repetition, the more appropriate way would be to say: Read your record against yourself, because the most common usage in the imperative is to say: Take for yourself such, and make for yourself such. But He disliked saying: Read your record against yourself, sufficient is yourself. So this is one aspect. It is permissible that it attaches to His saying: "Kafa" (Sufficient), as if He said: Your self suffices against you as an accountant. The position of "Alayka" would be accusative as a state, i.e.: Your self suffices while it is against you, not for you and with you. The meaning would be like what His saying in another place includes: (On a Day when their tongues, their hands and their feet will bear witness against them as to what they used to do) [Quran 24:24]. It is permissible that it attaches to His saying: "Hasiban", and it is in the position of a state, i.e.: Your self suffices as a fulfiller (*Mustawfiyan*) against you today, because the meaning of *Hasib*, *Mustawfi*, and *Muhasib* is one. I do not know anyone who explained this verse like what we mentioned.

Issue from Morphology (Abniyah)
Sibawayh said: *Maf'il* with Kasra on the 'Ayn did not come from the defective Lam; it only came with Fatha like: *Al-Marma*, *Al-Mad'a*, and *Al-Malma*. Al-Farra said: Two words came on it, which are: *Ma'qi al-'Ayn* (Eye corner) and *Ma'wi al-Ibl* (Camel shelter). As for exemplifying *Ma'q* as *Maf'il*, it is a mistake. That is because in this word there are several dialects: *Muq*, *Ma'q*, and *Maq*, on the weight of *Qadin*. All of that testifies that the Mim of the word is the Fa' of the verb. It is not permissible that it be among words with two dialects where one letter in one dialect is original and in the other extra, because what is of this nature must have indications in the word's conjugations, and nothing permitting contrary to what I mentioned was allowed. As for *Ma'wi al-Ibl*, it is strange and not counted. If it is said: Then among the dialects in it is *Ma'qa*; so on this, what is its weight? I say: Its weight is *Fa'la*, and it is as if the addition in it entered upon *Fa'l* so it became *Fa'la*. The addition of Ha in the end of this is like the addition of Alif in *Qaba'thara*, and Nun in *Kanhabal*, *Qaranful*, and *Inqahl*, in that it is not for coordination (*Ilhaq*) but a new structure was united by it. As for *Ma'q* on the weight of *Qadin*, it is *Fa'il* inverted; its original is *Ma'iq*, so the Qaf was advanced over the Hamza becoming *Ma'qi*, and they made substitution necessary for it for lightening as was done with *Al-Dhurriyyah* and *Al-Dawiyyah* and the like. What testifies to this is what Abu Zayd narrated of lightening the Hamza in it, and that it is pluralized as *Mawaq* and *Mawaqi* both.

Verse of Meaning
By Al-Ra'i:
*She stayed in it during the intensity of spring, and her neighbor ... was a brother of solace (*Salwah*), the night spent the evening (*Massa*) with him, white and black (*Amlah*).*

His saying: "Brother of solace (*Salwah*)", he means the dew/moisture (*Nada*), meaning she was in a comfort of life that consoles them from others. He says: She stayed in this place in the strength of spring neighboring the dew. His saying: "Massa bihi al-layl" (The night spent the evening with him), i.e., joined the night. And "Amlah": White in black, and it is a description of the Brother of Solace. The meaning: She stayed as long as the dew helped her, then she departed.

Issue of Syntax
If a speaker says: From where is it permissible to say: "'Aman awwala" (A year first/last year), and not permissible "Shahran awwala" (A month first), nor "Yawman awwala" (A day first), nor "Sanatan ula"? I say: Their saying: "'Aman awwala" is among what they intended for specificity with something that is not in others, relying on convention. Because the meaning is "'Aman awwala min 'ami" (A year first/before my year). When the word was circulated, and the need for its frequent use was pressing, they deleted, shortened, summarized, and limited, relying on the knowledge of the addressee, and the intention is completion. The difference between this and what is built on Damma, which is "Abda'u bi-hadha awwalu" (Start with this first), is that the one built on Damma has been made a limit implying the meaning of the deleted part, and it is fixed in intention. The one built [here] was not made the limit of speech nor implying the meaning of the annulled part of it; rather the limit of speech is what is in the soul. So it is in the status of what is spoken with it, even if deleted for lightening. It is as was deleted in the saying of the Rajiz:
*He mixed from Salma the cartilages of a nose ('Rafa')*
Do you not see that when he intended addition he said: "Wafa", so he deleted from the utterance and established it in the intention, until it became in the status of what is spoken. Had he intended singularity, only "Faha" would be permissible. Similar to this specification is their saying: "Al-Yawma fa'altu kadha" (Today I did such), making it for your day in which you are, and they do not say: "I met him The Month nor The Year." They have also said: "I met him *Al-'Am*" (This year), even though *Al-'Am* means the year. The poet said:
*O Year (*Al-'Am*) which has disturbed me ... You are the ransom like the mention of a year first/before (*'amin awwala*).*
If it is said: Why was *Min* needed such that you estimated in your saying "'Aman awwala" that its original is "'Aman awwala min 'ami"? I say: The speech only needed *Min* because they wanted to clarify in this *Af'al* (comparative/superlative) the beginning of the increase from what thing it was, to know its limit and start. So the meaning of your saying: "Zaydun afdalu min Amrin" (Zayd is better than Amr) is that the beginning of the increase of his merit is from the merit of Amr, so he is its limit and beginning. Likewise their saying: "'Aman awwala", so know it.

Issue from the Tradition
It was narrated from Abdullah ibn Mas'ud that he said: "Lengthening the prayer and shortening the sermon is a sign (*Ma'innah*) of the man's Fiqh." His saying: *Ma'innah*. Al-Farra said: It is said "Anta 'umdatuna wa ma'innatuna", i.e., we direct our needs to you. Its origin is: from *Anna fi al-amri ya'innu*, and *Dhanna yadhinnu*, if he hesitated in it and returned to accomplish its fulfillment. It is also said: *Annana* and *Dannana*. It was narrated from some of Banu Qays that he said: "Ta'annantu fulanan", in the meaning of: "Tanas-saftuhu", i.e., I sought justice from him for a claim I had against him. Al-Lihyani said: *Al-Ma'innah*: The status/place. He said:
