*Indeed applying Kohl to the pure white eye ... and looking at the arched eyebrow.*
*Is a sign (*Ma'innah*) of the crooked deed.*
i.e., *Madinnah* (Place of suspicion/location). Abu Zayd said: "Innahu la-ma'innatun an yaf'ala kadha", i.e., worthy/likely. Abu Malik said: "The mosque is a *Ma'innah* from me," i.e., a place. Dukayn recited:
*He is watered on a pricking pulley ... bound between squinting wells.*
*A place (*Ma'innah*) of the perishing of souls.*
i.e., a place of the destruction of souls. Al-Kisa'i: A man of the Bedouins, kunya Abu Zayd, attended me, and he was eloquent. He said: "I see this assembly of yours is a *Ma'innah* for scholars," i.e., a mine. He recited:
*So Tawdah of them, then Al-Qanan is a place (*Ma'innah*) ... then Thahlan of them is a spring camp and a summer one.*
Abu Sa'id narrated: A man possessing *Ma'innah* entered, on the weight of *Ma'annah*, and men possessing *Ma'innah*, i.e., attracting good. Abu Malik recited regarding *Al-Ma'innah*:
*And a dwelling of the love of Jumal I settled in ... a place (*Ma'innah*) of the observation points of places (*Ma'innat*).*

Chapter: Benefits and Subtleties
Al-Asma'i: For stabbing, *Al-Wakhd* is that which if stabbed does not penetrate. *Al-Tasrid*: Penetrating stab. The Masdar from it is *Al-Sarad*. The poet said:
*They did not spare me, you two left me ... but you feared the penetration (*Sarad*) of arrows.*
It is said: *Asradahu Isradan*. It is said: A stab and stabs *Nawajim* (appearing), which are those that if stabbed, a little of it penetrates from the other side; the horn and tooth *yanjumu* when it appears. It is said: *Wakhatahu Wakhatan*, if he stabbed a light stab resembling snatching. He said:
*A snatch (*Wakhtan*) with a sharp [sword] in the kidneys, snatching.*
It is said: A stab *Lazz*, and a stab *Shazr*. *Al-Shazr* is what is from right and left. It is said in its like: If the matter is straight forward: *Sulka*, and *Ma Sulka*, and not *Makhluja*, and not *Sulka*. Imru' al-Qays said:
*We stab them straight (*Sulka*) and crooked (*Makhluja*) ... your attack like an Amin upon a Nabil.*
i.e., Archer.

Al-Asma'i used to say: They used to shoot in the past with two arrows, two arrows, then the two arrows would be returned to the archer. *Al-La'm* (with Hamza) is the arrow, and it is taken from *Al-Multa'im* (matching/meeting) in the feathers. Harithah ibn La'm is from this. The poet said:
*People think of the two kings ... that they have united (*Ilta'ama*).*
*If you permit their repair (*Laymihima*) ... then the matter has become grave.*
*Al-Laym*: Reconciliation, named so because it is only from *Iltt'am* (uniting/healing).
Al-Asma'i said: There are times the Arabs mention. Among them is the time of *Al-Fithal*. They say: That was the time of *Al-Fithal*, when the rocks were wet. Among them are the years of *Al-Fataq*. Ru'ba said:
*It was not hoped for after the years of *Al-Fataq*.*
They only indicate by it the time of fertility and good. Among them are the times of *Al-Khunan*. This they indicate by it evil and calamities. Jarir said:
*And I cauterize the lookers for *Al-Khunan*.*
He strikes it as a proverb, because the camel, if afflicted by *Al-Khunan* (a disease), his *Naziran* (two veins) are cauterized.
Al-Asma'i said: *Al-Qirbah* is for water, *Al-Watb* is the skin for milk, *Al-Nihy* with Kasra on Nun is for ghee and thick juice (*Rubb*), and *Al-Ziqq*, which is pitched, is for wine and vinegar and the like.
It is said: What is the slippery rock on which the feet of scholars do not hold firm? It is said: Greed.
He said: Ibn Hubayrah used to seek refuge from snakes, the scorpion, and the 'Ilj (strong infidel/lout) if he became westernized (or strange/excessive).
He said: Bilal used to seek refuge from Satan and the Sultan.
He said: It is said of the horse's ear: As if it is a pod (*Sinf*) of a yellow Markh tree. *Al-Sinf*: A house (pod) that comes out at the base of the Rukh like the shape of fruit. If its fruit dries and falls from it, the *Sinf* remains hunched, hollow, pointed like the feather of an arrow, so the ear was likened to it.
A man entered upon Mu'awiyah and asked him about his stipend. He said: Two thousand and five hundred dirhams. He said: What is the matter with the surplus (*'Ilawah*) between the two loads (*Fawdayn*)? So he removed the five hundred from his stipend and established two thousand for him. *Al-Fawdan*: Two large containers carried on the camel or beast, topped by another container below them placed between them. This is a proverb struck. *Al-Fawdan*: Also the two sides of the head.
Al-Asma'i: It is said: *Al-Dafi'*: Water in the valley from the mountain or every high place. If it is a small push (*Daf'*) it is *Shu'bah*. If it is larger it is *Tal'ah*. If it exceeds that, it is *Maytha'*. He said: What is in the lowland is *Qariyy*. *Al-Midhnab*: If it pours into the meadow.
Abu Zayd said: "Ma lahu sa'nah wa la ma'nah", i.e., he has neither little nor much. It is said: *Al-Sa'nah*: Grease/Fat. *Al-Ma'nah*: Kindness/Ma'un. The Ha may be deleted from them, so it is said: "Ma lahu sa'n wa la ma'n". And "La 'afitah wa la nafitah". *Al-'Afitah*: The ewe. *Al-Nafitah*: The nanny goat, which is the one that snorts with its nose. And "Ma lahu sarih wa la ra'ih". *Al-Sarih* is the one who goes early, and *Al-Ra'ih* is the one who returns. And "Ma lahu haba' wa la raba'". And "Ma lahu zar' wa la dar'". And "Ma lahu thaghiyah wa la raghiyah", meaning sheep and camel. And "Ma lahu sabad wa la labad". And "Ma lahu khayr wa la mir", from *marahum yamiruhum*. *Al-Haba'*: That which is born at the end of time. It is said: *'Afata* with his sheep *ya'fitu* *'aftan*.
Al-Asma'i said: The *Khashib* sword to people is the polished one, but it is actually the one filed but not smoothed. It is said: Have you finished the sword? He says answering him: I have roughed it (*khashabtuhu*). Likewise arrows are roughed then smoothed (*tukhlaq*). So *Al-Khashb*: The first shaping. *Al-Takhliq*: Smoothing them upon finishing them. From it is the smooth rock (*Al-Safat Al-Khalqa'*). It is said: A sword *Mashquq al-Khashibah*, which is widening it when forging, then splitting it to make two swords from it. It is said: So-and-so roughs (*Yakhshubu*) poetry, i.e., passes it as it comes and happens, and does not refine it. Al-Ajjaj said:
*And a shaft of Athal wood, he did not rough out (*ma takhashshaba*).*
It is said: *Takhashshaba* the Athal wood from it a shaft. *Al-Takhashshub* is not removing from the wood its branches and excesses. This is as it is said: He went out cutting branches (*yataqaddabu al-qudban*), and went out gathering truffles (*yatakamma'u al-kam'ah*).
Some wise men of the Arabs said: "The prayer of the penitent is when the young camels feel the heat (*tarmadu*)."
It is said: So-and-so is *Mukhaddam* and So-and-so is *Muqaddam*. *Al-Mukhaddam* is the best of them in equipment and softest in living. *Qadama yaqdimu*, and *Khadama yakhdimu*. It is narrated from Abu Dharr, may Allah have mercy on him: "You eat moist/luscious (*takhdamun*) and we eat dry (*naqdamu*), and the appointment is Allah."
It is said: "Excellent is what wove its garment," meaning the weaving.
From proverbs: "The pure milk (*Al-Sarih*) is under the foam."
It is narrated from Ibn Umar from Al-Hasan that he said: "Talk to these hearts for they are quick to decay, and restrain these souls for they are yearning/ambitious."
Al-Asma'i: Al-Walid ibn al-Qasim informed us, saying: Mu'awiyah said: "There was nothing in youth but I had an enjoyment from it, except that I was not a much-marrier (*Nukahah*) nor a wrestler (*Sur'ah*) nor a reviler (*Subb*)," i.e., I was not intense in reviling.

Issue from the Revelation

His Almighty's saying: (And when We intend to destroy a city, We command (*amarna*) its affluent ones but they defiantly disobey therein; so the word comes into effect upon it, and We destroy it with [complete] destruction) [Quran 17:16]. It is read: *Amarna* with lightening (no shadda). It can be from *Al-Amr* (command), the opposite of prohibition. And it can be in the meaning of "We increased". It is said: *Amartu* the thing *fa-amara*, i.e., I increased it so it increased. It came in the tradition: "The best of wealth is a prolific mare (*muhrah ma'murah*) or a pollinated row of palms (*sikkah ma'burah*)." And *Ammarna* with Tashdid (shadda) would be from *Al-Imarah* (authority) and empowerment. And *Amarna* with Madd (long A) would be in the meaning of "We increased" only. It is said: *Amara* the people and *Amara-hum* Allah, so the addition of Alif is for transfer and transitivity.
Most people made the answer to *Idha* (When/If) *Amarna* according to its mentioned aspects. In every aspect there is a question. From that: If it is asked regarding *Amarna* with lightening: How is Allah Almighty's will to destroy a people permissible before He commands them and they counter His command with disobedience and wickedness? The answer: The mention of will (*Irada*) is metaphorical, and its reality is what preceded in His knowledge of their deserving destruction. This is as it is said: If the merchant intends his bankruptcy, he buys with cash and sells on credit; while it is apparent that there is no will from him for that. Another aspect is: If We intend in the future the destruction of a city, We command its affluent ones in the present, so they disobey; because on this [interpretation], what the questioner denied is removed from it.
It is asked regarding *Ammarna* with Tashdid: How is it permissible that they be destroyed and empowered *until* they disobey so they are destroyed? And is that anything but assistance from Allah Almighty in disobedience and wickedness and the necessity of destruction? The answer is that Allah Almighty empowers them to pour good upon them and bliss for them so they may be grateful and worship. If they oppose, become arrogant, rebellious, and wicked, they are only approached from their bad choice, and punished and destroyed for what they presented of their blameworthy actions. Similar question and answer apply to the reading of one who read *Amarna* with Madd and lightening.
Some said: The answer to *Idha* is deleted, and His saying: (We command its affluent ones) along with what is conjoined to it is a description (Sifah). As if He said: If We intended that, it would be easy and not impossible.
It is said: The Fa' in His saying: *Fa-dammarnaha* (so We destroyed it) is extra, because it is the answer. The meaning: If We intended the destruction of a city whose description is that We commanded it with obedience so they disobeyed and the Word and Judgment became due upon it due to what preceded in Our knowledge of it and its bad destiny, We destroyed it. What indicates the permissibility of the extra Fa' is what Al-Akhfash narrated of the saying of some: "Akhuka fa-wujida" (Your brother, so he was found), meaning *wujida*, and the saying of the poet:
*And if I perish, then at that, so grieve.*
Do you not see that one of the two Fa's must be made extra.
Better than these aspects in my view and further from objection and criticism is to say: The Fa' in His saying: *Fa-dammarnaha* is the one with which the condition is answered, not the conjunction nor the extra one. That is because *Idha*, since it implies the meaning of conditionality (*Mujazah*), is answered with what *In* and its sisters are answered with, even if it does not operate their operation mostly. It is answered with Fa' because of what follows it of inchoative and predicate and verb. The Fa' was only needed because the answer differed from the condition. If the verb is narrated after the Fa', know that the inchoative is deleted, and were it not for that, the Fa' would not be needed. The future and past verbs in that are equal. Witness to that is the saying of Amr ibn al-Mukhlat:
*Whoever has met envy from the meadow ... then for Qays in it there is a private [pasture] and a Cutter.*
If it is so, and His saying: *Amarna mutrafiha* with what is conjoined to it is a description for the city, then the estimation of the verse is: If We intended the destruction of a city commanded with obedience, disobedient, wicked, upon which the Word has become due, then We destroy it with destruction. Similar to that is the saying of Allah Almighty: (And whoever returns, then Allah will take retribution from him) [Quran 5:95], (And whoever disbelieves, then I will grant him enjoyment for a little) [Quran 2:126], (If a wound touches you, then a wound like it has touched the people) [Quran 3:140]. Do you not see that He raised the future verb after the Fa' because it is built on the inchoative, and if He wanted the answer to be with the verb, He would have dispensed with the Fa' and made the verb jussive. But the estimation is: Whoever returns, *then He*, Allah will take retribution from him. And whoever disbelieves, *then I* will grant him enjoyment for a little. And if a wound touches you, *then the matter and affair is*, a wound like it has touched the people. If the Fa' is from His saying: *Fa-dammarnaha*, then the answer: The verse is safe from the mentioned objections, and its path is easy, so know it, Allah willing.

Issue from the Traditions
In the Hadith of Umm Zar', the fifth woman said: "My husband, if he eats, he wraps (*laffa*); and if he drinks, he sips all (*ishtaffa*); and he does not insert the palm to know the grief (*bathth*)." Abu Ubayd said: *Al-Laff* in eating is increasing in it with mixing of its types. *Al-Ishtifaf* in drinking is to exhaust what is in the vessel and leave no leftover (*su'r*) in it. Taken from *Al-Shafafah*, which is the remainder staying in the vessel of drink. It is said in the proverb: Quenching is not by sipping all (*Al-Tashaff*).

His saying: "And he does not insert the palm to know the grief": I think he found her a disease or defect which she was depressed about, because *Al-Bathth* is sadness, so as if he does not insert his hand into her clothes to touch the defect and expose her; she describes him with generosity. Abu Muhammad al-Qutaybi said: However, she has blamed him in the first two phrases, because she described him with gluttony and stinginess in them, and praised him in the third, because she described him with generosity. So how are they combined? I do not see the saying except what Ibn al-A'rabi said. He narrated it: "My husband, if he eats he wraps, and if he drinks he sips all, and if he sleeps he wraps himself (*iltaffa*), and does not insert the palm so he knows the grief." He explained it saying: She meant that if he sleeps, he wraps himself aside and does not lie with her, and does not practice what a man practices with a woman if he wants to have intercourse with her, inserting the hand in her clothes and knowing the grief. There is no grief there other than the woman's love for her husband's closeness to her and her lying with him. So she alluded to that with *Al-Bathth* (grief), because the grief was because of it.
Al-Qutaybi said: It is as a woman from Kinanah said to her husband reproaching him: "Indeed your drinking is sipping all, and your lying down is falling down (*inji'af*), and your wrapping is wrapping up (*iltifaf*). And you are satiated a night you are hosted, and safe a night you fear." Similar is the saying of Aws:
*And the moist north wind blew, and when ... the bedfellow of the young girl spent the night wrapped up.*
i.e., wrapped up aside not lying with her. What I say is: What was objected to against Abu Ubayd regarding combining praise and blame in description according to what he explained is not objectionable. Because one who enumerates the traits of the described may combine what is praise and what is blame. This is as narrated from Luqman describing his brother: "He gives the fat young she-camel, and there is no hesitation (*la'thamah*) in him, except that he is the son of a slave woman." Al-Qutaybi explained this in his book in the Hadith of the son of Ad, saying: *Al-Ta'la'thum* is pausing regarding a thing until he thinks about it. He meant there is nothing in his traits to pause about and from praising him for, except that he is the son of a slave woman. As for what he narrated from Ibn al-A'rabi, it is closer and more likely than what Abu Ubayd mentioned.
Better than both is to make the whole speech praise. The woman would be describing her husband with smoothness of nature, ease of side, and his preference in all his states for agreeing with his family and comforting them, being open with them, beautiful in their agreement, leaving disgust with them, showing finding everything they bring closer agreeable, and satisfaction with everything they do. Reaching towards the removal of reserve from between them in their eating together and sitting together, so his life and theirs is pleasant, and surveillance and fear are removed from their group. If he eats, he partakes of everything present and combines whatever is possible. If he drinks, he finishes the last of what he gulps in, and exhausts all that is in his vessel. If he retires, he does not seek what necessitates concern for him and brings grief upon him, so he sees him interlocking his fingers, undoing with his thought the paths of worries, and pressing by his tracking the joints of matters, to know the hidden grief, and repel the stray sadness. This is as you see.
As for the addition in Ibn al-A'rabi's narration, which is: "If he sleeps he wraps himself (*iltaffa*)", the intended meaning is the opposite of what was mentioned, which is that he sticks to his family embracing (*mutawashshihan*) them. It is said: So-and-so wore so-and-so (*irtada*) and wrapped himself with him (*iltaffa bihi*), if he embraced him and coiled with him. He said:
*And both of us are wearing his companion ... like the wearing of the sword on the day of battle.*
Uways said:
*As if a cat, led by side, is under her stirrup ... and a rooster wrapped around her legs and two sparrows.*

Issue regarding words of Inclusion (*Shumul*) and Generality (*'Umum*)
Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds, and prayers upon the Prophet Muhammad and all his family. The majestic Sheikh Abu Ali Ahmad ibn Muhammad ibn al-Hasan ibn al-Hasan al-Marzuqi, may Allah prolong his grace, said:
Know that nouns which convey Inclusion and Generality have rulings, positions, and conditions. Among them are those which convey that definitively in a specific position, then if they leave that position—if they are capable of leaving—it is permissible that they convey it and are suitable for it, and permissible that they convey something else. Among them are those which are primarily to convey Singularity (*Wahdah*) and Isolation (*Infirad*), then if a word or state is conjoined with them, they convey Inclusion and Generality. Among them are those which convey by their wording the Genus (*Jins*) for which they were coined, then they turn to Singularity, and the turning is by a sign attaching to them and a change. Among them are those which convey Inclusion in Indefiniteness (*Tankir*) in one way, and convey it in Definiteness (*Ta'rif*) in another way, then neither takes the place of the other. Among them are those which convey Multiplicity (*Kathrah*), and their wording is the wording of the Singular, while formulated as a name for the Plural. Among them are those which convey Multiplicity and their wording is the wording of the Plural. Among them are those which convey Inclusion in the chapter of Negation and do not occur in Affirmation at all.

The First is what conveys Inclusion in a specific position. It divides into two parts:
One part adheres to that position and does not leave it, such as: *Kam* (How many/much), *Kayfa* (How), *Ayna* (Where), and *Mata* (When), because they adhere to the two positions of Ambiguity (*Ibham*), Interrogation (*Istifham*), and Condition (*Jaza'*). The occurrence of *Kam* in the Predicate (*Khabar*) does not infringe on what we mentioned, because it is more primary to Interrogation until it occurs in the Predicate if it occurs without a connection, so it remains on its limit in Interrogation regarding Ambiguity. We will clarify its state in the two chapters as needed in this place.
Another part leaves that position and transfers to another, and something conjoins with it in it which specifies it and removes Ambiguity from it, so it does not convey Inclusion and Generality. It may occur, with the specifier conjoined to it, conveying Multiplicity and Inclusion. That is like: *Man* (Who), *Ma* (What), and *Ayy* (Which). Do you not see that these nouns occur in the position of Ambiguity in the chapters of Condition and Interrogation in the same manner as the nouns that preceded in it, like: *Man 'indaka?* (Who is with you?), *Ma taf'alu?* (What are you doing?), *Man tadrib adrib* (Whoever you strike I strike), *Man tu'tihi ya'khudh* (Whoever you give takes), *Ayyuhum fi al-dar?* (Which of them is in the house?), and *Ayyuhum tukrim ukrim* (Whichever of them you honor I honor). So their ruling regarding Inclusion is the ruling of those. They also occur in the chapter of Predicate as relative pronouns (*Mawsulah*) clarified, or described (*Mawsufah*) limited. So it is more primary for them to signify the specified Singular in Indefiniteness. If they are described, something might also conjoin with them from which it is inferred that they convey Multiplicity and Inclusion. The first, though not needing an example due to its clarity, is like: *Ra'aytu man abuhu muntaliq* (I saw him whose father is leaving), *Ma sallamtuhu ila Zayd* (What I handed to Zayd), and *Ayyuhum fi al-dar* (Whichever of them is in the house). These are specialized by their relative clauses, definite in the meaning of *Alladhi*. And for the described indefinite like: *Rubba man ahsantu ilayhi asa'a ilayya* (Many a one whom I did good to did evil to me), because it means: *Rubba insan* (Many a human), and *Marartu bi-man zarifin* (I passed by a witty one), i.e., by a human. Likewise you say: *Marartu bi-ma salihin* (I passed by a good thing), i.e., by a good thing. His Almighty's saying: (This is what (*ma*) is with me, ready) [Quran 50:23] is interpreted that *Ma* in it is indefinite, and *Ladayya* is its adjective. Sibawayh said: This description is necessary for *Ma*, then he narrated it not described in Wonder (*Ta'ajjub*) and others, as if he means that is most of its states.

The Second is like His Almighty's saying: (And they worship other than Allah that which (*Ma*) does not harm them nor benefit them), then He said: (And they say, "These are our intercessors with Allah") [Quran 10:18]. And like His saying: (And they worship other than Allah that which (*Ma*) possesses not for them provision from the heavens and earth at all), then He said: (And they are not able) [Quran 16:73]. Do you not see that the context clarified its conveying Multiplicity? Ambiguous nouns have come like these. The nouns *Alladhi* (The one who) and its category is the Predicate, like His Almighty's saying: (And the one who (*Alladhi*) brought the truth), then He said: (Those are the righteous) [Quran 39:33]. And in His saying, Mighty and Majestic: (And among them are those who (*Man*) listen to you) [Quran 10:42], and this is very frequent.
As for the Second of the first division, which is what is primarily to convey Singularity and Isolation, then if a word or state conjoins with it, it conveys Inclusion and Generality, that is like: *'Ishruna dirhaman* (Twenty dirhams), *Ma ja'ani min rajulin* (No man came to me), *Hal ja'aka min khabarin* (Did any news come to you?), and like your saying: *Kullu insanin* (Every human), *Awwalu farisin* (First horseman), *Kullu rajulin* (Every man), and you say such. All this, its ruling in its original intent and coinage is to be for the Genus. Then by convention, it became primarily for the Singular, then what indicates its covering Multiplicity conjoined with it.
As for the Third: Which is what conveys by its wording the Genus for which it was coined, then turns to Singularity and Isolation by a sign attaching to it and a change. These are the Nouns of Actions (Verbal Nouns), like: *Al-Darb* (Beating), *Al-Darbah* (A beat), *Al-Insiraf* (Leaving), and *Al-Insirafah* (A departure). It is a condition of it and the condition of all generic nouns that they do not stop at little excluding much, nor much excluding little, except by indication.
As for the Fourth: Which is what conveys Inclusion in Indefiniteness in one way, and conveys it in Definiteness in another way, then neither takes the place of the other. Like your saying: *Kullu insanin* (Every human) says that. And like His Almighty's saying: (Indeed, mankind (*Al-Insan*) is in loss) [Quran 103:2]. And His saying, Mighty and Majestic: (Indeed, mankind (*Al-Insan*) was created anxious) [Quran 70:19]. And like your saying: *'Ishruna dirhaman* (Twenty dirhams), *'Ishruna dinaran*, *'Ishruna shatan* (sheep), *'Ishruna ba'iran* (camels). And like your saying: The Dinar and Dirham destroyed the people, and Sheep and Camel increased. Likewise: *Rubba sariqin* (Many a thief) was safe, and every sinner (*mudhnib*) and wicked person (*fasiq*) has his burden. And like His Almighty's saying: (The thief (*Al-Sariq*) and the female thief (*Al-Sariqah*)) [Quran 5:38]. And His saying: (The adulteress (*Al-Zaniyah*) and the adulterer (*Al-Zani*)) [Quran 24:2]. Do you not see that the definite of this section does not take the place of its indefinite, and likewise its indefinite does not take the place of the definite. And it is not like your saying: *Mi'atu dirhamin* (A hundred dirhams), and *Mi'atu al-dirhami* (A hundred of the dirham). And like your saying: He gives *Khazzan* (silk) and *Qazzan* and *Dirhaman* and *Dinaran*, and *Al-Khazz* and *Al-Qazz* and *Al-Dirham* and *Al-Dinar*. There was from it *Darban* and *Shatman*, and *Al-Darb* and *Al-Shatm*.
As for the Fifth: Which is what conveys Multiplicity and its wording is the wording of the Singular. These are nouns formulated for a Plural, like: *Kull* (All) from *Juz'* (Part) and *Ba'd* (Some). Like: *Qawm* (People) from *Rajul*, *Nisa'* (Women) from *Imra'ah*, *Ibil* (Camels) from *Naqah* and *Jamal*, and *Ula'i* (Those) from *Dha*. The second: That it be from the wording of the Plural with the singular noun formulated for Multiplicity. That is like: *Al-Jamil* from *Jamal*, *Al-Baqir* from *Baqar*, and like: *Al-Da'in* and *Al-Kalib*, from *Da'n* and *Kalb*.
As for the Sixth: Which is what conveys Multiplicity and its wording is the wording of the Plural. That is like sound plurals, like: *Al-Muslimun* and *Al-Muslimat*. And broken plurals, like: *Al-Fujjar* and *Al-Fussaq*. The structures of these plurals have details and rulings we will reach and detail. In general, they do not convey Inclusion and Multiplicity except after being stripped of what restricts them to numbers and specifies them.
As for the Seventh: Which is what conveys Inclusion in the chapter of Negation and does not occur in Affirmation at all. That is like their saying: *Ma fi al-dari dayyar* (There is no one in the house), *Ma biha turiyy*, and *Ma biha safir*. Do you not see that you do not say: *Biha safir*, *Biha turiyy*, and *Biha dayyar*. This is some detailing of that summary, and we will busy ourselves now with clarifying it and mentioning the evidences in it, Allah Almighty willing.

Know that what indicates that *Kam* (How many) is coined for Generality and Inclusion is that it is used to ask about numbers. When asked with it about a counted thing, the addressee is compelled to answer about the little of that questioned thing and the much of it, such that if he falls short, he has no excuse to say that the number of what you asked about is such and such, and your question did not cover [it]. Were it not that *Kam* encompasses every number, the state of the addressee when he wanted to answer would not be compelled to mention the number of the questioned thing definitively. Likewise is the state of *Kayfa* (How) regarding conditions (*Ahwal*), because it is used to ask about them. There is no condition for the questioned thing except *Kayfa* encompasses it, such that the addressee has nothing to cling to if he sends down the answer.
If it is said: How do you claim that for *Kayfa*, when we know that if a speaker said to another: "How are you?" and he started saying: "Washed of clothes, clean of body," and similar conditions of his, he [the speaker] would have the right to say: "I did not ask you about any of this." If the matter is so, how is the word *Kayfa* encompassing for asking about all conditions? And if it is encompassing, how can he say: "I did not ask you about anything of what you mentioned"? It is said to him: What you mentioned does not indicate that *Kayfa* is not encompassing for all conditions. That is because the convention of interlocutors is that if one asks the other about himself with the word *Kayfa*, he needs to consider which of his conditions the questioner intended, so he informs him about the condition of that questioned thing excluding others, because he is compelled [to understand] that he did not ask him about all his conditions. If the word *Kayfa* encompassed them by coinage, then what he did not ask him about became like the excepted from their totality. A thing becomes excepted by wording, and becomes excepted by custom (*'Urf*), reason (*'Aql*), and Sharia (*Shar'*). If the matter is so, and there is no condition of the conditions of that convention between them except that it is valid to be asked about with the word *Kayfa*, and it is permissible that he intends it, and it is not excepted by custom and reason, then its encompassing of all of them is established by this evidence, and what the questioner asked falls by what we mentioned and clarified that it is like the excepted, so know it.
If it is said: What do you deny that *Kayfa* covers [only] that which you claimed is the intent of the questioner and the questioned, which needs to be intended for answer after contemplating and understanding it, not others. And that your saying: "It covers everything by coinage originally, and the extra is like the excepted" is corrupt? It is said: What you mentioned does not impugn the evidence. We reveal what we mentioned by what supports the evidence and drops the question, which is that we found the affirmation with what is indefinite (*Nakirah*), like *Salih* (Good) and *Mu'afa* (Healed), and what runs this course. If the question were about a specific thing, its answer would come out in the manner of definites (*Ma'arif*). In the fact that its answer only comes indefinite is an indication that what you mentioned was not intended by it upon coinage. What reveals what we mentioned is that the definite was prevented from being in the answer to *Kayfa*—so it is said: *Al-Salih* and *Al-Mu'afa*—because the speech would exit to being an answer to a question about essences (*Dhat*) not about their conditions. If the questioner about conditions with *Kayfa* intended to ask about a specific thing among them, the ruling of that thing in specification would be the ruling of the essence, so its answer would come definite, but its answer only comes indefinite. If the matter is as we mentioned, just as it is not permissible for its answer to be definite because it exits in the question to covering the essence, likewise in the condition (*Hal*) it is not permissible that it covers a specific thing among them, because that necessitates its answer be definite.
By such a method we clarify the state of *Ayna* (Where) in places, and *Mata* (When) in times, this is in the chapter of Interrogation. As for *Kam* and *Kayfa*, they have no entry in Condition (*Jaza'*). And *Ayna* and *Mata*, their state in Condition is like their state in Interrogation. As for *Kam* in the Predicate (*Khabar*), it remains on its ambiguity, due to what we mentioned that the chapter of Interrogation is more primary for it, evidenced by the fact that it was not connected in it, even though it is a chapter of clarification and explanation, as was done with its sisters in it. If a speaker says: "Kam rajulin akramtuhu" (How many a man I honored), its meaning is many men. The multiplicity he refers to does not reach the limit of inclusion for the whole genus, even if he is not stopping at a specific amount. For this reason, it was permitted to be added to the singular and the plural, so it is said: "Kam rajulin" and "Kam rijalin". In Interrogation, it is only specified by the generic noun in singular form. This multiplication we described, he accompanied it to the Predicate, because that is effective in it inevitably. Do you not see that it is objectionable in reason that the speaker of "Kam rajulin akramtuhu" honored the entire genus? If the chapter were the chapter of Negation or Interrogation or Condition, that would not be objectionable. This is revealed by the slightest contemplation, so know it.

What indicates that *Man* (Who) and *Ma* (What), which are the second category of what conveys Inclusion, convey Inclusion in the position we mentioned, which is Ambiguity in the chapters of Condition and Interrogation, are evidences from what we inferred in the first type: That the questioned is compelled in the genus he was asked about to answer, such that he has no escape by claiming the questioner's wording covered such and such, excluding such and such. Here the place becomes clear by contemplating the motives that called for coining these words. It is that they looked into what they ask about of conditions, times, places, numbers, genera, and rational beings, and found themselves with the questioned in a state that necessitated upon them formulating comprehensive, encompassing words. Otherwise, the questioned could deviate from answering what he is asked about, even if the questioner burdened himself with many matters and elaborated speech that tired him and was difficult for him. Do you not see that the questioner about a counted number imagining it with others of a genus, if he said to him: Is such with you of this genus or such or such, until he multiplied names of numbers, and exhausted times in that, he would not be safe from what is with him being less than the numbers we mentioned or more than them. Likewise here in conditions, if he enumerated many conditions in a specific questioned object, he would not be safe from it being on others. Likewise in times, if we mentioned many times of past and future, he would not be safe with the extension of times that the questioned object is in others, so his answer would not come out according to his intent. Likewise in rational beings, if he mentioned most of whom he knows, he would not be safe from it being others. This, and a human has been asked about what he does not know, just as he is asked about whom he knows. Mentioning whom he knows is impossible in the manner we mentioned. As for whom he does not know, it is impossible that he mentions him. Since the matter is like this, they resorted to formulating words sufficient from prolongation, comprehensive of genera, compelling to the questioned, such that if they wanted the answer, [they would have] no ending to the intent. In that is evidence for the position he wants to indicate of the inclusion of these words for what they were coined for, and their encompassing what is not hidden.
Among them is that when the questioned hears these words, if he considers, he does not find in the genera he is asked about with them a cause except that it is fit to be an answer to the questioner, if he intends it and makes it an answer. Were it not for the inclusion of these words for the genera they were coined for [and] their encompassing, it would not be valid in every [part] and some of it to be an answer. If this evidence is objected to by saying that whoever says: "Man dakhala dari akramtuhu" (Whoever enters my house I honor him) in Condition, that the thief is not permitted to be intended; and if he said: "Man dakhala dari ahantuhu" (Whoever enters my house I insult him), it is not permitted that the angel/king be intended. And likewise what runs this course. The answer to it is that the word covers the whole in the origin of coinage, and what exited from it by reason or custom or Sharia, is as if it was extracted from it by exception. Do you not see that if he said: "Whoever enters my house is held accountable," or: "Whoever enters my house is rewarded or punished," and He said: "Allah created whoever (*Man*) is in the heavens and earth," or "what (*Ma*) is in the heavens and earth," every worshipper and existent of Jinn and Angel and others would enter under this, if the speaker is one who knows that worship includes these genera, likewise reward and punishment and creation. Were it not that the word is comprehensive, the rulings of reports and promises and what is guaranteed for them would change, and reporting in these words that are used in these places. You knew that the origin of coinage in them is what we mentioned, nothing else.
Among them is the permissibility of excepting the excepted from them whatever he wished, reaching whatever it reached in fewness and abundance. Were it not for the inclusion of these words and their encompassing, exception from them would not be permissible to the limit we mentioned. This is not impugned by the saying of the sayer: That with exception it is as if it was coined for that which it indicates. Nor his saying: It did not convey Inclusion in a way, because according to you it is not free from exception, or what runs the course of exception of custom and reason. Because whoever considers what the word conveys in its isolation, and upon exception from it what the exception conveys in it, and were it not for exception how the state of the word would be—it becomes clear to him that this question is fallen. Likewise whoever considers that the word and its coinage is one thing, and the dominance of custom, reason, and Sharia over it is another thing, occurring upon it after the convention on it, just as exception from it by word is after convention on it.
Know that his saying: "It never conveyed Inclusion" is corrupt, because the word must be precedent to what it was coined for, to custom and reason both, because these two dominate it like the domination of the word specifying it afterwards.

If it is said: What do you deny that reason at the time of coinage dominates it just as custom and word dominate later? It is said to him: If reason dominates in the place you pointed to, it would prevent coining the name for it from the start. Whenever the coiner intends coinage with the prevention of reason from it, he is like one undertaking an impossibility, or playing with what he coins. If the matter is like this, and reason does not prevent nor forbid, an encompassing name is coined for it. Rather, how would it forbid when the need touches upon it as we clarified? So it must be that the convention has occurred with it, and that reason dominated after the coinage so it specified, just as custom dominates after it, and as the word dominates after it. In this, for one who looks carefully, is sufficiency.
Among them is that words were only coined according to the need for them. We have known that one of us, just as he intends to report about sensed individuals, likewise he intends to report about known genera, and attaches the intended [meaning] to them as he attaches it to singulars. If the matter is so, there must be in their speech what conveys the genus, including it, encompassing it; otherwise, the deficiency of the Arabic language regarding meanings occurring in the soul would appear. Even if it must be that their need for what they express is like our need, and their motives like our motives. If the matter is so, and the intention from us to report about the genus with a word comprehensive of all of them is valid, then likewise their matter must be like our matter. If their matter is like our matter, there must be in their language what conveys that in reality not metaphorically, and this is in the nouns we mentioned.
By this which we mentioned, the saying of one who claims that it is not impossible that words are suitable for Inclusion without being conveying of it in reality, restricted to it, falls. It is supported by the fact that we found these nouns conveying these genera in the places we pointed to by way of regularity in them. Among the signs of what is reality in a thing is its regularity in it and its continuity. If these words are continuous in conveying these genera in the ways we mentioned, they must be reality for them.
These evidences we mentioned contain what indicates conveying Inclusion and Generality in *Man* and *Ma* if they transfer from the place of Ambiguity to the chapter of Clarification and Explanation, which is the chapter of Predicate (*Khabar*) also. That is the permissibility of exception from us in the way we clarified, and the validity of intention attaching from us to what conveys Inclusion and Generality if we wanted reporting about a genus, and that their way is like our way, and that there must be in their speech what conveys that in reality, otherwise the language would be deficient from what was occurring in their souls then, and in our souls now. This is the state of *Man* and *Ma*, and they are for Encompassing.
As for *Ayy*, it is for a part of a whole. Although it is not specific to some over some, but each of them is valid by way of substitution and according to what is estimated as a part of the totality, it does not convey Encompassing. Due to the intensity of its ambiguity, addition became necessary for it. The meaning of ambiguity in it is that it is not specific to a genus over a genus, just as each of *Man* was specific. Do you not see that you do not intend a genus? *Ayy* is used in the general, so it is more inclusive than *Man* and *Ma* in this aspect, and below them in what it conveys of Encompassing.
As for what is primarily to convey Singularity and Isolation, then if a word or state conjoins with it, it conveys Inclusion and Generality, like their saying: "Ishruna dirhaman" (Twenty dirhams), "Ma ja'ani min rajulin" (No man came to me), "Hal ja'aka min khabarin" (Did any news come to you?), "La rajula fi al-dar" (There is no man in the house). And like your saying: "Kullu insanin" (Every human), "Awwalu farasin" (First horse), and what resembles this. These indefinite nouns convey Encompassing by what conjoined with them of words before them, since they and their likes were made by custom and usage such that conveying Singularity by themselves is more primary, even if they were coined for units and above. Here in these nouns is like the mark and change in verbal nouns. What indicates that is that *Min* in your saying: "Ma ja'ani min rajulin", and "Hal 'indaka min shay'in", is not permissible to enter upon a specific singular. You do not say: "Ma ja'ani min Zaydin" (No Zayd came to me). Were it not that it conveys in *Rajul*—when conjoined with it in your saying: "Ma ja'ani min rajulin", "Hal ja'aka min khabarin", "Hal 'indaka min shay'in"—Multiplicity and Inclusion, it would not be prevented from entering upon the specific singular as well. Since it was prevented from it, and your saying *Rajul* is either that the intended by it is one of a tribe unspecified, or the Tribe as it is,

And we have known from their language and intent that they do not mean negation of an unspecified one in their saying: "Ma ja'ani min rajulin" (No man came to me), so nothing remains except that it conveys negation of the Tribe as it is encompassing the nouns. You, if you said: "Ma ja'ani rajulun" without *Min*, it is more primary that you intend by it negation of an unspecified one. Likewise your saying: "Ishruna rajulan" (Twenty men); your saying "Ishruna" alerted that the intent is the whole Genus, since it is not permissible that it conveys an unspecified one along with the conjunction of Twenty with it due to the corruption entering the meaning, and because it is apparent that the intended by "Twenty men" is twenty from the men, and from the Tribe which is Men. Likewise if you said: "Kullu rajulin" (Every man), *Kull* clarifies that *Rajul* afterwards is general for the Genus. Likewise your saying: "Hal 'indaka min ahadin" (Is there anyone with you), *Ahad* is in the meaning of Plural evidenced by the fact that it is not permissible to occur for one, if the intent by which it is valid in non-one is not valid in one, unless there is a position where a benefit close to what we mentioned in non-one is obtained, like the sayer's saying: "Ja'ani al-yawma kullu ahadin" (Everyone came to me today), because this, even if it conveys Multiplicity, does not convey Encompassing. It is as we mentioned regarding *Kam* if it transfers from the chapter of Interrogation to the chapter of Predicate.
If it is said: Why do you not say: "Ja'ani 'ishruna wahidan" (Twenty ones came to me), because what is after Twenty is only in the meaning of Plural according to your claim? It is said to him from before: Twenty and its likes is a specific number needing clarification of the counted upon which the count fell, and that is what generic nouns convey, and *Ahad* is not among them. We have clarified that these nouns, when they exceed the position in which they convey Singularity and Isolation, turn to the Genus, and there must be conjunction of what conveys it.
If it is said your saying: "Kullu rajulin" and "Kullu insanin", is it permissible that the definite generic noun take the place of the indefinite here, because each of them conveys the benefit of its companion according to your claim, and be like your saying: "Mi'atu dirhamin" and "Mi'atu al-dirhami" if you intended Definition? It is said: No. But if Definition is intended in your saying: "Kullu rajulin", you say: "Kullu al-rijali", and in "Kullu insanin", "Kullu al-nasi". And "Kullu insanin" (Every the human) and "Kullu al-rajuli" (Every the man) is not permissible. That is because: "Kullu rajulin" is in the meaning of: "Kullu ahadin" (Everyone), and its summary is: All men, if they were man by man, on the limit of your saying: "Kullu ithnayni" i.e.: All people, if they were two by two. And like your saying: "Huma khayru ithnayni fi al-nasi" (They are the best two in people), i.e.: They are the best of people, if they were two by two. If you intended Definition, it exits from this, because such estimation is not possible in it [leading] to your saying: "Kullu al-rijali", "Kullu al-nasi", and there is no other. And "Mi'atu rajulin", *Ahad* does not take its place due to what we clarified in our saying: "Ishrina" and their likes. When you added the Hundred to *Rajul*, and you had finished with the number so you needed the Category, you defined what was indefinite, so you said: "Mi'atu al-dirhami". In this is a clear distinction between: "Mi'atu dirhamin" and its tribe, and between "Kullu ahadin" and its tribe, so understand it.
If it is said: Why did you prevent "Kullu al-rajuli", while Allah Mighty and Majestic says: (All food (*Kullu al-ta'ami*) was lawful to the Children of Israel) [Quran 3:93]? I say: This question is a mistake or fallacy, because Food in its inclusion of types is like People (*Al-Nas*) in its inclusion of types. We have permitted saying: "Kullu al-nasi", and we only prevented saying: "Kullu rajulin" and "Kullu al-rajuli". We have indicated it with what is sufficient, so know it.
As for their saying: "Ahkaka al-nasu al-dinara wa al-dirhama" (People destroyed the Dinar and the Dirham), this is not among what relies in conveying Multiplicity on something before it, as we mentioned in indefinites. But whenever it is stripped of what specifies it, it must be covering the Genus, encompassing it, and indicating that Alif and Lam are for Definition and Specification. The Specified Defined, just as it can be sensed, perceived, familiar, it can be known, rational. Alif and Lam refer to specifying that defined [noun] according to what is valid to specify it with. If it is familiar, perceived, sensed, the reference by Alif and Lam is to defining it in that way. And if it is known, rational, the reference by it is to defining it in that way. Our saying: *Rajul* is either that the intended by it is one of the Genus unspecified, or the Genus as it is. Likewise if Alif and Lam enter it and what specifies it with a specific familiar does not conjoin with it, it must convey the second position which belongs to it of the two positions, which is the Genus as it is. It is inferred that your saying: "Ahlaka al-nasu al-dinara wa al-dirhama, wa kathura al-sha'u wa al-ba'iru" (People destroyed the Dinar and Dirham, and Sheep and Camel increased) - the intended by it is Generality and Multiplicity - from what preceded of the permissibility of excepting the group from this singular noun in wording. Likewise the second indication from the need to attach the intended to the generic noun conveying Generality.

If it is said: If the indefinite conveys that as you claimed before, then what is the benefit of this definition? It is said to him: The intent in it is referring to what is established in the soul and understood of knowledge of types. The Dirham in this or similar is not like a single one you knew and knew sensed, then pointed to it, because knowledge of types from this perspective is impossible, and it is not permissible that any of us knows types sensed, as some individuals are known so. Since the matter is so, and it is not impossible in their language that the indefinite word provides what the definite provides, and the definite provides like what the indefinite provides by conjunction of indicators, likewise what we mentioned in generic nouns is not impossible, that their indefinite conveys like what their definite conveys by conjunction of indicators. So if it is definite, its wording accords with its conveyed meaning. If it is indefinite, it only clarifies what is clarified from it and its indicators that brought it to that limit.
As for the saying of one who says: Alif and Lam convey Genus, and its estimation is that it was coined in the language for that, it is ignorance of language and art, because Alif and Lam, their benefit is nothing but Definition. Our saying: "Alif and Lam" is leniency from us and running on the habit of grammarians, because the Lam is what was coined for Definition only. The Alif with it is Hamzat al-Wasl, so know it.
If it is said: How did you claim that Alif and Lam in the like of this definition enter what conveys Multiplication without Singularity, while you say: "Kharajtu fa-ra'aytu al-asada" (I went out and saw the lion), and its definition is that definition, while you do not intend Multiplication nor Encompassing, but the intent is: I went out and saw the one of this genus, without specification or particularization? I say: This was only permitted in this type of singulars due to its resemblance to the Type in that it is not familiar by sense, just as the Type is not so. As if you placed the Genus in place of the Singular due to the name falling on it like its falling on the Genus, and because the General is used in place of the Specific, like their saying: "Asiru 'alayhi al-abada" (I march on it forever), while the intent is: I march on it, much. Since the matter is so, it is like a thing borrowed from its chapter for other than its chapter. Similar to it is what is used of the plural wording in place of the singular. Do you not see that it is good to say to one who owned a slave, or gave a dinar: "Sira tamliku al-'abida wa tahabu al-dananira" (You became owning slaves and giving dinars), even if what he owned or gave was only one. Just as you permit with plural, likewise you permit with generic noun, defined in the unspecified singular, even if that is of the benefit of indefinites. Do you not see that there is no difference between his saying: "Kharajtu fa-ra'aytu al-asada" and his saying: "Kharajtu fa-ra'aytu asadan", except what you see of definition. Yes, it is possible to say: If it were said: "Kharajtu fa-ra'aytu asadan", the listener might allow following his saying *asadan* with an adjective of adjectives. So if the speaker falls silent and does not follow it with the adjective, it becomes clear to him later that his intent was one of the genus unspecified and undescribed. If it were said: "Kharajtu fa-ra'aytu al-asada", the listener would know that the intent is the one of the genus and would not wait for the adjective that is permissible to come with the indefinite. This may be among the benefits of what has Alif and Lam. In any case, definition did not increase specification that was not in indefiniteness. The indefinite that conveys the benefit of definites refers by it to indefinites limited by descriptions and conditions, until it runs the course of pointing to the meaning, like your saying: "Fina rajulun 'alayhi darra'atun sha'nuhu kadha" (Among us is a man wearing a coat whose affair is such), and there is no one in the group wearing a coat other than him. The definite that conveys the indefinite is other than your saying: "Mithluka shibhuka, hasanu al-wajhi" (Your like is your resemblance, beautiful of face), because this is from the perspective of wording, not because of the ambiguity presented in the position. If you say instead of your saying: "Fina rajulun 'alayhi darra'atun", "Fina Zaydun aw Abu Fulanin aw ghulamuka" (Among us is Zayd or Abu Fulan or your servant), and in the group the name of each one of them or his description or his Kunya is like that name or description or Kunya, the benefit of the definite—if the matter is so—would be the benefit of the indefinite.

If it is said to him: You claimed that if Alif and Lam enter the generic noun, and it is stripped of what specifies it, it is encompassing and inclusive. What do you deny that the intended by it is the Tribe and the Genus unspecified? Likewise, it is valid to intend the Genus without wanting Encompassing. If it is so, its turning to Encompassing needs an evidence conjoining with it conveying that in it. Otherwise, due to its emptiness of what conveys Specification in it, it only exits to conveying the Genus merely. I say: Whoever contemplates generic nouns, how they were formulated, and why they were coined, dispenses with this question by that. That is because they only intended to distinguish genera from each other in coining names for them, just as they intended to distinguish individuals. They coined [them] with the condition that it covers the One to wherever it ends and reaches, and sufficed for it with that name in distinguishing it from what differs from it. Therefore, they did not pluralize it nor dualize it, because they formulated it with the condition that it conveys what it was coined for, whatever amount it reaches, and however it increases or decreases. A thing is only valid to be dualized and pluralized if it is restricted, evidenced by the fact that dualization is adding a thing to its like, and pluralization is adding a thing to its likes or similars. If this addition which we pointed to is not valid except in what has stopped [is limited], then this meaning is not valid in the generic noun. If the state of the generic noun is this state, whenever nothing conjoins with it specifying it to some of what it was coined for, it must be inclusive of all of it, encompassing, because its coinage is on that. How can it convey the Genus as it is, and not be encompassing of it? If that is according to what we mentioned, there is no meaning to the sayer's saying: It conveys the Genus without Encompassing, because that is imaginable in the position where one says this: If the intended meaning attaches to part of the Genus, and for other than that part is the name of the Genus. That is not known except by indication, just as Isolation and Specification are not known except by indication.
If it is said: Do you not permit saying: "Place this money in this Genus," pointing by it to men, and not intending All and Encompassing? If that is permissible in its wording *Al-Jins*, what denies that it be permissible in the generic noun also? I say: His saying: "Place this money in this Genus" is specified by custom. Therefore he was commanded to spend it on some of the Genus not all of it. Because it is not in custom that the One covers the Genus, as it is by connection or command. If it is so, were it not for the customary specification we mentioned, their saying: "The Genus" would include all of them. If the state of the word *Al-Jins* is this state, likewise the state of the generic noun is this state; whenever it is stripped of what specifies it from custom, Sharia, reason, or word, it is only inclusive, so know it.
From this category is their saying: "Awwalu farisin" (First horseman), because by the entry of *Awwal*, *Faris* exited from conveying what is more primary to it of Singularity and Isolation, and became conveying Inclusion and Generality. On that is His Mighty and Majestic saying: (And do not be the first disbeliever (*awwala kafirin*) in it) [Quran 2:41]. For this reason, Al-Akhfash interpreted it as meaning: The first who disbelieved in it. Others said: Its meaning is: First group disbelieving in it. The difference between the two ways is that Al-Akhfash made it encompassing, so he put *Man* in its place as if the intended was: And do not be the first of disbelievers in it when it becomes disbeliever by disbeliever. Others made it on another way, so they diverted it to a group of the Tribe unknown, as if he said: First of disbelievers in it if they became group by group. Most of our Basran companions are on the method of Abu al-Hasan al-Akhfash, and it is not correct, as we indicated and clarified, because claiming the deletion of *Fariq* and setting up *Kafir*, which is its adjective, in its place, needs evidence.
From this category is their saying: "Rubba rajulin" (Many a man), and "Kam rajulin" (How many a man), because *Rajul* by the entry of *Kam* and *Rubba* upon it became conveying Multiplicity and encompassing. What indicates that to you is that *Kam* conveys Multiplication of what it enters upon without end, and *Rubba* conveys Minimization of it unconfined. But based on what the informer sees of the littleness of the thing and its abundance. Were it not that *Rajul* after them is for Encompassing, the entry of either of them upon it would not be valid. How does the Much which has no known end emerge, except from the word which conveys Encompassing? And likewise the Little which is on the limit we mentioned.
From this category are the active and passive participles like their saying: *Al-Kafir* (Disbeliever), *Al-Sariq* (Thief), *Al-Zani* (Adulterer), *Al-Muslim* (Muslim), *Al-Mu'min* (Believer).

Know that their saying: *Al-Fasiq* and *Al-Zani* is placed in the position of: *Alladhi fasaqa* (He who sinned) and *Zana* (committed adultery), and the Alif and Lam in it mean *Alladhi*. This is because the verb, since it was not coined for Specification, but was coined to be a useful predicate only, was prevented from what its occurrence would be for Specification like Addition (*Idafa*) and Alif and Lam. But just as they made it, I mean the verb, part of the completion of *Alladhi*, they loved that Specification covers it also, so they transferred it to the active participle. They intended by Alif and Lam in it—even if its coming in the origin of speech is for Specification only—the meaning of *Alladhi* which the verb used to carry in the relative clause of *Alladhi*, so Alif and Lam would be completed by the active participle as that [relative clause] was completed by the verb. Just as *Alladhi*, if not conjoined with what specifies it to a specific one, turns to the Genus, so what indicates its encompassing and inclusion is what indicates in the generic noun; there is no difference between them. Its matter is close to its implication of the meaning of Condition (*Jaza'*), such that it is answered with what Condition is answered with of Fa'. Just as Condition with Ambiguity, where the ruling of the noun used in it became what we clarified and evidenced—which is *Man* and *Ma*—likewise is the ruling of the active and passive participle, evidenced by His Almighty's saying: (The thief (*Al-Sariq*) and the female thief (*Al-Sariqah*), cut off their hands) [Quran 5:38], in the status of his saying had he said: Whoever steals, cut off his hand. Abu al-Abbas al-Mazini narrated that the active participle is entered by Alif and Lam conveying Definition only; its entry upon it is like its entry upon the generic noun, when you say: *Al-Rajul*. This, even if it is a disagreement from our companions, has no entry in what we are in.
If it is said: I see you turning your speech regarding Alif and Lam on [the basis] that it has two places: One is definition of Familiarity (*'Ahd*), and the second is definition of Genus. Yet you may say: "Hadha al-rajulu fa'ala kadha aw kadha" (This man did such or such) without there being familiarity regarding him between you and the addressee. So if you were [saying] by his saying and no familiarity [existed], and it is apparent that your saying: "Hadha al-rajulu" does not intend the Genus, why didn't you say: It has a third place, which is your saying: "Hadha al-rajulu" and "Tilka al-mar'atu", while you point to two present ones, one by distance and the other by proximity. I say: *Al-Rajul* and *Al-Mar'ah* were transferred by what accompanied them of the demonstrative noun to the present. They are originally for the Genus. It is not impossible for what is for the Genus to have something conjoin with it making it for one of the Genus, because the generic noun encompasses the One to infinity, so know it.
From this category is their saying: "Ni'ma al-rajulu Zaydun" (Excellent is the man, Zayd), and "Habbadha Zaydun" (Beloved is Zayd), because *Dha* is like *Al-Rajul*. *Al-Rajul* is a generic noun. The meaning: Zayd is praised in his tribe. Except that it is not encompassing, evidenced by the fact that it is dualized and pluralized, so it is said: "Ni'ma al-rajulani al-Zaydani", "Ni'ma al-rijalu al-Zayduna". If it were encompassing, its dualization would not be valid. Neither is the saying of the sayer: "Zayd is praised among men," and if they became man by man, correct. Nor is the saying: "It is for a specific one" correct, because the occurrence of *Rajul* in the place of *Ahad* so that it covers the units of the Genus by way of substitution only happens in the indefinite. As for when it becomes definite, it does not convey unity. Therefore we did not say: "Kullu al-rajuli", nor: "Kullu al-insani", and the evidence for that has passed. Nor is it permissible that it be for a specific one, because if it were so, what conveys Specification of proper nouns and others would not be prevented from occurring in its place, due to their equality in conveying a specific one. In the prevention of that is evidence that it is for the Genus not for the specific one.
If it is said: Then *Al-Rajul* from your saying: "Ni'ma al-rajulu", to which aspect do you direct it if you do not make it encompassing? I say: The praiser as if he knew Zayd and his likes, or knew him and his tribe which he is from, so he wanted praise to cover him while he is preferred over them. So he borrowed the word of the Genus for some of them. Its dualization and pluralization became indicative of his intent, because when he took *Al-Rajul* to be restricted to his likes or his tribe which he is from, it became specific or standing at a number, so it became capable of dualization and pluralization. As if when we said: "Ni'ma al-rajulani al-Zaydani", we said: The two Zayds are praised in their two tribes. Each tribe of the two tribes is different from the other, even if in one aspect, because the similarity of two things, each one of them to the other in every aspect, is corrupt and not permissible. It has been known from the principles of language and the saying of our grammarian companions: That generic nouns are dualized and pluralized if they differ. His Almighty's saying: (Nay, His hands (*yadahu*) are outstretched) [Quran 5:64] has been interpreted as dualization of the Genus, as if two genera of blessing, the blessing of the world and the Hereafter, or the blessing of religion and the world.
From this category is their saying: "Qalla rajulun yaqulu dhaka" (Rarely does a man say that), and "Aqalla rajulin yaqulu dhaka".

Do you not see that it is not permissible for you to intend a specific single person from the tribe by your saying 'rajul' (a man), because one cannot be less than one in number. The intention of the speaker with this is not this purpose, nor is it to convey less contempt and humiliation. Rather, the intent is: The sayers of that are few, meaning: No one says that. If the matter is so, 'rajul' conveys the genus, and nothing else is encompassing; rather it is on the way of substitution, as if he said: The sayers of that are few if they became man by man. The meaning of: "Qalla rajulun yaqulu dhaka" (Rarely does a man say that) is like the meaning of: "Aqalla rajulin" (The least of men/Rarely a man), and this is not the place for its explanation. The distinction between the two words or the equality, except in what we mentioned of the state of your saying: That 'rajul' occurs in both of them in the same way. It has become clear by what we mentioned of the state of your saying: "Dirhaman min 'ishrina dirhaman" (A dirham out of twenty dirhams) that every specificator (*Mumayyiz*) in weight, area, and volume, its state is the state of this specificator in the counted, so know it. Not everything that conveys Multiplicity conveys Encompassing, and the clarification of every position that our speech covered has passed, so know it.
What is intended as the genus has come added (Mudaf) in their speech. From that is what came in the Hadith: "And Iraq was prevented its Dirhams and Qafiz," meaning its output and crops. Allah Mighty and Majestic said: (And if you count the favor (*ni'mah*) of Allah, you cannot calculate it). It was narrated from Ibn Abbas, may Allah have mercy on him, that he read: (And His angels (*Mala'ikatihu*)), for he said: His writing (*Kitabuhu*) is more than His scribes (*Kutubihi*).
As for what conveys Multiplicity, while its wording is singular, which are nouns formulated for the plural, I divided it into two parts when detailing the summary that started this speech. Know that these nouns, despite their difference, are not devoid of three states: Either the noun is coined for the few specifically, and the few is intended as the lowest number, which is from three to ten, like *Al-Nafar*, *Al-Raht*, and *Al-Dhawd*. Or a specific number is intended by it, like their saying: *Sirmah*, *Hajmah*, *Hunaydah*, and *Arj*. Or Multiplication is intended by it, that is: like *Qawm* (people), *Nisa'* (women), *Kalib* (dogs), and what runs their course. Each of these types, its ruling is to convey what it was coined for. So we say: If the speaker says: "I passed by a *Nafar*," or "I saw a *Raht*," or "I crossed over a *Dhawd*," then every number from three to ten is related by the relation of its companion in that the noun was coined for it, and that it conveys it if it conveys it in reality. Whenever what specifies it to some of what it was coined for is conjoined with it, it is conveying that in reality. If it is released absolutely, the first of these numbers is certain, and the rest reaches it by indication. We only said this because the word was coined for minimization. Since it was formulated for minimization and it has a known end in what it covers, just as it has a known beginning, judgment was made on the certain part of it which is the first, excluding the middle and the last, because all did not exit from what the word was coined for of minimization. The first was certain, and what is other than it is not certain, and taking the certain is more appropriate. The way of this is not the way of the noun coined for different things, so it is not diverted to one of them except by indication. Do you not see that it is not a condition of what several meanings share that it is not coined for one of them unless it has been coined for the rest, whether it happened for them by one coiner or two coiners. And indeed among the conditions of this is covering every one of the numbers it is suitable for after convention on one of them by it, due to their sharing in what it was coined for that one. This is the way of these and their likes.
As for if he says: "I passed by a *Hunaydah*," and what runs its course, its benefit is what it was coined for of number, because *Hunaydah* is a name for a hundred and what approaches it, and *Al-Arj* is a name for five hundred and six hundred up to a thousand. Likewise what runs its course of what is restricted to a number, or a number and what approximates it, and this matter is clear.
As for *Al-Jamil*, *Al-Baqir*, *Al-Da'in*, and *Al-Kalib*, its benefit is Multiplicity, because these nouns were coined for Multiplication, so know it. Just as they have no amount they end at, they have no beginning either. But they cover what is many and are not specific to a number, even if many, except by indication.
As for what conveys Multiplicity and its wording is the wording of the Plural, it has rulings, and we will clarify the saying in it with what is present.
Know that Plural is of two types: Sound Plural (*Jam' Salamah*) and Broken Plural (*Jam' Taksir*). Sound Plural is wherein the wording of the singular remains sound. It has two structures: One is what is with Waw and Nun or Ya and Nun, and the second: is with Alif and Ta. Sibawayh said: And this, its wording is the plural with Alif and Ta and Waw and Nun for tripling the lowest number up to ten-ing it, which is the singular. Just as Alif and Nun became for its dualization, and its dual is less than its tripled. Do you not see that the genitive of Ta and its accusative are the same, and the genitive of the two and the three who are on dualization and their accusative are the same. So this brings closer that Alif and Ta and Waw and Nun are for the lowest because it agreed with the dual. End of the quote from him.

Know that what we narrated of his speech contains an inference to two things of his doctrine:
First: That the first of plural is at three. Do you not see he said: Tripling is the lowest number, meaning tripling of numbers when he judged upon Waw and Nun, and Alif and Ta.
Second: That he stated clearly that Alif and Ta, and Waw and Nun are for the lowest of numbers, because it agreed with the dual. He means by agreement that the dual in the position of accusative and genitive [is with Ya], just as the sound plural is in the position of accusative and genitive with Ya. And just as the plural with Alif and Ta is in the position of accusative and genitive with Kasra, and Kasra is the sister of Ya. Since these structures agreed in what we mentioned, and the sound plural was on the limit of dualization in the soundness of the singular's wording in it, it became just as it ascended from singular to dualization in benefit, it ascended from dualization to three in benefit. Then its ruling became the ruling of three in that it is from the lowest number related to it by the relation of three, so it became suitable for all. So you say: His doctrine implies that the plural with Waw and Nun, and Alif and Ta is primarily in what the lowest number conveys, which is from three to ten, and is suitable for the many since this structure was not taken by the plural secondly. We do not mean by our saying: "It is suitable for it" that if used for the many it would be metaphorical in it, but we mean that primarily it is for the lowest number, then it is suitable for the many also by coinage. Whenever evidence indicates that it is for the many, it is diverted to it. We do not say: It is a metaphor in it. What made the ruling of priority for the lowest number is what Sibawayh mentioned of its being built upon dualization and coming on its limit, and its agreement with it in what he mentioned. What allowed it to be for the many, and indicated it, is that this structure, I mean the sound plural, was not taken by the plural a structure as the structures formulated for the lowest number were taken, which are four: *Af'al*, *Af'ilah*, *Af'ul*, and *Fi'lah*, and broken as singulars are broken due to their suitability to them in conveying the few. Do you not see their saying: *Akru'* and *Akari'*, and *Abyat* and *Abayit*, and that they do not do that with the sound plural. What establishes what we mentioned and supports it is that the sound plural, if diminished (*sughghira*), is diminished on its wording. So we say in *Muslimin*: *Musaylimun*, and in *Ja'farin*: *Ju'ayfirun*, and in *Muslimat*: *Musaylimat*. Just as what was coined for the lowest number is diminished on its wording, which are these four structures. They were only diminished on their wordings because when they conveyed the few, they resembled the singular in its conveying of the lowest number on their wordings. The structures conveying Multiplicity, if diminished, are returned to their lowest number if they have a lowest number. If they do not have a lowest number, they are returned to their singular, so it is diminished and the plural sign is attached to it. If the matter is so, it becomes clear that the ruling of *Muslimat* and *Muslimun* in that priority belongs to the lowest number, and the ruling of these four structures is the same. Even if these structures, if used for the many, would be by way of metaphor because just as they borrow words, they borrow structures also. The sound plural, even if priority belongs to the lowest number, is suitable for the many also, conveying it in reality if an indication is conjoined with it. This is the ruling of sound plural.
If it is said: If the sound plural, even if priority belongs to the lowest number, has been coined for the many also, and ends up with it if evidence indicates it, and that is making the priority overcome it, why was it treated in diminution on the way of what was coined for the lowest number, which is that it is diminished on its wording? It is said to him: The plural of multitude, whenever it does not have a lowest number, is returned to its singular. If returned to its singular, it is like the sound plural if diminished. Do you not see that *Masajid*, if you diminish it, you say in its diminution *Musayjidat*, so it is on the limit of *Musaylimat* if you diminish *Muslimat*. If it is so, then it is as if in diminishing it on its wording they combined the two rulings for it: the ruling of the lowest number which is diminished on its wording, and the ruling of the plural of multitude if it does not have a lowest number so it is returned to its singular, since it was coined for both, I mean for the few and the many. Even if when isolated, priority belongs to the few due to the evidence that indicated. It has been narrated that Hassan ibn Thabit, when he recited to Al-Nabigha his poem in which is:
*We have the white bowls (*Al-Jafnat*) shining in the forenoon ... and our swords drip blood from bravery.*
He criticized his saying *Al-Jafnat*, and said to him: Why did you reduce your bowls? This supports what we mentioned, so understand.
As for the second part, which is the Broken Plural, it has two structures: One for the few, and its mention has preceded. And the second for the many. It happens in most cases that a thing obtains both structures. It also happens that it is restricted to one of them, then used, if it is for the few, in the many also, and if it is for the many, in the few also.

Since number is of two types: few number and many number, the noun of number from three to ten was specified to be built on the structure of the few and added to it, excluding the structure of the many, so that they do not exit from similarity to contrast. So it was said: *Burd* and *Burdan*, and *Thalathatu Abrad* (Three garments); *Fals* and *Falsan*, and *Thalathatu Aflus* (Three fils); *Jabal* and *Jabalan*, and *Thalathatu Ajbal* (Three mountains); *Ghulam* and *Ghulaman*, and *Thalathatu Ghilmah* (Three boys); *Ghurab* and *Ghuraban*, and *Thalathatu Aghribah* (Three crows). The use of the structure of the many is not preferred in what has a structure of the few if they want to clarify the few number, except rarely. The structures of the many are more than counting can cover except after effort, then it is not secure that much of it will also fall out, so I did not seek to restrict them.
Know that the structures which convey Multiplicity, like *Al-Fujjar*, *Al-Fussaq*, *Al-Zunah*, *Al-Ghuzah*, *Al-Buyut*, *Al-Masajid*, *Al-Ghuraf*, *Al-Shuraf*, *Al-Ghilman*, *Al-Sudan*, *Al-Bidan*, and what ran their course, whenever nothing conjoins with them specifying them with a specific number, their ruling is the ruling of generic nouns. Except that generic nouns ascend from the One, and these structures ascend from the Three. Their agreement is that each of them was coined to cover that which it conveys whatever amount it reaches. Whenever nothing conjoins with it specifying it, it must be conveying Multiplicity. Everything inferred in generic nouns can be inferred in these structures that they were coined for Multiplicity and Inclusion.
We also say: The sound plural, whenever something conjoins with it taking it out of what is more primary to it of conveying the few, is attached to this also, because even if priority belongs to it conveying the few, it covers the many also by coinage, and the indication for this has passed. If it is so, His Almighty's saying: (And they, in the chambers (*Al-Ghurufat*), are safe) [Quran 34:37], with what conjoined to it of what we alerted to that He intends the lowest number [or rather, multitude?], attached in its conveying Multiplicity to the generic noun, and to what was coined for the many and specified by it. Likewise His Almighty's saying: (Indeed, the Muslim men and Muslim women) and all that runs its course.
If it is said: Why did you claim that the few number must be clarified by the structure of the few plural and added to it? Why wasn't it added to the structure of the many just as the part is added to the whole? I say: It was only added to the structure of the few due to the fewness of the counted number. If it were added to the structure of the many, it would not be good due to the fall of agreement and similarity between them, and the entry of distance and contrast in their definition. Do you not see that if you said: "Khamsatu Jimal" (Five camels [many plural]) or "Sab'atu Bighal" (Seven mules [many plural]), you would be minimizing by your saying: "Khamsatu" and "Sab'atu", and maximizing by your saying: "Jimal" and "Bighal", and between them is a contradiction that is not hidden. If you said: "Khamsatu Ajmal" and "Sab'atu Abghul", the number and its clarifier would be similar, and cooperate in conveying that it is of paucity, and each of the annexed and annexed-to would indicate the state of its companion.
If it is said: Allah Almighty has said: (And the divorced women shall wait concerning themselves for three *Quru'*) [Quran 2:228], so He turned away from *Aqra'* which is for the lowest number to *Quru'* which is the many, and you claimed that does not occur nor is it good. The answer: *Aqra'* was not seen by Sibawayh, and its singular is *Qar'* with open Qaf.
