The analogy of *Fa'l* is to be on *Af'ul*, even if we affirmed it because of what appeared in the report of his saying: "Ayyam Aqra'", but it is among what deviated from analogy, even if it appeared in usage like *Istahwadha*. Just as analogy on *Istahwadha* is not permissible, likewise analogy on *Thalathatu Quru'* is not permissible. Our companions returned this interpretation to what it is upon, and looked and said: Its estimation is three *Aqra'* from the *Quru'*. Another way: It is that since the structure of the many is more frequent in usage and more famous than the structure of the few, evidenced by the fact that the like of Sibawayh did not make in the plural of *Qar'* other than *Quru'*, it became in the status of what no structure other than the many came in. So just as it is said: "Thalathatu Rijal" and "Arba'atu Masajid", it is said: "Thalathatu Quru'" since *Aqra'* is in the status of what did not come due to its scarcity.
What reveals the ugliness of adding the few to the many and its exit from suitability to contradiction is that they did not diminish the structures of Multiplicity on their wordings since diminution is minimization. These structures are for Multiplication. So just as they rejected that due to the cessation of similarity from them and the occurrence of contrast in them, likewise we must reject what we denied, and this is clear. Whoever contemplates these places, their purposes in these structures become clear to him, and the correctness of what we clarified in all of them, Allah willing.

Know that what conveys Inclusion in Negation specifically and is not used in Affirmation is only in several chapters of it. It seems they were specified by it due to the frequency of affliction with them as they used to waste what they wasted according to the need for it. It was not used in Affirmation because what conveys Inclusion like it on its limit is not valid in Affirmation, since narration (*Hikayah*) here did not occur with it, and we have clarified that.
Among them is what is spoken in negating people, like: "Ma biha du'wiyy" (There is no one in it), and "Ma biha tamur", and "Ma biha shafr". Among them is what is in negating wealth, like: "Ma lahu samm wa la hamm", and "Ma lahu qudha'milah". Among them is what food is negated by, like: "Ma dhaqtu 'alusan". Among them is what sleep is negated by, like: "Ma dhaqtu ghimadan wa la huthathan". Among them is what pains are negated by, like: "Ma bihi wadhiyah". Among them is what jewelry is negated by, like: "Ma 'alayha khadad". These, despite their difference, and their likes, nothing of them is used in Affirmation. They convey the negation of the little of what they were coined for and the much of it. So understand that and know it, Allah willing.

Selected Poems
Muhammad ibn Yazid ibn Maslamah
*O my two companions, stop for me a little while ... so we may stop by the palace of Abd al-Qadir.*
*Turn with me, to Allah is the goodness of your father ... healing hearts from the hidden passion.*
*As for dismounting, I despair that you will do it ... do not be stingy with me regarding the standing of a looker.*
*Stop the blame, and it is not a time for blame ... this is a time of mutual support and help.*
*Or cut the rope of affection between us ... this road is for one going to Najd or Tihama (Gha'ir).*
*So they stopped, separated in their desires ... among my helpers with loyalty and a betrayer.*
*So this one was led by me and saw his guidance ... and that one turned aside to the unjust road.*
*When the valley of Al-Nuwayrah appeared before us ... we traversed the mountain passes with a strong, lean she-camel.*
*He raised his voice (*'aqirah*) singing, so it thrilled me ... a return like the rolling of scattered pearls.*
*The monks of Midian, if they saw you, would have come down ... and the white-footed mountain goats from the peaks of the mountains, the large males.*
*So the eye of the youth filled with tears, so I rebuked him ... Restrain your tears! So he refrained for the rebuker.*
*Until when the darkness lowered its curtains ... and Capella (Al-Ayyuq) declined, what a declining.*
*And the hands of the stars descended and set ... and setting ones of them were in front of setting ones.*
*We turned to the palace of Banu Shu'ayb after ... the mix [of people] became bored and every night-companion slept.*
*And slumber threw [itself] on the two guards so they nodded ... after they remained for a night, staying awake.*
*My cousin said: What do you see? I said: Be slow ... The ignorant of a plan is not like the expert.*
*Hobble a young she-camel aside, do not pasture her ... and tie the shank of her foreleg to the other.*
*As for the steed, he did not leave his place ... by advancing from him nor by delaying.*
*I sought refuge for him, while I visit my beloveds ... [from] his negligence, and likewise every risk-taker.*
*And when his saddle-bow gathered with his rein ... the bit chewed until the return of the visitor.*
*And I knew that the matter has no cure ... except the bold, it is not a time for boldening [others].*
*So I went out preceding my companion, wearing ... the suspenders of the usurped [sword], the sharp, the cutter.*
*I push the sleepers right and left ... and the people are set up on my rights and my lefts.*
*Nothing startled me except the wine of a servant girl ... at the wall, throwing scattered pebbles.*
*Commanded, she did not exceed what she was commanded ... giving drink to a commanded one there and a commander.*
*And they noticed, so they looked out at me ... from between one lowering the veil and one bare-headed.*
*They looked down, the looking of gazelles that watched ... a lightning that flashed in a raining cloud.*
*In polished wraps that were joined ... and waist-wrappers they tied with waist-wrappers.*
*Nine gathered for a tenth helping him up ... O Lord, save his person from a tenth.*
*So they lowered ropes to me, weak ... if they broke, I would find no excuser for me.*
*So I tied them to the wrist of a brilliant, noble one ... proceeding on terrors, not consulting.*
*And their exhaustion was whispers that cut ... my heart for fear of a sound from a walker.*
*So I stretched the shoulder of my companion and he rose with me ... and they pulled with the ropes after consultation.*
*So they were patient for the matter they attempted ... until they succeeded and spent the night not patient [in joy].*
*So if I entered the palace the entry of a bold attacker ... I was not, within the curtain of the chambers, a libertine.*
*As for the waist-wrapper and its domain, it is forbidden ... and for me is the sash and what was free of rain (upper body).*
*And smelling and kissing were made lawful ... and touching, except for a shaking sand dune.*

*That is only because I am noble ... free of origin, I spent the night among free women.*
*Between Al-Rabab and peers of hers ... white, whom bliss nourished, beautiful.*
*So the long night became short, and it was not ... before that, for me, short.*
*Its sky poured happiness upon us ... and its stars ran with the happiest omen.*
*When the light of morning appeared announcing ... the first of it, the rears of darkness with ends.*
*She said, while the tear of the eye washed her kohl ... My soul be the ransom! The morning has approached, so hasten.*
*So I went out among five buxom girls who visited her ... at the time of Isha, the exit of the arrow of the gambler.*
*We do not pass by a guard except he turned ... from us the fierceness of his squinting glance.*
*So they went with me, their hearts trembling ... beating between a gut and throats.*
*When they stood at the hill path, there was nothing ... but the farewell of a greeter or a walker.*
*And behold the lands are empty of my companion ... the morning glimpsed him, for light is a helper.*
*His armies defeated the darkness of its gloom ... and the night is defeated without armies.*
*I left him, while his heart was wary of enemies ... in the like of the secondary feathers of the flying eagle.*
*And behold the steed is in a position I secured him ... when the saying of the poet came true in him.*
*He became bored of chewing the bit as if he was ... safe in the desert of Al-Ma'a then Quraqir.*
*I brought him near then mounted his back ... and he swooped down falling like the breaking eagle.*

Abd al-Qadir contradicted him and said:
*O palace of Maslamah which gifted us ... the houris of gazelles, may you be watered by the pouring of the rainer.*
*I used to receive, so I became denying ... about the beauty of your people in the past time.*
*Until I saw the sun, its light shone ... in a polished sheet and Quraqir.*
*And I saw the gazelles of the chambers unveiled ... smiling revealing [teeth] like the blooming daisy.*
*In a gathering whose sky of joy poured ... pearls falling from a skilled artist.*
*So I picked from the fruit of ardor and passion ... and struck from the leaves of lush bliss.*
*And they remained shooting hearts with arrows ... I poisoned their broadheads with a languid glance.*
*And they hit a killing spot in me, so they killed me ... O who has seen a lion killed by young gazelles.*
*Leave this, but did you hear her saying ... while the eye helps her with raining tears.*
*In negligence of her family towards her young girl ... Woe to me tomorrow if Abd al-Qadir travels.*

Amr ibn Qa'as al-Muradi said:
*O house in the high ground, a house ... and were it not for the love of your people, I would not have come.*
*O house, your people threatened me ... as if I committed all their sins.*
*The blamers came early and I became desperate ... and am I immortal if I sobered up?*
*If fresh meat missed me ... I struck the foreleg of my young camel and roasted.*
*And I was, if I saw a sick skin [of wine] ... being wailed over its funeral, I wept.*
*I comb my hair and drag my tail ... and a reddish-brown horizon carries my clothes.*
*I walk in the dwellings of Banu Ghatif ... if injustice burdens me, I refuse.*
*And a black-eyed one of the eye-sockets, the friend of Sakhr ... watching me with looking, I have been shot.*
*And a branch, soft, fresh, moist ... I bent towards me from it and picked.*
*And water not from a flowing spring ... nor water of the sky did I drink.*
*And Tamur (wine/blood?) I spilled and it was not wine ... and a grain not grinding I rubbed.*
*And meat people did not taste before me ... I ate in seclusion and selected.*
*And a kneeling camel I stirred with a Mashrafi sword ... if it slipped from a hock, I shot.*
*And a returning [group] together while the arrival was separate ... on their backs in the afternoons I drove.*
*And a running [mare] having a long tail ... I returned with a morsel of what I desired.*
*And a fire I kindled without a fire-stick ... I stirred its hellfire then warmed myself.*
*I establish my falsehood so it becomes truth ... and a truth without doubt I twisted.*
*I did not turn my back on the closest ones, for I ... the most noble ones grew me and I did not grow [alone].*
*Whenever my term comes to me, it finds me ... satiated with pleasure and healed.*

Umar ibn Hizam al-Udhri said:
*O two crows of the dung of the house, clarify ... is it the separation from Asma' you are whispering?*
*If what you say is true, then rise ... with my body to your nests and eat me.*
*And let not people know what my death was ... nor let birds eat what you leave.*

*For if you uncover the shirt from me, you will see ... in me the sickness from Afra', what you leave.*
*Then you will find little meat and bones ... worn out, and a heart constantly palpitating.*
*For Afra' is the purest of people to me in affection ... and Afra' is the turning away, slackening one from me.*
*Upon my liver from the love of Afra' is a heat ... and my eyes from passion for her are flowing.*
*Shedding and dripping and pouring and continuous rain ... and spilling and moistening, and they race each other.*
*As if they are two tears in an old waterskin ... blocked at times and bursting at times.*
*So I swear, were it not for the love of Afra', there would not meet ... upon me the two flaps of your worn-out tent.*
*Nor would my she-camel carry [me] in a dusty obliterated [path] ... nor would my eyes be entrusted with shedding.*
*So woe to me over Afra', a woe as if it is ... upon the chest and bowels the edge of a spearhead.*
*O Afra', how many a death you have caused me to die ... and sadness that urged the eye to shedding.*
*Afra' has left my heart as if it is ... the wing of an eagle, constantly flying.*
*Oh, would that we live together, and would that we ... when we die, a shroud gathers us.*
*And would that we, O Afra', without doubt ... were two camels grazing the wasteland, united.*
*The desire of my she-camel is behind me and my desire is ahead ... and I and she are different.*
*For if you carry my longing and your longing, you will limp ... and I do not have for the heavy load two hands.*
*Oh, would that my uncle, the day he separated between us ... was given poison mixed with Yemeni Shath (plant).*
*So O uncle, may no moisture wet you from a relative ... and may the feet slip under you.*
*And that is because of what you separated between me and her ... while we are two cousins united.*
*Afra' tasks me with sixty young camels ... and I do not have, O Afra', other than eight.*
*Afra' tasks me with what I do not have ... nor do the anchored mountains have two hands for.*
*So by Allah, I did not tell your secret to a companion ... advising, nor did the two lips utter it.*
*Except that I said one day to my companion ... in the forenoon while our two young camels were trotting with us.*
*Oh, how beloved from the love of Afra' is a meeting place ... of ostriches and Na'am where they meet.*
*I made for the diviner of Yamama his judgment ... and the diviner of Najd if they cure me.*
*So they said: Yes, we cure from every disease ... and they stood with the visitors racing.*
*And they left no incantation they knew ... nor a solace except they treated me with it.*
*Then they said: May Allah cure you, by Allah we do not have ... for what the ribs contain of you two hands.*
*As if a sandgrouse was hung by its wing ... upon my liver from the intensity of palpitation.*

Hassan ibn Thabit said:
*Did you ask the trace of the house or did you not ask ... between Al-Jawabi then Al-Badi' then Hawmal.*
*Then Al-Marj, the meadow of Al-Suffarayn, then Jasim ... then dwellings of Tibna, effaced, not inhabited.*
*A house of a people I used to see once ... above the mighty ones, their might not moved.*
*To Allah belongs the goodness of a group I drank with ... one day at Jilliq in the first time.*
*The children of Jafnah around the grave of their father ... the grave of Ibn Mariyah the generous, the preferred.*
*They give drink to whoever comes to Al-Baris, upon them ... Barada cloth, clapping with the pure nectar.*
*They are given the Theriac of wine to drink, and their ... slave-girls did not used to run to peel the colocynth.*
*They are visited until their dogs do not growl ... they do not ask about the approaching person.*
*White of faces, noble are their lineages ... High of noses, from the first style.*
*So I stayed long days among them ... then I remembered as if I did not do.*
*Either you see my head, its color changed ... with grayness and became like the dried Thagham grass.*
*For the threatening one sees me as if I am ... in the palace of Dumah or the middle of the temple.*
*And I have drunk wine in its shop ... reddish-white, clear like the taste of pepper.*
*Seeking to serve me with its cup is one wearing earrings ... so he gives me a second drink from it even if I did not take the first.*
*Indeed the one you handed me and I returned ... She was killed (diluted), you killed, so bring it unkilled.*
*Both are the milk of juice, so give me ... in a glass, the looser of them for the joint.*
*In a glass, she danced with what is in her belly ... the dance of the young she-camel with a hasty rider.*
*My lineage is original among the nobles, and my manger ... its marks brand the side of the one warming himself.*
*And a youth who loves glory makes his wealth ... protection for his honor, even if not asked.*

*And the tribe turbans us with its affair [makes us leaders] ... and our sayer hits the middle of the joint.*
*So our riding camels visit the doors of kings ... and when we are made judges in the tribe we are just.*

Al-Harithi said:
*Visit Zaynab, a coming early has passed from you ... and tomorrow a journey will be serious with whom you love.*
*How is the meeting when the one we love meeting ... is going to Najd early and you are going to the lowlands (Ghawr)?*
*How many a burning [tear] settled on me and a sigh ... when it was said: The one you love will travel tomorrow.*
*Watering [of rain] for the one I bid farewell, for he is ... from what he hides of separation, collapsing.*
*Indeed I, on the morning of their separation, since I did not die ... of grief on the morning of their separation, am patient.*
*O Marabid, the day of your separation has been decreed ... so is the meeting for a lover destined?*
*She said, and her tear rose from her eye ... and a passion which bowels and conscience boil with.*
*Indeed He who decreed separation upon the one ... whom souls love, is Capable of the meeting.*
*The lovers may become distant, then repeat them ... times, and matters succeed matters.*
*So I was silent out of sorrow and said: Perhaps ... and I knew that her speech was consoling.*
*What would it harm your family if a lover is given ... or his ear is facilitated so he visits?*
*They envy the little upon him from you, and with Him ... if he obtained the little from you, it is much.*
*Nothing is easier than the visit of a night-comer ... who loves meeting you, and the meeting is easy.*
*My soul is attached to your memory, and the bowels ... are anxious for you, when you are mentioned, they fly.*
*Do not deny my anxiety for you and my childish passion ... Indeed the lover is excused in what he did.*
*If you wished, the lover would be revived by a visit ... an eye would live for him, happy with it.*
*And I have extended my hand for the giving of your gift ... Indeed the lover is poor towards the beloved.*
*And I remembered you while Hellfire is defined ... with passion for your face, and the lover remembers well.*
*Were it not for shame and that it be said: He complained of passion ... to one who grants protection by your passion.*
*But I covered you lest our mention be raised ... and I covered myself, and the noble is covering.*
*The blamers said: You have become too old for childish passion ... The blamers spoke truth, indeed I am old.*
*If gray hair touches [me], my side locks have branched ... then love is the prime of youth, fresh.*
*I wear it out and aging follows it with newness ... Indeed passion is long-lived, abundant.*

Malik ibn al-Rayb said mentioning his alienation and illness and eulogizing himself:
*O would that I knew, will I spend a night ... beside the Ghadha trees, driving the swift young camels?*
*So would that the Ghadha, the riders did not cross its width ... and would that the Ghadha walked with the riders for nights.*
*I say to Zayd while he has passion like me ... I see the opinion from us is that we visit Al-Ma'awiya.*
*And how is a visit to the Ma'awi after ... we found a doctor other than that treating?*
*So he spent the night distracting me with who dwells in the Ghadha ... even if it was nothing, O Zayd, but wishes.*
*I see myself from the love of the Ghadha joining it ... so my family holds it and its shepherd my wealth.*
*Indeed there was among the people of the Ghadha, if the Ghadha was near ... a visiting place, but the Ghadha is not near.*
*My two friends from the high Rabi'ah of Mazin ... at Samnan, will what sufficed me suffice you two?*
*I thought the Ghadha heals the passion, but I did not find ... the scent of the Ghadha healing the passion, my passion.*
*And I had thought the Jinn had died and ended ... so I spent nights away from the humming of women.*
*So when we descended the land of Amr from the Ghadha ... the soft grounds of the hills and the rights, the hidden places.*
*Then in the Ghadha, O watering of who dwells in the Ghadha ... is the likeness of Sawda' whom I am not forgetting.*
*Did you not see me, I sold error for guidance ... and became in the army of Ibn Affan, a raider.*
*And I became in the land of the non-Arabs after ... I saw myself far from the land of the non-Arabs.*
*Passion called me from the people of Awd, and my company ... was at Dhu al-Tabasayn, so I turned behind me.*
*I answered passion when it called me with a tear ... I veiled myself with my cloak from it lest I be blamed.*
*I say while the villages of the Kurds came between us ... May Allah reward Amr the best of what he was rewarding.*
*If Allah returns me from the raid, I do not see ... even if my wealth is little, seeking what is behind me.*
*By my life, if Khurasan assassinated my head ... Indeed I was far from the two gates of Khurasan.*
*So to Allah is my deed the day I leave obediently ... my sons at the top of Al-Raqmatayn and my wealth.*
*And the deed of the gazelles passing from right to left in the evening ... informing that I am perishing before me.*

*And the deed of my two elders who both ... are compassionate to me, advising, if they forbade me.*
*And the deed of the men witnessing my impulsive behavior ... with my command that they do not shorten my bonds.*
*And the deed of passion from where his companions call ... and a deed for my needs and the deed of my ending.*
*I remembered who would weep for me, but I did not find ... other than the sword and the Rudayni spear weeping.*
*And a blond [horse], clipped [mane/tail], dragging his rein ... to the water, Time did not leave a waterer for him.*
*A people lead him while his master has died ... he is sold for a loss after he was expensive.*
*But at the sides of Al-Sumaynah are women ... it is hard upon them this evening what is with me.*
*My old woman and my two daughters who are for me ... and a daughter of Ayyub making the weeping women weep.*
*Thrown down on the hands of men in a wasteland ... they straighten my cheek where my decree was destined.*
*And when my death appeared at Merv ... and my body became thin by it and my death time came.*
*I say to my companions: Watch me for I ... it pleases my eye that Canopus appeared to me.*
*So O my two companions of my saddle, death has approached, so descend ... at a hill, for I am staying for nights.*
*Stay upon me today or part of a night ... and do not rush me, my hater has become clear.*
*And stand when my soul is pulled out and prepare ... for me the Sidr and the shrouds at my annihilation.*
*And draw with the tips of the spears my lying place ... and return upon my eyes the excess of my cloak.*
*And do not envy me, may Allah bless you both ... of the land of width, that you widen for me.*
*Take me and drag me by my garment to you ... for I was before today difficult of my leadership.*
*And I was a turner [of horses] when the horses retreated ... fast in the battle to what called me.*
*And I was praised by the possessor of provision and hospitality ... heavy upon the enemies, my tongue is sharp.*
*And I was very patient against the peer in the battle ... and regarding insulting the son of the uncle and the neighbor, weak.*
*So at times you see me in shades and bliss ... and a day you see me while the noble horses are my mounts.*
*And a day you see me in a round mill [battle] ... the tips of spears tearing my clothes.*
*And stand at the well of Al-Sumaynah, make hear ... at it the noble and the white beautiful gazing women.*
*That you two left me in a wasteland ... the wind heaps upon me in it the dust.*
*And do not forget my covenant, my two friends, after ... my joints are cut and my bones decay.*
*And the grieving ones will not lack a sorrow that strikes them ... and the clients will not lack inheritance from me.*
*They say: Do not be far, while they are burying me ... and where is the place of distance except my place?*
*The morning of tomorrow, O sorrow of my soul for tomorrow ... when they depart at night from me and I become staying.*
*And my wealth of new and old becomes ... for others, and the wealth was yesterday my wealth.*
*I hope for a fresh youth and health ... and how is the hope of the old man for what he is not meeting?*

'Ayniyyah of Laqit ibn Ya'mar al-Iyadi:
*O abode of Amrah, from her occupier the sandy ground ... stirred for me worry and sorrows and pain.*
*A tender girl enslaved my heart at Dhat al-Jaz' ... she passed wanting at Dhat al-'Adhbah the church.*
*With two eyes of a fawn, dark-lipped, obedient to her ... is the plant of the meadows, she drives in its middle a step.*
*And a white [tooth], cool of canines, possessing serration ... like the daisy when its blossom shines.*
*She dragged for what is between us the rope of the stubborn ones, so no ... clear despair do I see from her nor hope.*
*So I do not cease, despite distance, being kept awake by ... a phantom intending my saddle wherever it was placed.*
*Indeed, by my eye when their loads aimed at ... the belly of Al-Salutah, they do not look at who followed.*
*Sometimes I see them and sometimes I do not distinguish them ... when a litter lowered the hour it shone.*
*Nay, O rider driving with haste ... towards Al-Jazirah seeking pasture and resort.*
*Convey to Iyad and call out among their nobles ... Indeed I see the opinion, if I am not disobeyed, has become clear.*
*O sorrow of my soul if your affairs were ... scattered, and the affair of the people was judged so it united.*
*Do you not fear a people, may you have no father ... who entered evening towards you like locusts, rushing?*
*Sons of a people who sheltered you upon rage ... they do not feel whether it harmed Allah or benefited.*
*The free men of Persia, sons of the kings, they have ... from the armies, armies that despise the forts.*

*So they are rushing towards you, between one picking ... thorns and another gathering the bitter tree and the acacia.*
*If their gathering aimed with its crash at ... the high peaks of Thahlan, it would have split.*
*Every day they sharpen the spears for you ... they do not sleep when the heedless sleeps.*
*Narrow are their eyes as if their glance ... is the burning of fire, you see from it the brightness cut.*
*Plowing does not distract them, rather they do not see for themselves ... without your territory any quenching or satiety.*
*While you plow the land broadwise ... in every worked place seeking a planting ground.*
*And you join the barren of the camels at times ... and you breed at Dhat al-Qal'ah the young camels.*
*And you wear the clothes of security openly ... not fearing, while this lion has gathered.*
*You are two teams: this one, does not stand for him ... the crushing of lions, and this one is perishing, stunned.*
*And there has overshadowed you from the direction of your frontier ... a dark terror covering you as pieces.*
*Why do I see you asleep in luxury ... while you see the meteor of war has shone?*
*So heal my burning thirst with an opinion from you, good ... my heart will become for it quenched, satisfied.*
*And do not be like one who spent the night shrinking ... when it was said to him: Dispel a grief, he shrank.*
*Stand a standing on the tips of your feet ... then fear, the matter may be attained by one who feared.*
*Preserve your horses and polish your swords ... and renew for the bows the Nab' wood and the string.*
*And buy your old wealth with the protection of your selves ... and the protection of your women, do not perish in panic.*
*And let not some of you leave others to a calamity ... as you left at the top of Bisha, Al-Nakha'.*
*Kindle the eyes behind the grazing herd and guard ... until you see the horses from their running in pain.*
*For if you are overcome despite stinginess with your abode ... you have met with the command of a prudent one, a fright.*
*Let not camels distract you, they are not your camels ... Indeed the enemy has snatched a bone [great thing] from you.*
*Far it is! No wealth of crops or camels ... is hoped for your remaining ones if your nose is cut.*
*Do not bear fruit to the wealth for the enemies, for they ... if they win, they will contain you and the old wealth together.*
*By Allah, wealth has not ceased, since eternity ... for its people, if they are hit once, to be followers.*
*O people, indeed you have from the inheritance of your first ... a glory I have feared that it perishes and is cut off.*
*And the glory of your first does not return to you ... if its last is lost or humiliated and lowered.*
*And let not world nor greed deceive you ... that you revive with resolve that greed.*
*O people, your territory (*baydatakum*), do not be bereft of it ... Indeed I fear for it the Azlam (lion/time) the Jada' (mutilated/calamity).*
*O people, do not feel safe, if you are jealous ... for your women, from Chosroes and what he gathered.*
*It is the evacuation whose humiliation remains ... whether your bird flies one day or falls.*
*It is the annihilation that uproots your origin ... so tuck up and prepare for wars together.*
*And entrust your affair, to Allah your goodness ... to one wide of arm, undertaking the matter of war.*
*Not luxurious if the ease of life helped him ... nor if a disliked thing bit him, he humbled.*
*He does not taste sleep except the amount that wakes him ... a worry whose harm almost breaks the rib.*
*Sleepless, your affairs concern him ... he intends from them to the enemies an observation point.*
*He did not cease bringing the milk of time, its halves ... being a follower one day and followed.*
*And not distracting him is wealth he invests ... from you, nor a child seeking elevation for him.*
*Until his twist continued on toughness ... firm of age, neither wheat nor teat.*
*Like Malik ibn Qanan or like his companion ... Zayd al-Qana the day he met the two Hariths together.*
*When a faulter faulted him one day and said to him ... Soften for yourself before the day a lying place.*
*So he assaulted him and they found him a brother of repeated drinks ... in war, capturing the lion and the beast.*
*Seeking help, challenging all people ... if he fought people for their lineages, he would knock.*
*This is my letter to you and the warner for you ... So who saw like this an opinion and who heard?*
*I have spent my advice to you without deceit ... So wake up, for the best of speech is what benefited.*

And Al-Khansa bint Amr said eulogizing her brother Sakhr
*Is there a mote in your eye, or is there an inflammation in the eye ... No, rather you wept for one whose house became empty.*

*She weeps for Sakhr; she is the tearful one and she wept ... and without him are veils of the soil of the earth.*
*As if my eye, for his memory when it occurred ... is a flood flowing on the two cheeks, pouring.*
*Khunas weeps for Sakhr and she has the right ... Time took him away, indeed Time is a stumbler.*
*In the hollow of a grave, staying, contained him ... in his grave, piled stones and rocks.*
*O Sakhr, arriver at water, the people of the water sources ... warned each other of him; there is no shame in his arrival.*
*The walk of the leopard to a difficult battle ... he has two weapons: fangs and claws.*
*Like the Rudayni [spear], his youth was not soiled ... as if he is, under the fold of the cloak, a bracelet.*
*Frowning of face [at war], his image lights up the night ... his fathers are of the tall in stature, free men.*
*Wide of hands in doing good, possessing a way ... huge of gift, commanding good deeds.*
*Sturdy, imagined [to bring rain/good], giver, superior, easy ... and in wars, if you met, an igniter.*
*Protector of the truth, guide of the way ... pure of nature, benefiting and harming.*
*Protector of the distant, sayer of the rebellious ... slaughterer of the distant [camel], leader of the army.*
*So let a weeping woman weep with bereavement, calling ... on a day of clamor in which there is no secret.*
*Doer of the high [deed], arriver at the overflowing [water] ... growing to glory, journeys concern him.*
*Sweet is his sweetness, decisive is his speech ... sharp is his determination, in the battle a raider.*
*So let a poor one weep for him, whom a time deprived of his wealth ... and misery and poverty allied with him.*
*Or a company whose driver was confused in a dark place ... as if its darkness in the gloom is tar.*
*A female neighbor did not see him walking in her courtyard ... for a suspicion when the neighbor empties his house.*
*Nor does she see him eating what is in the house ... but he is prominent in the morning, a slaughterer.*
*And indeed Sakhr is our master and our chief ... and indeed Sakhr, if we winter, is a slaughterer.*
*And indeed Sakhr, the guides follow him ... as if he is a mountain peak, in its head is a fire.*
*So I said when I saw Time having no ... blamer, diligent, corrupting and weaving.*
*Ibn Nahik announced the death of a brother of trust ... news used to be conjectured about him before.*
*So I spent the night awake watching the star ... until veils came before the setting of the star.*
*So not a mother who lost her calf, circling it ... whom wet nurses helped in yearning.*
*Time took him away from her so she is cutting off [milk] ... she has two yearnings: a soft one and a loud one.*
*She grazes as long as she is heedless, until when she remembers ... it is only coming and going.*
*A day more painful to me than the day Sakhr parted from me ... and for Time there is sweetening and bittering.*
*There must be a death in whose turning is change ... and Time in its turning has states and stages.*

Qays ibn al-Khatim said:
*Do you know a trace like the flow of gilding ... belonging to Amrah, wild, other than the standing place of a rider?*
*Houses of the one who almost, while we were at Mina ... settled with us, were it not for the speed of the riding camels.*
*She appeared to us like the sun under a cloud ... an eyebrow of it appeared and it was stingy with an eyebrow.*
*And I did not see her except three times at Mina ... and my covenant with her was as a virgin having braids.*
*And the like of you I have loved; she is not a daughter-in-law ... nor a neighbor nor the wife of a companion.*
*I called Banu Awf to spare their blood ... so when they refused, I was easy in the war of a gatherer.*
*And I was a man who does not raise war unjustly ... so when they refused, I ignited it on every side.*
*I persisted in repelling war until I saw it ... upon repelling, increasing only in nearness.*
*So since there was no repelling from the end of death ... then welcome to it if it does not cease in the wide spaces.*
*So when I saw war as war, I stripped ... I wore with the two garments the clothes of the warrior.*
*Doubled [armor], its excess covers the fingertips ... as if its nails are the eyes of locusts.*
*Bands came from the two Kahins and Malik ... and Tha'labah of the traces, the clan of Ibn Ghalib.*
*Men who, when called to fright, trot ... to it like the trotting of the difficult camels.*
*When they were frightened, they extended to the fright a shout ... like the wave of the flood, foaming, piled up.*
*You see the pieces of spears falling as if they are ... the measuring of palm branches in the hands of the peelers.*
*We accompanied with it the fortresses around Muzahim ... the helmets of the first of our white [swords/men] are like the star.*

*If you threw a colocynth above our helmets ... it would roll from the one of close alignment.*
*When we fled, the worst of our fleeing was ... the turning away of cheeks and the deviation of shoulders.*
*If our swords fell short, their connection was ... our steps to our enemies by approaching.*
*I fight them on the Day of the Garden bareheaded ... as if my hand with the sword is the kerchief of a player.*
*And on the Day of Bu'ath our swords surrendered us ... to a lineage in the stock of Ghassan, penetrating.*
*They bare white [swords] when we meet our enemy ... and sheathe red [swords] thin of edges.*
*Banu Awf obeyed an emir among us who forbade them ... from peace until it was the first duty.*
*I wondered at Awf when their women say ... and they throw a defense: Would that we did not fight.*
*We accompanied them with a gray [army], its white [swords] shining ... revealing the anklets of the fleeing women.*
*Our swords struck nobles from the bright ones ... and the children of the wood-gathering slaves were left behind.*
*And among us is he who swore thirty nights ... from wine until he visited you with battalions.*
*I was pleased for them that they do not leave its bottom ... to the absent wealth except with a companion.*
*Were it not for the peaks of the fortresses you know ... and leaving the open space, you would have been shared in the buxom girls.*
*So do not prevent from us a place we want ... as a sanctuary for you, except the backs of the drinking places.*
*Why did you not, at the fierce war, have patience ... for our strike, while might is difficult to ride?*
*We made you nurses to the white [swords] until you are ... more humiliated than the lambs among the milkers.*
*When we descended Al-Harith, our emir said ... Wine is forbidden to us as long as we do not fight.*
*So men of might from us permitted it to him ... so they did not leave until it was made lawful for a drinker.*
*Would that Suwayd saw who fell of you ... and who fled when they drive them like imports.*
*So we returned to our sons and women ... and none of those we left at Bu'ath is returning.*
*And I was absent from a day my clan sufficed me ... and the Day of Bu'ath was a day of overcoming.*

And he also said:
*The mixture [of people] returned the camels and departed ... what was upon them if they had stopped?*
*If they stopped an hour, we ask them ... the duration the Salaf (travelers?) sun their camels.*
*Among them is a playful one of the evening, pleasant of ... coquetry, loving to her husband, breach [of promise] grieves her.*
*Among the shapes of women, her creation is ... moderate, neither huge nor slender.*
*She steals the glance while she is playing ... as if a bleeding thinned her face.*
*Allah decreed for her when the Creator created her ... that darkness does not cover her.*
*She sleeps from the greatness of her affair, so when ... she rises slowly, she almost breaks.*
*Wide-eyed, long-necked, light is sought from her ... as if she is the branch of a Ban tree, soft.*
*She walks the walk of the white cow in the soft ... sand to the plain, before it is the cliff.*
*And the speech she spoke is not bad ... and in her mouth it is possessing pleasure, fresh.*
*She saddens it while it is desired, beautiful ... and it, when she speaks, is scattered.*
*As if her upper chest, scattered over it ... lean locusts, their middles are hollow.*
*As if she is a pearl surrounded by the ... diver, the shell clears from her face.*
*And by Allah of the Sacred Mosque and what ... was covered of Yumnah, she has a turning away.*
*Indeed I love you without lie ... the insides and the pericardium have thinned from me.*
*Nay, would that my family and the family of Athlah were in ... a house of a relative where he frequents.*
*Far it is! From his family is at Yathrib ... he has entered evening, and before his family is Saraf.*
*O Lord, do not make distant the dwellings of Banu ... Udhrah where I turned and they turned.*
*Convey to Banu Jahjaba and their people ... Khatmah, that we are disdainful behind them.*
*And that we, before what the enemies impose on them ... of the injustice of a plan, we refrain.*
*Indeed we, even if they advanced what they knew ... our livers dry up behind them.*
*We split with the edge of the broad sword their skulls ... and our splitting their skulls with us is violence.*
*When their foreheads appeared in the morning ... the wombs and the pages yearned for us.*
*So our saying to the advanced ones is: Stop ... from your goal, while wars vary.*
*Follows its traces if it trembled ... hot, fresh blood, its veins dripping.*
*The people said to us: A group that won ... We said: For we are fearful for our people.*
*Indeed we have a possession, and its main part ... between its peaks are gathering places, marching.*
*Defending them is a night-companion, strong ... black of the covering as if it is a mane.*

And Hatim ibn Abdullah al-Ta'i said:
*Do you know ruins and a destroyed trench ... like your writing in a parchment a decorated book?*
*The winds circulated in it after its inhabitant ... months and days and a year and the harvesting time.*
*So they became having changed the appearance of its soil ... and the Anwa' (rains) replaced what was a landmark.*
*And the length of oldness and decay changed it ... so I do not know the ruins except by imagination.*
*Houses of the one who stood showing you, while she has effaced ... and emptied of visitors, a palm and a wrist.*
*Her jewelry swayed on her, possessing joy ... and a flank like the folding of the Sabiriyyah (cloth), slender.*
*And a chest like the silver tray adorned by ... the glow of ruby and beads arranged.*
*Like the ember of Ghadha, the winds of Saba blew on it after a sleep ... of the night, so it smiled.*
*It lights up for us the dull house, its gaps ... when she at night tried to breathe.*
*If she turned on the mattress once ... the whisper of the jewelry hummed a humming.*
*So she departed for intentions of hers and exchanged ... with it a substitute, the birds passed for it most ill-omened.*
*And two blamers woke up after a sleep ... blaming a destroyer, a benefiter, blamed.*
*They blame, when the star set, in error ... a youth who does not see spending in the right as a fine.*
*Nay, do not blame me for what has passed ... Suffice the turns of Time as a judge for the man.*
*So I said when the reproach became long on them ... and they threatened to spend the night and cut off.*
*For you two do not catch up with what passed ... and I am not regretful over what I missed.*
*So your soul, honor it, for if you humiliate it ... upon yourself, you will never find an honorer for it.*
*Humiliate the old wealth in what you love, for it ... if I die, the wealth will be plunder divided.*
*And do not be miserable in it so an heir becomes happy ... with it when you are stuffed in the dusty hollow, darkened.*
*He divides it as spoil and buys honor ... while you have become in a line of the earth greater.*
*Be forbearing from the two ears and keep their affection ... for you are not hitting forbearance until you act forbearing.*
*When you meet the grudges of the clan with deliberation ... and restraining harm, it cuts the disease for you, a cutting.*
*And obstinacy did not send me in my passion ... if I did not find in what is before me an advance.*
*If I wished, I would have rivaled the man of evil as he did not rival ... you, and you would have slapped the mean one, slapped.*
*He saw the night, stars destroyed it leading it ... and the night traveler might hate the stingy blamed one.*
*And I was a man of a group, a habit for them ... a wish that the guest spends the night quenched, fed.*
*And their seeker praises and their friend is pleased ... if the rain missed the yard so it became dark.*
*And an ugly word I turned away from so it did not harm ... and a crooked one I straightened so he became straight.*
*And I forgive the ugly word of the generous one, saving him ... and I turn away from insulting the mean one, honoring myself.*
*And I do not forsake the client even if he is forsaking ... nor do I insult the cousin if he is silenced.*
*Nor did my wealth increase me in distance from him ... even if he was possessing a decrease of money, cut off.*
*And a pitch-black night I wore its terror ... when the night frowned with the weak weakling.*
*And the vagabond will not earn praise nor wealth ... if he does not ride a great thing of the matter.*
*And did not witness the raiding horses in the forenoon ... raising dust with the hooves, dark.*
*May Allah curse a vagabond whose wish and concern ... of life is to find clothing and food.*
*He sees hunger as torture, and if he finds a fullness ... his heart spends the night from lack of concern, vague.*
*Staying with the wealthy, not leaving ... if he attained a gift of food and a perch.*
*He sleeps the forenoon until when his sleep is complete ... he wakes up cold of heart, swollen.*
*But a vagabond whom ambitions assault ... and he proceeds against the days and Time, advancing.*
*A youth of requests, who does not see hunger as sadness ... nor a meal, if he attained it, he counted as spoil.*
*If he saw one day noble deeds turning away ... he aimed at the biggest of them then determined.*
*You see his spear and his arrows and his shield ... and a ridged [sword], sharp of the blade, cutting.*
*And the curves of a saddle, sparing, and his bridle ... the equipment of a brother of war, and a steed marked.*

*So that one, if he perishes, his praise is good ... and if he lives, he does not sit weak, blamed.*

And he also said:
*O Mawiyah, avoidance and abandonment have become long ... and an excuse has excused me in seeking you.*
*O Mawiyah, indeed wealth is going and coming ... and what remains of wealth are the stories and the mention.*
*O Mawiyah, indeed I do not say to a beggar ... if he comes one day: A vow has settled in our wealth.*
*O Mawiyah, either a preventer, so he is prevented ... or a giving that rebuking does not restrain.*
*And the peoples have known that if Hatim ... wanted the abundance of wealth, he would have a surplus.*
*If the miser confers favor with wealth, then I ... give generously, so my giving is neither little nor scant.*
*I ransom the captive with it and it is eaten good ... so arrows and wine do not strip him.*
*O Mawiyah, if my owl (soul/echo) becomes in a wasteland ... of the earth, no water with me nor wine.*
*You see that what I exhausted did not harm me ... and that my hand is empty of what I was stingy with.*
*O Mawiyah, indeed I am the lord of the only one of his mother ... I protected, so no killing upon him nor captivity.*
*And I do not slap the cousin if my brothers were ... witnesses, and Time has destroyed his brothers.*
*And I do not forsake the client for his bad trial ... even if the ribs are bent over it, rancor.*
*We were rich for a time with vagabondage and wealth ... and Time gave us drink from both their cups.*
*So our wealth did not increase us in oppression against a relative ... nor did poverty disgrace our benevolence.*
*If a man becomes rich then his wealth is not ... a gift in misery, difficulty allies with him.*
*So give and do not withhold for fear of poverty ... for indeed behind difficulty, if you fear it, is ease.*
*And what harmed a neighbor, O daughter of the people, know ... neighboring me, that there is no cover for him.*
*For my neighbor is a right, he saw that as obligatory ... and before me for him, Mawiyah, the pot does not descend.*
*In my eyes regarding the private parts of my neighbor is negligence ... and in the hearing from me regarding their talk is deafness.*
*Whenever my neighbor is distant, he does not see me for his wife ... myself a connector as long as I see that he is traveling.*
*I will guard him my effort, indeed the neighbor has a sanctity ... and he returns, caution did not send against me for it.*
*By your life, I do not fear by the saying of my neighbor ... if I die: Cowardice and stinginess and treachery died.*
*May Allah curse him who keeps of wealth after him ... for his heir something, and the sin follows him.*
*So do not prevent the hoper of your gift, for it is ... the mention in the world and the reward joins you.*
*Shall I leave my wealth if I perish to an heir ... whom my eye follows when the grave encloses me?*
*O Mawiyah, what does wealth avail the youth ... when my soul rattles and my chest becomes tight with it?*
*If I, those whom I love lower me ... in a niche-grave, slippery, its sides are dusty.*
*And they stood on its edges burying me ... saying: Generosity and pride have perished.*
*And I was surrendered in it, not leaving its bottom ... so no wonder at what you see and no mockery.*
*And they went quickly shaking their palms ... saying: Digging has bloodied our fingernails.*
*There I do not spare a favor for myself ... so its beginning is provision and its end is store.*

And he also said:
*Is it not that my eye was sleepless so I spent the night turning it ... for fear of a tomorrow, I am more worthy that it does not harm it.*
*If the star is at the setting of the sun, gazing ... and there was no lightning in the horizons illuminating it.*
*If the sky was nothing but a milking ... like the web of the spider's house, he illuminates it.*
*For Ghawth has known that our nobles ... when their affairs are announced after the secret.*
*And indeed we humiliate wealth without stinginess ... and its harm does not complain of us in the years.*
*If the miser of people, his dogs growled ... and its biting was hard on the strange guest.*
*Then I am the coward of the dog, my house is trodden ... generous when the soul, its conscience is stingy.*
*For indeed my dogs have been settled and left ... little is its growling at who visits me.*
*And I expose my pot in the courtyard, its little ... is seen not being stingy with, and its much.*
*And there is no veil on my fire concealing it ... for a fire-seeker at night, but I light it.*
*No, by your father, the son of my female neighbor does not remain ... circling around our pot, not approaching it.*
*And my female neighbor does not complain of me except that I ... if her husband is absent from her, I do not visit her.*

*My good will reach her and her husband will return ... to it, and her curtains will not fall short on me.*
*And horses that run with stabbing, I witnessed them ... and if I were not in them, their excuse would be bad.*
*And a foot-crowd, disheveled of heads as if they were ... sons of Jinn, their slaughtered camel was not cooked in a pot.*
*I witnessed, and our call was Umaymah, that we are ... sons of war, we burn in it if its light is kindled.*
*On a filly, short-ribbed, short-haired, lean ... secure, its shank bones calm, its hoof-frogs [sound].*
*And a flood of death in which there is no leniency ... sharp Mashrafi swords are its bridge.*
*We were patient for it in our exhaustion and our proceeding ... with our swords until its blaze subsides.*
*And sunken-eyed, thin [camels] I drove with youths ... upon them, the saddle of one of them has untied.*
*And a Tha'labi family refuses my oppression ... noble is its rich, chaste is its poor.*
*And I swore I will not give a king an injustice ... while around me is Adi, its mature man and its inexperienced one.*

And Abu Bakr Muhammad ibn al-Hasan ibn Durayd al-Azdi said:
*Do you not see my head, its color resembled ... the edge of morning under the tails of darkness.*
*And the white ignited in its black ... like the ignition of fire in the dry Ghadha wood.*
*And a time sank the water of my youth, threw ... the thoughts of the heart with the agony of passion.*
*And the meadow of amusement returned dry, withering ... after it had been rejecting the moisture.*
*And the scattering distance kindled a brand ... it does not cease burning the folds of the bowels.*
*And sleeplessness took my eye as a familiar place ... when the phantom of slumber shunned its eyelids.*
*So all that I met is forgiven ... beside what the distance of separation left over.*
*If some of what my heart meets touched the solid rock ... it would have shattered the solid rocks.*
*If the moist branch withers, then know ... that its end is depletion and destruction.*
*I choked, nay a lump choked me ... its stubbornness is more killing to me than grief.*
*If endurance protects weeping from my eye ... the heart is stopped on the paths of weeping.*
*If dreams had whispered to me what ... I meet awake, death would have hit me.*
*A station I did not think would be pleased with ... for himself a possessor of strength nor intellect.*
*Natures of a cloud, deceitful is its lightning ... and a standing between hope and wish.*
*In every day a disliked dwelling ... sipping the water of my soul, and hated.*
*I did not think that Time would bend me to ... a harm which the lizard of the holes is not pleased with.*
*I glance at life at a trickle, for if ... I intended sipping, I intended the difficult of the intoxicated.*
*Is Time returning to me a full year ... to what it accustomed, or is it not hoped for?*
*O Time, if there is no goodwill, then go slow ... for your slowness and goodwill are equal.*
*Ease upon me, long have you worn me out ... and keep some water of a peeled branch.*
*Do not think, O Time, that I am humble ... to a calamity that strips me the stripping of knives.*
*I practiced one whom if the spheres fell from ... the sides of the atmosphere upon him, he would not complain.*
*But it is the spit of a chest-diseased one when ... foam boiled from its sides, he threw.*
*I accepted by force, and upon force is the acceptance ... of one who was angry at the turn of fate.*
*Indeed the two new ones [night and day], when they overcome ... a new one, bring it close to decay.*
*I did not know, while Time is fond of ... scattering the gathered and undoing the strands.*
*That fate is my thrower into a pit ... the soul of one who fell in it does not recover.*
*So if I stumbled after it, if my soul ... escaped from this, then say: No recovery.*
*And if its duration is connected ... to death, I empowered consolation over sorrow.*
*Indeed Imru' al-Qays ran to a limit ... so his death hindered him before the limit.*
*And the soul of Abu al-Jiyr mixed with passion ... until death contained him in what he contained.*
*And Ibn al-Ashajj the King drove himself ... to destruction for fear of the gloating of enemies.*
*And the sword of drawn death snatched Al-Waddah ... before what he hoped for.*
*And Yazid rose before me seeking ... the limit of heights, so he did not weaken nor slacken.*
*So it intercepted before what he aimed at, while ... the gluttonous, usurious Grandfather had been serious with him.*
*Am I an innovation among leaders against whom ... the turn of time transgressed and assaulted.*
*And if destines grant me what ... I plot for them, I will return to repairing the rift.*

*And Amr rose to his vengeances ... so he lowered from them every high aspiring one.*
*So he brought down Al-Zabba' forcibly while she was ... of the eagle of the atmosphere's slate, a higher origin.*
*And a sword his ambition rose with ... until he hit the furthest limit of the thrown.*
*So he made the Abyssinian drink soaking death ... and occupied from Ghumdan the niche of statues.*
*Then Ibn Hind, his fires commenced ... the day he burnt Tamim with the fire.*
*No despair presented itself to me whispering to my ambition ... but a hope challenged it and was concealed.*
*An oath by the working camels, speed throws ... with them between the middle parts of the deserts.*
*Sunken-eyed like the ghosts of bows, lean ... bleeding with mixed fluids from the pulling of nose-rings.*
*They sink in the sea of darkness, and in the forenoon ... they float in the mirage if the mirage floats.*
*Their hooves from unshodness and pain ... are bruised, dyeing the white pebbles.*
*Carrying every pale, hunched one ... from the length of perseverance of morning and night travel.*
*Devout, the length of hunger pared his body ... so he is like the arrow of Nab' wood, bent of back.*
*Intending the one which the Lord of Heights preferred ... when He spread its soil over the structures.*
*Until when he faced it he wept, not ... owning the tear of the eye from where it flowed.*
*Then he circumambulated and bent kissing ... then came to the two Marwas and ran.*
*And made Hajj obligatory and doubled an Umrah ... after he clamored and said Talbiyah and supplicated.*
*Then he went in the Talbiyah-sayers to ... where the two narrow passes and Mina are aimed at.*
*Then he came to the Definition (Arafat) reading, humble ... agreeing between Ilal and Al-Naqa.*
*And he resumed the seven and seven after it ... and the seven between Al-Aqabah and the stones.*
*And he went for the farewell, whoever went has ... attained a reward and hated the abandonment of nonsense.*
*With that or with horses running the gallop ... rising, their shoulders, hard of kidneys.*
*Carrying every brisk, brave one ... sharp of heart, wading the flood of battle.*
*Covering the loins of death with his cheeks if ... the flame of death was disliked to warm at.*
*If death were represented to him as a peer, not ... would awe turn him away from it nor would he bend.*
*And if destiny protected a soul from him ... he would aim at it or you permit what he protected.*
*Deaths become obedient to his command ... pleased with what he pleases and refusing what he refused.*
*Nay, an oath by the high mountains of Ya'rub, is there ... for a swearer after this an end?*
*They are the ones, if they boasted, the ones said ... in the mouth of a man who boasted against you is the dust of the earth.*
*They are the ones who made the springs of dew flow ... pouring for whoever sought or asked.*
*They are the ones who subdued whoever leaned ... and straightened whoever turned and inclined.*
*They are the ones who made those who plotted drink ... the milk of injustice, bitter sips.*
*He removed the stuffing of a woven coat of mail ... until I hide between the bowels of the corpses.*
*And my two companions are a sharp sword, in its blade ... like the crawling of ants rising in the hills.*
*As if between its ridge and its edge ... a frying pan in which embers eroded.*
*It shows death when it follows its trace ... in the darkness of livers, paths not seen.*
*If it falls on a body it leaves it ... after it was odd, and it is even.*
*And a horse overlooking the regions, fleshy his thigh ... knitting the short ribs, huge, hard of the sciatic nerve.*
*Close what is between the croup and the back ... far what is between the back of the head and the rump.*
*High of neck in a full vein ... wide of arm in secure nerves.*
*Mounted in hidden cannons ... to frogs like the ejected date stone.*
*He turns two long necks in a gathered [head] ... to two glancing [eyes] with the looks of the wild cow.*
*Intertwined of creation, wide his chest ... smooth of the back, twisted, strong.*
*No knocking of knees disgraces him nor wideness ... nor weak flesh nor bone protrusion.*
*He runs so the wind falls in his goals ... tired, seeking refuge in the mounds of the dust.*
*If you strove looking in his trace ... you said: A light flashed or a lightning disappeared.*
*As if Orion is in his pasterns ... and the Star is in his forehead when he appeared.*
*They are my two equipments, the sufficient ones, so I have lost whoever ... I prepared, so let him be distant from me who was distant.*
*So if you hear of a mill set up ... for war, know that I am the pole of the mill.*

*And if you see a fire of death blazing ... know that I am the igniter of that blaze.*
*The best of souls flowing openly ... on the edges of the sharp swords and spears.*
*Indeed Iraq, I did not leave its people ... out of hatred that repelled me nor loathing.*
*Nothing attracted my eye since I left them ... that pleases the glance from this mankind.*
*They are the high peaks, lofty of summits ... and people are holes other than them and drops.*
*They are the seas, full are their waves ... and people are shallow water, puddles and pools.*
*If I had seen for them after them ... a likeness, and closed my eyes on the prick of thorns.*
*Except the two Emirs who cast ... upon me a shade of bliss that was extensive.*
*They are the ones who built for me a hope ... despair had stood with it on a brink.*
*They remedied the life which was muddied by ... the turn of time, so it became palatable and clear.*
*And they made the water of modesty flow for me comfortably ... so my branch shook after it had withered.*
*They are the ones who rose with my gaze ... after my closing eyes on the sting of the mote.*
*They are the ones who populated for me a side ... of prosperity that was of old effaced.*
*And they necklaced me a favor, if compared ... to the gratitude of the people of earth entirely, it would not fulfill.*
*With a tenth of a tenth of it, and it was like ... a sip in the waves of a sea that overflowed.*
*Indeed Ibn Mikal the Emir lifted me ... after I was like the thrown thing.*
*And Abu al-Abbas extended my upper arms from ... after the contraction of the arm and the short span.*
*My soul be the ransom for my two Emirs, and whoever ... is under the sky for my two Emirs be the ransom.*
*My thanks for them will not cease connecting ... my wording, or the turn of death hinders me.*
*Indeed those whom I left without hatred ... my heart did not deviate from them nor slip.*
*But I have a determination, if I draw it ... for the ambiguous matter, it opens and splits.*
*And if I wish, youth would join its two sides ... upon me in the shade of bliss and wealth.*
*And a tender, soft girl would play with me ... she makes sick, and in sipping her is the cure of sickness.*
*Or she whispered to the inaccessible [ibex], so he descended for her ... obedient to leading from the peaks of summits.*
*Or she hit the devout one in a smooth ... difficult of path, rugged of ascent.*
*Her intimacy distracted him from his glorification and religion ... until you see him having become amorous.*
*As if the reddish-white wine is mixed with it ... water of rose harvest when the night darkens.*
*The sipper of the coldness of her saliva draws it ... between the whiteness of the teeth from her and the dark lips.*
*May [rain] water Al-Aqiq, then Al-Huzayz, then Al-Mala ... to Al-Nuhayt, then the near villages.*
*Then the High Mirbad where you meet in it ... the wrestling places of lions by the glances of wild cows.*
*The place of every noble whose fathers' feats ... rose with him in the branch of height.*
*From those whose essence, if they trace lineage ... is from an essence from which is the Chosen Prophet.*
*Black [cloud], the South wind lent it a side ... of it, and the hand of the East wind opposed its rain.*
*It distanced, Yemeni, so when its bosoms ... spread and its rear extended, it covered.*
*So it covered the horizon, so every side ... of it, as if from its drops the rain cloud greeted.*
*If its lightnings faded, there presented to it ... the East wind igniting from it what faded.*
*And if its thunders slackened, the shepherd of the South ... drove it, so it sang as he sang.*
*As if in its bosoms and its chest ... are chests [of camels] calling between rumbling and haste.*
*You did not see like the rain cloud grazing camels, neglected ... you think it tended, while it is neglected.*
*So it covered the earth, so every spot ... of it says: The rain has settled in this.*
*It says to the barren lands when they became consistent ... with its driving: Trust in quenching and life.*
*So it widened the raised grounds with a sufficient flow ... and covered the bellies with quenching water.*
*As if the desert, after its rain ... is a sea whose current rose then calmed.*
*That gift, may a people not cease to be specified with it ... they are for the earth rain and gift.*
*I am not, when a flood burdens me ... of those who say: The torrent reached the high grounds.*
*And if a sigh settled between my ribs ... filling what is between the side to the side.*
*I restrained it, suppressed, until is seen ... humbled from it what had tyrannized.*
*And I do not say if a calamity befalls me ... the saying of despair: The membrane in the belly split.*

*I have practiced of matters a practice ... that assaults terror if terror rises.*
*I have twisting if my enemy twists ... and I have straightness if my friend is straight.*
*My taste is colocynth for the enemy sometimes ... and honey with wine for him who seeks my love.*
*Soft, if treated gently, easy is my fold ... twisting, if treated roughly, feared is the harm.*
*Forbearance holds to the sides of my waistband ... when the winds of recklessness fly with the waistbands.*
*A polluting greed does not entice me ... if greed swayed or enticed.*
*And my experiences have risen with me to ranks ... they looked down with me from them on the paths of intellect.*
*If a man is feared for excessive harm ... no rashness nor harm is feared from me.*
*From other than weakness, but I am a man ... guarding an honor which dirt did not pollute.*
*And guarding the honor of a man is to give what ... he was stingy with of what he possessed and extracted.*
*And praise is the best of what you took as a shield ... and the most precious of stores after piety.*
*And every generation rising in a time ... is like the time in which it appeared.*
*And people are like plants, so of it is pleasing ... fresh, green, its wood is bitter of fruit.*
*And of it is what the eye despises, even if ... you tasted its fruit, it swallowed sweet in the uvulas.*
*The young is straightened from his deviation ... so what was crooked of him and bent becomes straight.*
*And the old man, if you straighten him from his deviation ... the training does not straighten from him what twisted.*
*Likewise the branch, its bending is easy ... soft, its pinching is hard if it hardens.*
*Whoever wrongs people, they avoid his wrong ... and his sides become mighty from them and he protects.*
*And they are, to him who his side is soft to them ... more unjust than the snakes of the roots of Sifa plant.*
*Slaves of the possessor of wealth even if they do not taste ... of his flood in a gulp that heals thirst.*
*And they are enemies to him who is destitute even if ... he shared with them in what he gained and collected.*
*I tested my days, and the naive is not like one ... whom Time wrapped upon and cloaked.*
*Intellect does not raise without luck, nor ... does ignorance lower you if luck rises.*
*Whoever Time does not admonish, what ... the preacher went with today or tomorrow will not benefit him.*
*Whoever his days did not benefit with lessons ... blindness was more appropriate for him than guidance.*
*Whoever measured what he did not see by what he saw ... what is near showed him what is far.*
*Whoever let greed own the leadership did not cease ... sipping in water of humiliation, stagnant.*
*Whoever countered greeds with despair, the eye of ... glory gazed at him from where he gazed.*
*Whoever bent the soul to its disliked thing ... richness was his companion where he intended.*
*Whoever does not stop at the end of his capability ... wide steps fall short of him.*
*Whoever wasted prudence gathered for himself ... regret more stinging than the burn of the sun.*
*Whoever hung the loops of his character to vanity ... the loops of loathing were tied to those loops.*
*Whoever reached above the end of his reach ... attaining the near incapacitated him, let alone the far.*
*Whoever aimed at what his capability falls short of ... of the burden, one day returned with broken back.*
*And people, a thousand of them are like one ... and one is like a thousand if a matter occurs.*
*And for the youth from his wealth is what his hands ... presented before his death, not what he acquired.*
*And indeed man is a good story ... so be a good story for him who remembers.*
*Indeed I milked Time, its two halves, so ... it was bitter for me at a time, and at times sweet.*
*And my canine tooth bared from experience, so say ... about a full-grown camel who trained matters and rode.*
*And people are for death, a fresh plant it eats ... and rarely does fresh plant remain upon eating.*
*I wondered at one certain that death ... if it comes to him, is not treated with incantations.*
*And he is, from negligence, in pits ... stumbling between darkness and night-blindness.*
*We, and no ingratitude to Allah, are as ... was said about the grazing camel: he found empty place so he grazed.*
*If he sensed a sound he was frightened by it ... it quieted from him, he continued and played.*
*We are frightened by the thing that scares us ... and we graze in negligence when it ends.*
*Indeed misery is distributed to the miserable ... he possesses no return for it when it comes.*
*And blame for the free man is a resident deterrent ... and the slave, nothing deters him but the stick.*
*And the bane of intellect is desire, so whoever's intellect ... rises over his desire has been saved.*

*How many a brother whose character is hated ... I purified affection for him with a pleasing character.*
*If you test the sword as praised, do not ... blame it one day if you see it has bounced.*
*And the horse crosses the limit, and perhaps ... a stumble appears to his running so he falls.*
*Who is for you with the refined, noble one who ... does not find a step for the defect to him.*
*If you examine the affairs of people, you will not ... find a man who possessed perfection so he sufficed.*
*Indeed the stars of glory have become setting ... and its shrinking shade has become collected.*
*Except remnants of people by whom ... to the path of noble deeds one is guided.*
*If conversations drew their news ... they were like the scent of the garden the dew visited early.*
*How excellent would be the life if the youth ... death accepted from him the high bribes.*
*Or if his time adorned him with youth ... gray hair did not snatch those ornaments.*
*Far it is! Whatever is continued is retrieved ... and in the calamities of Time for people are consolations.*
*And youths whom the phantom of slumber travelled with ... so they conversed with sleep while they were soft of necks.*
*And the night is casting its chest on the deserts ... and the white camels are searching the hatching places of sandgrouse.*
*Where he does not guide to a hearing a sound ... except the hooting of the owl or the voice of the echo.*
*I accompanied them in the night journey until when ... the tool of the saddle leaned with the cowardly, sick one.*
*I said to them: Indeed slowness, its end is ... weakness, so strive, you will praise the end of the night journey.*
*And a desolate of sides, its water is flowing ... broken of sides, demolished of the pool.*
*As if the feathers on its sides ... are blue arrowheads sharpened to be used.*
*I came to it while the wolf howls around it ... blocked of the hearing hole from the length of hunger.*
*And a female producing, the mother of her father is her mother ... the touch of emaciation did not betray her body.*
*He spread her the daughter of his brother, so she bent ... with a child by whom fire is kindled and roasted.*
*And a watchtower, smooth its sides ... difficult of tops, rugged of ascent.*
*I ascended while the sun was spitting its saliva ... and the shadow from under the shoe was worn.*
*And a night visitor whom the wolf comforts when ... the wolf cries in the evening and howls.*
*He sought shelter at my fire, and it is a familiar place ... its light calls the seekers to hospitality.*
*By Allah, what a phantom of imagination visiting ... the dreams of sleep drive it to the heart.*
*It traverses the middle parts of the deserts despising ... the terror of the darkness of the night when the night breaks.*
*Ask it, if it speaks clearly about its news ... how did it climb the night or how was it guided.*
*If it knew before it what is Persia ... and what are its desolate deserts and the villages.*
*And a questioner about my disturber from my homeland ... its side did not become narrow for me nor did it bounce.*
*I said: Destiny is the owner of the youth's affair ... from where he does not know and from where he knows.*
*Do not ask me, and ask Destiny: Does ... a refuge and a shelter protect from it?*
*A man must meet what He wrote ... The Possessor of the Throne, of what he is meeting and [He] revealed.*
*It is no wonder if a unjust time persisted ... so it stripped the marrow-filled bone and selected.*
*For you may see the dry one turning green, and you may ... meet the brother of poverty one day having grown.*
*O these two, have you asked for us ... the piercer of the veil from the eyes of a gazelle.*
*The mother of the two boys was not fair, who ... captivated the brother of forbearance while he was not captivated.*
*Be shy of white hairs between your ear-locks that ... the white women lead you, the leading of the guided.*
*Far it is! How ugly is this slip ... Is it joy after graying and baldness?*
*Nay, many a night its two sides gathered for me ... a daughter of eighty [years/dirhams? context implies wine], a bride displayed.*
*Water did not possess its command over her ... nor did the kindled flame pollute her.*
*As if the horn of the sun in its rising ... followed her action in the bowl and the cup.*
*I disputed with her, a wonderful one, she does not attack ... the boon-companion of her sharpness when he gets drunk.*
*As if the blossom of the garden is the arrangement of his wording ... improvising or reciting or if he sang.*
*Of everything the youth attains, I have attained ... and the man, good praise remains after him.*
*So if I die, my pleasure has ended ... and everything, [when] it reaches the limit, ends.*
*And if I live, I accompany my time knowing ... what folded of its turn and what was revealed.*

*Far be it for one whom intelligence left ... and forbearance, that I follow the scouts of obscenity.*
*Or that I be seen humbled by a calamity ... or by joy, happy or arrogant.*
*Whoever fed the orphan and the poor and the ... captive out of love for the God, Possessor of Heights.*
*And whoever established his prayer humble ... gives Zakat bowing to whoever came.*
*And whoever Gabriel walked with Michael ... on his sides in wars when he walked.*
*And whoever calls Gabriel openly ... while the war has stood on the leg of destruction.*
*There is no sword except Dhu al-Fiqar, know ... and no youth except Ali in the battle.*
*Who has a praise whose mention is exalted ... joined with Allah when the creation stands?*
*For you are the Prophet and the Trustee, a father ... and his wife and the sons of the People of the Cloak.*
*O caller to the Truth who ... revived for us the dead of wishes with gifts.*
*In the mine of wisdom you were raised, and in ... the house of correctness and guidance and piety.*
*Your two Muhammads achieved praise for you ... and the two Hasans are beauty of glory and light.*
*And the two Zayds increased you in high pride ... above Pleiades and Arcturus it rose.*
*And the glory of Ishmael with that has topped ... of the heights, the peaks fell short of it.*
*A fatherhood, if stars wrapped it ... the sun of the forenoon would darken before it.*
*O lofty mountain of Allah and the one to whom ... the handles seek refuge in calamities.*
*Seekers of wealth aim for your doors ... as the pilgrims of Mina aim for the House.*
*So all of them, seeker and desirous ... returns from you with the desire and satisfaction.*
*May you live gently, and your son Al-Mahdi in ... the shade of joy and bliss and prosperity.*
*The earth is collected for you, all of it, its rugged ... and its plain, and its people are ransom for you.*
*Excellent is the helper, by your life, and excellent what ... you are a treasure for, and excellent is the followed.*
*So strengthen a hand with him, for he is for you ... a lion, a strong lion at the sanctuary.*
*Soon you will see him announcing ... against everyone who opposed you the sword of annihilation.*
*Take a bride displayed, appetizing ... possessing meanings arranged the arrangement of ornaments.*
*Fair like the pure water in delicacy ... and its taste is the taste of honeycomb gathered.*
*The presentation of one who has become saying, blaming ... Has he not sobered? Has he not ended? Has he not refrained?*

And some of Banu Asad said:
And it is said: It is Al-Nazzar al-Faq'asi. He described the snake, the pigeon, the falcon, the sandgrouse, and the horse. Al-Asma'i recited it:
*The house of Layla became distant, so the visiting place was far ... so your eyes do not taste sleep.*
*And a Barih (hot wind/omen) passed at her separation ... so the Crow of separation confirmed that.*
*And she became at Baghdad in a house ... having balconies below the sky.*
*And an army and a garrison around it ... thick of necks like the lions of Al-Shara.*
*In their hands are newly polished ... Surayji swords cutting the necks.*
*And before her is a distant land ... the owl answers the echo of the echo in it.*
*And how many a weak one is before your house ... and a blocking black one in a burrow.*
*And a watering place, altered is its water ... neglected, not turned to, it has overflowed.*
*And a snake which does not answer the charmers ... brown, possessing a sting like the rope.*
*Deaf, silent, long of hibernation ... wide of the mouth corner, bare of the back.*
*He has in the dry grass a puff that flies ... on his sides like the ember of Ghadha.*
*And two eyes, red seem their corners ... glowing in a head like the millstone.*
*When he yawns he reveals ... sharpened, crooked ones like knives.*
*As if the rustle of the millstone is his sound ... when his fangs clash on the rocks.*
*And if he bit the two edges of a rock, then ... he would sink his fangs into the rock.*
*As if his crawling tracks are straps ... cut singly and some of them doubly.*
*And the cooing of a turtle-dove thrilled me ... merry in the evening, cheering in the forenoon.*
*Of the pigeons, wailing, she came early to ... a branch of palm at Dhat al-Ghadha.*
*She sang on it with a melody of hers ... stirring for the lover what has passed.*
*Ringed, clothed in adornment ... by the call of Noah to her when he called.*
*I have not seen a weeping one like her ... weeping while her tear is not seen.*
*She lost a small chick so she circled for it ... and the ropes of death had caught it.*
*So when despair of it appeared, she wept ... for it, and what does weeping return?*

*And a hungry, carnivorous one hunted it ... beating the wing, fast of escape.*
*Sharp of claws, bare of the shank ... trained, of the blue-eyed [falcons] in whom is a curve (?).*
*You see the wild beasts and birds from fear of him ... retreating from him when he goes early.*
*So he spent the night fasting on a watchtower ... on a lofty peak difficult to ascend.*
*When his morning shone for him ... and he shook the dew from his shoulders.*
*And he rubbed with his claw a dried [blood] ... on his beak from the blood of sandgrouse.*
*So he ascended in the atmosphere then circled ... trained, fast when he swoops.*
*So he sensed a flock of sandgrouse approaching ... the trough of a watering place which buckets did not exhaust.*
*They went early with water-skins quenching ... for downy chicks thrown in the desert.*
*Racing to a watering place, so they did not turn ... to what lagged behind or what slackened.*
*They remembered a possessor of moss, overflowing ... the scum circulating on its edges.*
*In it is a group of sandgrouse arriving ... and another returning from it, quenched.*
*So they filled water-skins not disgraced ... by stitching, and the loops of them were tied.*
*So he killed a dark one of them ... and tore her chest and bowels.*
*You think the rustle of his wings when ... he hung from the air a lightning that flashed.*
*So they turned away striving in escape ... fleeing in the effaced landmarks.*
*So they returned thirsty and gave them [chicks] drink ... their regurgitations like the water of the placenta.*
*So they spent the night talking to speckled of backs ... red of crops, yellow of throats.*
*That, and I go early in the morning ... with a short-haired [horse] like the wolf, thick of legs.*
*He has a rump, strong, high ... and pillars [legs] that do not complain of pain.*
*And an ear, pointed, sharp ... and a wide mouth-split and a hollow belly.*
*And two jaws tightened to a nostril ... wide, and crooked [legs] long of step.*
*He has seven [ribs?] that lengthened after ... seven shortened for him, so he became straight.*
