*And seven bare and seven clothed ... and five quenched and five thirsty.*
*And seven neared and seven distanced ... from him, so there is no defect seen in him.*
*And seven thick and seven thin ... and a back of a wild ass and a back of a sandgrouse.*
*Sharp of the eight, broad of the eight ... strong of the skin, strong of the back.*
*And in him are five of the birds, so who ... has seen a horse like him possessed.*
*Two crows above a sandgrouse of his ... and a vulture and his queen bee [blaze] has appeared.*
*And he is preferred with provision before the family ... and in all his wintering he is tracked.*
*We devoted to him from the noble milch-camels ... five, enduring, high of humps.*
*A portion is ransomed for him constantly ... and we give him of milk what he desires.*
*So he spent the summer fed, and when he wintered ... we took him by leading until he folded [became lean].*
*So we roused with him a herd in the Ghatat ... empty of bellies, sound of legs.*
*So they turned away like lightning in their flight ... fleeing, breaking the hard rocks.*
*So the slave directed him in their track ... so sometimes he disappears and sometimes he is seen.*
*So he felled five, among them one killed on spot ... and one lifting his legs, bleeding of kidneys.*
*And two shook their dyed [chests] ... and a third sobbed with blood.*
*So we returned with game to our family ... and the dress of darkness had covered the earth.*
*And we spent the night dividing its limbs ... for a neighbor, and he who came seeking ate it.*
*And we went like the ivory bracelet of the bride ... slender, not complaining of pain.*
*And the women spent the night invoking protection for him ... and eating from his roasted game.*

Abdullah ibn Abbas

News of Abdullah ibn Abbas and Nafi' ibn al-Azraq and the poem of Umar ibn Abi Rabi'ah
The narrators said: Nafi' ibn al-Azraq the Kharijite came to Abdullah ibn Abbas, may Allah be pleased with him, one day and began [asking] until he [Ibn Abbas] became weary and started turning away from him in annoyance. Then Umar ibn Abdullah ibn Abi Rabi'ah ibn al-Mughira ibn Abdullah ibn Umar ibn Makhzum appeared, and he was a youth that day. He greeted Abdullah and sat down. Abdullah said: "Recite to us something." So he recited to him: "Amin Ali Nu'min Anta Ghadin fa-Mubkiru", until he reached its end, and it is about eighty verses. Ibn al-Azraq said: "To Allah are you, O Ibn Abbas! We beat the livers of camels to you asking you about religion, and you turn away, and a youth from Quraysh comes to you and recites foolishness to you and you listen to him?" [Ibn Abbas said:] "By Allah, I did not hear foolishness." He said: "Did he not recite to you:
*She saw a man, as for when the sun opposes ... he is exposed to sun, and as for in the evening he feels cold.*
Ibn Abbas said: "He did not recite it to us like this. Rather he said: 'Fayadh-ha' (he is exposed to the forenoon sun), and as for in the evening 'Fayakhsuru' (he feels cold)." Ibn al-Azraq said: "Have you memorized what he said?" He said: "By Allah, I did not hear it except my hour, and if I wished to narrate it I would repeat it." He said: "Then repeat it." So he recited it to him. Ibn al-Azraq said: "I have never seen anyone more retaining (*Arwa*) than you." Abdullah said: "I have not seen anyone more retaining than Umar [ibn al-Khattab], nor more knowledgeable than Ali, may Allah be pleased with them both."
The poem:
*Is it from the family of Nu'm you are going early then early morning ... the morning of tomorrow, or going in the evening then midday?*
*For a need of the soul you did not say in its answer ... so you convey an excuse, and the speech excuses.*
*You wander in love for Nu'm, so neither is the gathering united ... nor the rope connected nor the heart refraining.*
*Neither is the proximity of Nu'm, if she nears you, beneficial ... nor does her distance console, nor are you patient.*
*And another came before Nu'm, and the like of her ... forbade the possessor of intellect if you desist or think.*
*If I visit Nu'm, a relative of hers ... does not cease, whenever I meet him, to frown.*
*Hard upon him that I visit her house ... he conceals hatred for me, showing the hate.*
*Convey from me to her peace, for it ... is denied, my visiting her, and publicized.*
*By the sign of what she said the morning I met her ... at the flow of riders: Is this the publicized one?*
*Stop and look, O Asma, do you know him ... Is this the Mughiri who used to be mentioned?*
*Is this the one whom you praised in description? I was not ... by your life, forgetting him until the day I am buried.*
*She said: Yes, no doubt, changed his color ... the night travel, reviving his brisk pace and early movement.*
*If it is him, he has indeed changed after us ... from the covenant, and the human may change.*
*My body changed, but the character is like what ... you knew, and an informer did not inform of your secret.*
*She saw a man, as for when the sun opposes ... he is exposed to the sun, and as for in the evening he feels cold.*
*A brother of travel, traverser of a land, deserts threw ... him, so he is disheveled, dusty.*
*Little upon the back of the riding beast is his shadow ... and quenched is what the embellished cloak repelled from him.*
*And pleased her of her life the shade of a room ... and a quenched [garden], wrapped in gardens, green.*
*And a guardian who sufficed her everything that concerns her ... so she does not stay awake for anything at the end of the night.*
*And the night of Dhu Dawran, she tasked me with the night journey ... and sometimes the deceived lover tasks himself with terror.*
*So I spent the night a watcher of the companions on a brink ... watching who of them circulates and looking.*
*At them, when sleep takes them ... and I have a sitting place, were it not for the need, rugged.*
*And my young she-camel spent the night in the open, and her saddle ... is for a night-comer or for one who came, exposed.*
*And I spent the night whispering to the soul: Where is her tent ... and where is the source for the matter I come to?*
*So a scent I knew guided the heart to her ... belonging to her, and the desire of the soul which was appearing.*
*So when I lost the sound from them and were extinguished ... lamps that were lit at Isha and illuminated.*
*And a small moon set which I was hoping for its setting ... and shepherds returned and night-talkers slept.*
*And the voice was lowered from me, I approached the walk of the ... snake, and my corner, for fear of the people, was slanted.*
*So I greeted when I surprised her, so she became distracted ... and almost announced the return of the greeting.*
*She said, and bit the fingertips: You have exposed me ... and you are a man, your easy matter is difficult.*
*I see you, when we were easy for you, did you not fear ... a watcher, while around me from your enemy are present ones?*
*So by Allah, I do not know, is it hastening a need ... that traveled with you, or has he whom you feared slept?*
*I said to her: Nay, love and passion led me ... to you, and not a soul of the people perceives.*
*She said, and she softened and her fright calmed ... May the Compeller Lord protect you with His protection.*
*So you, O Abu al-Khattab, undisputed ... are a trustee over me as long as you stay commanded.*
*So oh for you of a night, its length shortened ... and my night was not before that shortening.*
*And oh for you of a diversion there and a session ... for us, a disturber did not disturb it for us.*
*It glitters when she smiles from it as if it is ... hailstones or a blooming daisy.*
*And she gazes with her eyes at me as gazed ... at a doe in the middle of the thicket a young gazelle.*
*So when the night passed except a little of it ... and the followers of its star almost set.*
*She signaled that the tribe, time has come from them ... for waking, but a promise from you is difficult.*

Ibn Abbas said: 'He did not recite it to us like this. He only said: "He becomes exposed to the sun (yad-ha)." As for "In the evening he becomes cold (yakhsar)".' Ibn al-Azraq said: 'Did you memorize what he said?' He replied: 'By Allah, I only heard it this hour of mine, but if I wished to recite it back, I would return it.' He said: 'Then return it.' So he recited it to him. Ibn al-Azraq said: 'I have never seen anyone more retaining (of poetry) than you.' Abdullah [Ibn Abbas] said: 'I have never seen anyone more retaining than Umar, nor more knowledgeable than Ali, may Allah be pleased with them both.' The Poem: 'Is it from the family of Nu'm that you are leaving early... tomorrow morning, or departing in the evening then traveling by midday heat? For a need of the soul you did not speak in its answer... so you could present an excuse, and speech excuses. You wander in love towards Nu'm, but neither is the gathering united... nor is the rope connected, nor does the heart refrain. Neither is the nearness of Nu'm, if she draws near to you, beneficial... nor does her distance console, nor do you have patience. And another woman came instead of Nu'm, and the likes of her... forbid the possessor of reason, if he would desist or think. When I visited Nu'm, a relative of hers never ceased... becoming like a tiger (angry) whenever I met him. It is hard on him that I visit her house... he hides hatred for me, manifesting malice. Deliver my greetings to her, for indeed... my visiting her is denied and publicized. By the token of what she said the morning I met her... at the stream-bed of riders: "Is this the publicized one? Stop and look, O Ism (name), do you recognize him... Is this the Mughiri who used to be mentioned? Is this the one whose description you praised? For I will not... by your life, forget him until the day I am buried." Nu'm said: "No doubt, his color has been changed by... the night travel that revives his gait, and the midday journey. If it is indeed him, he has changed after us... from the covenant, and the human may change. My body has changed, but my character is as... you knew, and no informant has reported your secret." She saw a man who, if the sun opposes him... becomes exposed to it, and in the evening becomes cold. A brother of travel, a traverser of land, tossed about... by deserts, so he is disheveled and dusty. His shade upon the back of the mount is little... and soaked is what the patterned cloak repelled from him. She was pleased in her life by the shade of a room... and a lush, green, wrapped garden. And a guardian who sufficed her every thing that concerned her... so she does not stay awake for anything at the end of the night. And on the night of Dhu Dawran, she burdened me with night travel... and indeed the deceived lover may be burdened with terror. I spent the night as a watchman for the companions on a brink... watching those of them who patrolled, and looking. Towards them, when would sleep take them... while I had a sitting place that, were it not for the need, was rugged. My young she-camel spent the night in the open, and her saddle... was for a night visitor or one who came exposed. I spent the night whispering to the soul: Where is her tent... and where is the source for the matter I am coming to? A fragrant scent directed the heart to her; I recognized it... belonging to her, and the passion of the soul which used to appear. When I lost the sound from them and were extinguished... lamps that were lit at evening and illuminated. And a small moon I was hoping for its setting disappeared... and shepherds went home and night-talkers slept. And the voice lowered for me; I approached with the walk of the... sand-grouse (or snake), while my corner shied away in fear of the people. I greeted when I surprised her, so she was distracted with love... and she almost spoke aloud in returning the greeting. She said, biting her fingertips: "You have exposed me... while you are a man whose easy affair is difficult. I show you, since we are easy for you, did you not fear... a watcher, while around me are those of your enemies present? By Allah, I do not know if it is a haste of a need... that traveled with you, or has the one you were fearing slept?" I said to her: "Nay, love and passion led me... to you, and not a soul among the people perceives." She said, having softened and her fear subsided: "May the protection of your Great Lord protect you. You are, O Abu al-Khattab, undisputed... trustworthy over me, given command as long as you stay." Oh, what a night it was! Its length became short... whereas my night before that was not short. Oh, what a diversion was there, and a session... for us, which no disturber disturbed for us. It flutters when she smiles revealing it, as if it is... hailstones or a chamomile in bloom. She gazes at me with her eyes as... a young gazelle gazes at a doe in the middle of a thicket. When the night passed except a little of it... and the sequence of its stars almost sank. She signaled that the tribe, the time has come for their... waking, but a promise from you is difficult (to keep/obtain).'

*Nothing startled me except a caller: Depart ... and a known blond [light] from the morning had appeared.*
*And when she saw who of them had risen ... and their waking ones, she said: Point out, how do you command?*
*I said: I will show myself to them, so either I escape them ... or the sword attains a revenge so I take revenge.*
*She said: Is it a realization of what a hater said ... against us and a confirmation of what was transmitted?*
*If it is what must be, then other than it ... of the matter is more guiding to concealment and more covering.*
*I will narrate to my two sisters the beginning of our story ... and I have no delaying from letting them know.*
*Perhaps they will make a way out for you ... and welcome a path in what I was restricted.*
*So she stood, sad, no blood in her face ... from grief, shedding a tear that descends.*
*She said to her two sisters: Help a youth ... who came visiting, and the command is decreed for the command.*
*So two free women stood to her, upon them ... two garments of silk, violet and green.*
*They approached and were terrified, then said ... Lessen the blame upon yourself, for the matter is easier.*
*The younger of them said to her: I will give him my cloak ... and my garment and this shift if he fears.*
*He stands and walks between us disguised ... so our secret does not spread nor are we mentioned.*
And it is narrated: *And we bring him out from between us covering him ... so our secret does not appear nor is he revealed.*
*So there was of my shield, before who I was fearing ... three figures: two buxom girls and a pubescent girl.*
*When we crossed the courtyard of the tribe, they said to me ... Did you not fear the enemies while the night is moonlit?*
*And they said: Is this your habit forever, heedless ... Do you not feel shame or desist or think?*
*If you come, grant the glance of your eye to other than us ... so they think that passion is where you look.*
*So the last covenant I had with her was where she turned away ... and a cheek, pure, and an eye-socket appeared to her.*
*Except that I said: O Nu'm, a saying ... to her while the Arhabi riding camels were being urged.*
*Congratulations to the husband of the Amiri woman her scent, the ... delicious, and her fragrance which I remember.*
*So I stood to a lean camel, her fat betrayed by ... the night travel until her meat is stripped.*
*And my confinement for needs until as if she is ... the worn-out wood of a board or a tied litter.*
*And water in a desert, its familiarity is little ... empty lands, summer did not create a settlement for it.*
*In it is a built place for the spider as if it is ... on the end of the sides, raw cloth spread out.*
*I arrived and I do not know: Is what is after my arrival ... of the night [more], or is what passed of it more?*
*So a ghoul of the land circled it as if she is ... if she turned, a mad woman when she looks.*
*Disputing with me out of greed for the water, her head ... and before what she desires is a filled well.*
*Trying for the arrival, were it not for her rein ... and my pulling with it, she would have almost broken many times.*
*So when I saw the harm from her and that I ... was in a town of land in which there is no squeezing [for water].*
*I cut for her from the side of the basin a drinking place ... small like the measure of the span or it is smaller.*
*When she started drinking in it, there was not for the meeting of ... her lips from it the measure of the span, a span.*
*And no bucket except the heel was its rope ... to the water, a strap and the braided rein.*
*So she sniffed and did not dislike, and nothing repelled her drinking ... from quenching, a turbid beaten water.*

Poem of Kuthayyir Azzah
The narrators said that Kuthayyir ibn Abd al-Rahman al-Khuza'i entered upon Abd al-Malik ibn Marwan, and Al-Akhtal was with him. He recited to him. Abd al-Malik turned to Al-Akhtal and said: "How do you see?" He said: "A Hijazi, mutilated, deceived. Let me slap him for you, O Commander of the Faithful." Kuthayyir said: "Who is this, O Commander of the Faithful?" He said: "This is Al-Akhtal." Kuthayyir said to him: "Why didn't you slap the one who says:
*Do not seek maternal uncles in Taghlib ... for the Zanj are more noble than them as maternal uncles.*
*And the Taghlibi, if he clears his throat for hospitality ... scratches his ass and quotes proverbs.*
Al-Akhtal fell silent and did not answer with a letter.
They said: Abd al-Malik mentioned poetry one day and said: If the saying of Kuthayyir ibn Abd al-Rahman:
*So I said to her: O Azz, every calamity ... if the soul is settled for it one day, becomes easy.*
were in war, he would be the most poetic of people. And if the verse of Al-Qutami:
*They walk easily, so the buttocks are not lagging.*
were in the description of women, he would be the most poetic of people.

They said: Kuthayyir was asked one day: Are you more poetic or Jamil? He said: Rather, I am. It was said: Do you say this while you are his narrator? He said: Yes, because he says:
*May Allah throw mote into the two eyes of Buthaynah ... and into the white of her teeth, breakers.*
And I say:
*Wholesome, palatable, without a lingering disease ... for Azzah is what she permitted of our honors.*

And this is the poem of the verse:
*My two friends, this is the trace of Azzah, so hobble ... your two young camels, then weep where she settled.*
*And touch dust that had touched her skin ... and a shade and a house where she spent the night and stayed.*
*And do not despair that Allah forgives you two ... sins if you pray where she prayed.*
*For she swore an oath by what Quraysh sacrificed to ... on the morning of the two narrow passes and said Talbiyah.*
*I call you, as long as the pilgrims perform Hajj and say Takbir ... at Fayfa Ghazal, a company, and raise voices.*
*And she was, regarding cutting the rope between me and her ... like one vowing a vow, she fulfilled so she became lawful [to break it?].*
*So I said to her: O Azz, every calamity ... if the soul is settled for it one day, becomes easy.*
*And no human met from love a prime ... that is general, nor a blind one except it cleared.*
*As if I am calling a rock when she turned away ... from the hard rocks, if the white-footed goats walk on it they slip.*
*And my passion for you, O Azz, if you knew it ... is like the passion of a thirsty bird that went astray from water.*
*Turning away, so she does not meet you except stingy ... so whoever became bored of that connection, she became bored.*
*She permitted a sanctuary people did not graze before her ... and settled in valleys not settled before.*
*Would that my young she-camel was at Azzah's, tied ... with a weak rope, she deceived it so she fled.*
*And her saddle was left in the resident tribe ... and she had a seeker other than me, so she recovered.*
*So who is for an eye that does not see the peaks of the sanctuary ... nor the mountain of Al-Awshal except it pours?*
*Persistent when it flows, disobedient when it weeps ... equal whether it was little in weeping or much.*
*And when we ascended in an ascent of passion ... to ranks from which I was hated and became weary.*
*I was like the diseased woman whose disease returned ... at the time the two callers said: She recovered.*
*And I was like the possessor of two legs: a sound leg ... and a leg Time shot in it so it became paralyzed.*
*And I was like the one with a rib, when she bore ... on her rib after stumbling, she rose.*
*I want the stay at her place and I think she ... if we prolong the stay at her place, becomes bored.*
*I wished for her until when I saw her ... I saw deaths, filled, having overshadowed.*
*And nothing deceived me except a book she wrote ... so would that my right hand before that had been paralyzed.*
*The swine tasks her with insulting me, and she has no ... desire to humiliate me, but for the owner she submitted.*
*Wholesome, palatable, without a lingering disease ... for Azzah is what she permitted of our honors.*
*So by Allah, I did not approach except she distanced ... for cutting off, nor did I increase except she decreased.*
*So if it is goodwill, then welcome and hello ... and goodwill was due for her with us, but it was little.*
*And if it is the other, then behind us are ... lands, if I task the white camels with them, they tire.*
*My two friends, indeed Al-Hajibiyyah has exhausted ... your two young camels, and my she-camel has become tired.*
*So let not a connection to Azzah become distant, which has become ... in the end, its causes have turned away.*
*Do evil to us or do good, neither blamed ... with us nor hated if she hated.*
*But bestow and remember from an affection ... for us, a friendship that was with you so it remained.*
*For I, even if she turned away, am praising and truthful ... regarding her in what she slipped to us.*
*And I am not invoking destruction upon Azzah ... nor gloating if Azzah's sandal slipped.*
*May destruction strike him who wishes destruction for you ... and may those who said 'Azzah went mad' go mad.*
*Let not the slanderers think that my ardor ... for Azzah was a flood then it cleared.*
*I have become recovered from a sickness with her ... just as a thirsty woman was sickened then recovered.*
*So by Allah, then Allah, no one settled after her ... nor before her from a friendship where she settled.*
*And no day passed over me like her day ... even if other days were great and majestic.*
*So oh wonder for the heart, how is its acknowledgement ... and for the soul when it was settled, how it submitted.*
*And for the eye are flocks whenever I remember her ... and for the heart is anxiety if the eye became bored.*

*And I and my wandering in love for Azzah after ... I abandoned what was between us and she abandoned.*
*Am like the one hoping for the shade of a cloud, whenever ... he settled in it for a nap, it vanished.*
*As if I and she are a cloud of a drought-stricken one ... he hoped for it, but when it passed him, it poured.*

Poem of Jamil Buthaynah
They mentioned that Kuthayyir ibn Abd al-Rahman said: Jamil ibn Abdullah ibn Ma'mar, who is Abu Umayr, said to me: Go to Buthaynah and take a promise from her for me. I said: When was your last meeting with her, and is there a sign between you and her? He said: My last meeting with them was while they were at Wadi al-Dawm washing their clothes. He said: So I came to them and found her father sitting in the courtyard. I greeted and he replied. I conversed with him for an hour until he asked me to recite poetry. So I recited to him and said:
*So I said to her: O Azz, my companion sent ... despite the distance of the abode, and the entrusted one conveys.*
*That you make an appointment between me and you ... and that you command me with what I do in it.*
*And the last covenant from you was the day you met me ... at the bottom of Wadi al-Dawm while the garment was being washed.*
He said: When Buthaynah heard, and she was behind her father in that curtain of hers, she struck the side of the tent with her palm and said: "Scram!" Her father said to her: "What is it, O Buthaynah, what is wrong with you?" She said: "A dog comes to us when people sleep from behind this hill." Kuthayyir said: So I returned to Jamil and informed him that she promised him behind the hill when people sleep.
Jamil only needed someone to convey for him because of what Abu Ubaydah narrated. He said: Buthaynah's people complained about Jamil to Mu'awiyah, so he made their blood lawful (permitted killing him) and said: If you catch him near it, I have wasted his blood for you (made it unretaliated). So Jamil was warned and stuck to greeting [from afar], and began sending the sign with the slave girl and the shepherd and the rider he trusts. Therefore he says:
*Buthaynah said: You do not care about our separation ... Yes, by your grandfather, indeed I do care.*
*Do you not see me, because of the crime of her love ... walking in smooth armor, tucking up my shirt.*

And the Poem:
*What stirred your longing from the decay of ruins ... at Al-Barq, a passing of east wind and a passing of north wind.*
*The north wind played with its novelty and struck it ... the star of Arcturus with a pouring, heavy rain.*
*The violent winds dragged their tails in it ... the dragging of women the excesses of trails.*
*So they revealed dark [stones], their era is old ... and they remained for epochs of years.*
*And I remembered a quarter our families settled in ... when we were in circles there, settling.*
*We stop the talk if we fear a hater ... and we hide when we fear with proverbs.*
*Until our family separated on an intention ... of casting [far], and our family announced departure.*
*They departed, so soft ones like dolls departed ... white of faces, swaying in the thickets.*
*The service of slave-girls around them, and they handed ... with their palms the reins of the camels.*
*They went with the piebald [camels], others complain ... the violence of the driving, lifting the tails.*
*They put Aqarih all on their right ... and the hills of Burqat As'as on the left.*
*And I looked so my tear overflowed after ... the litters passed and were veiled by a mirage.*
*The width of Al-Jabajib from Uthal as went ... the heavy ships, pushing with weights.*
*Is it every possessor of grief you knew his place ... you forget his affection, and I am not forgetting?*
*Without proximity, there is not in distance ... except the brief visit, and not much connection.*
*Buthaynah said: You do not care about our separation ... Buthaynah was ignorant, indeed I do care.*
*And the criminals, out of fear and devotion ... drive every noble, swift she-camel.*
*Forcibly, as if their eyes from the night travel ... and from fatigue are the flows of water-trickles.*
*Indeed I conceal her love while some of them ... regarding whom he loves is like the seeker of lost camels.*
*O Buthayn, do you know how much you tasked me ... of hamstringing a swift she-camel and the war of clients.*
*And traversing the desert, its Jinn play music ... after the calm, with a sturdy, fast she-camel.*
*And I have indicated to your cousin a pregnant [war] ... from our war, mangy, possessing shackles/thirst.*
*A war whose practice distresses the weak ... conceived upon barrenness and length of non-conception.*
*Do you not see me, because of the crime of her love ... walking in smooth armor, tucking up my shirt?*
*The rust of iron is on my shoulders as if I am ... a black [camel] covered in pitch/tar.*
*O would that the pleasure of our life returned to us ... in the like of an era that has passed, empty.*
*So we sell days that passed in the past ... short, for days that followed, long.*
*And when the enemy, his news are belied ... and when the advisor is believed in sayings.*
*From every sociable woman, as if her fangs ... are hail of a falling place of a meadow, often settled.*
*Pouring like the morning cloud of Al-Salm, its ascent runs ... over the Rajajah from thick, heavy [clouds].*
*Whoever you give it to, I am closer to what he missed ... of her, even if she did not reward him with a gift.*
*And fleshy ankles appeared and a lean flank ... the sash roamed upon it every roaming.*
*And a buttock, full, and a leg, plump ... white, silencing the speech of the anklet.*
*Until when the darkness mixed and tempted me ... consolation won, and they are not reducing/sparing.*

News of Majnun Layla
They mentioned that Kuthayyir entered upon Abd al-Malik, who said to him: Recite to me something you said about Azzah. He said: Rather I recite to you what I praised you with. He said: I ask you by the right of Abu Turab [Ali], that you recite to me your poetry about Azzah. He said: You asked me by a right upon me that is great. So he began reciting to him while his eyes were shedding tears. Abd al-Malik said: How strong is your love for Azzah! Have you ever seen anyone whose love was stronger than yours? He said: I inform you, O Commander of the Faithful: I went out, and longing stirred in me, and remembrance of Azzah. They had sought pasture near the tribe for a time. I passed by a man who had set a trap for himself, isolated from the tribe. I turned to him and said: Is there any hospitality? He said: I am isolated from the tribe, and I have set my ropes, so be patient a little, I will drive the gazelles towards you. If something falls into the ropes, we eat together, for I have not tasted anything for three [days]. So he went to drive. A dark, long-necked doe fell into his trap. He hastened towards her, and I was where I could see and hear. He began wiping the dust from her, then released her and reset the rope and came to me. I said: O you, have you seen anyone do your deed? We both complain of hunger, until when Allah brought relief, you made us destitute of our provision? He said: Woe to you, I looked at her and at her eyes, so I likened her to the one I love. Have you seen one who eats the likeness of his love? He recited saying:
*O likeness of Layla, do not fear, for I ... am today, among the wild beasts, a friend to you.*
*I say, having released her from her bond ... You are free for the sake of Layla, if she gave thanks.*
Then he said: Stay, for if something falls we eat. So I stayed hoping that hunger would prevent him from returning to the like of his deed. A gazelle fell into his trap. He strove towards it, released it, and it ran. He recited saying:
*O likeness of Layla, if you stayed an hour ... perhaps my heart would recover from its passion.*
*And not that you resembled her then did not return ... safe; I am compassionate for her in life.*
I said: Woe to you, hunger has exhausted us. And I left him, knowing that he is mad with love. Then I passed by gazelles grazing. I said: If I guide him to them, I hope he drives them, and his knowledge that it is my game prevents him from releasing what falls into his trap of them, so he eats and feeds me. I returned to him and said: Do you not see those gazelles still, grazing? He said: Far be it! I saw Layla grazing in this meadow and playing. And I said:
*I saw gazelles grazing in the middle of a meadow ... and I used to see Layla, so I became soft for them forever.*
*So O gazelle, eat luxuriously, happily, and do not fear ... for I am a neighbor to you even if you feared forever.*
Then he went and left me. This, O Commander of the Faithful, is the most loving lover I saw. He said: Who do you think he is? He said: Al-Majnun Qays ibn al-Mulawwah, and he is from Banu Amir ibn Sa'sa'ah. Among what he intended of his poetry in the confusion of his mind is his poem:

Poem of Majnun Layla
*I remembered Layla and the past years ... and days we did not fear a transgressor against the amusement.*
*So I said, and I did not control: O Ka'b ibn Amir ... because of a love at Dhat al-Raqmatayn, it appeared to me.*
*When we traveled at night and you were before us ... your memory sufficed as a guide for our riding camels.*
*A fire of longing was kindled in my heart, so there became ... for it a blazing flame in my heart.*
*It is magic, except that for magic there is a ruqyah (cure) ... and I do not find a curer for what is in me.*
*And you two told me that Tayma is a home ... for Layla when the summer casts the anchors.*
*So these months of summer have passed ... so what is with distance throwing Layla to the throwing-places?*
*The two sons of Kulayb blame you regarding her foolishly ... so would that passion, O sons of Kulayb, was in my place.*
*And if a slanderer, his house in Yamama ... and my house in the highest of Hadramawt, he would be guided to me.*
*And what is for them, may Allah not beautify their preservation ... of luck, in cutting off Layla my ropes.*
*If I were blind striking the earth with a stick ... deaf, and she called me, I would answer the caller.*
*And I go out from between the sitters, perhaps I ... talk to the soul about you, O Layla, alone.*
*And you are the one who, if you wished, made my life miserable ... and if you wished, after Allah, blessed my mind.*
*And indeed I seek to faint while I have no slumber ... perhaps a phantom of you meets my phantom.*
*If my eye applies kohl with your eye, I do not cease ... in good, and a flood clears from my heart.*
*If I traveled in the open land, you see me ... cajoling my saddle to lean towards my side.*
*May Allah water neighbors of Layla, the distance cast ... them until they occupied the Matali (places).*
*I exchanged for your gift, O Umm Malik ... whispers of worry attending my pillow.*
*For indeed that which I hoped for, O Umm Malik ... turned my back-head gray and infatuated my heart.*
*So two days: a day in the company, muddied ... and a day I race the running winds.*
*I count the nights, night after night ... and I was for a time not counting the nights.*
*If Time folds you, O Umm Malik ... then the affair of the decreeing deaths is my affair.*
*My two friends, if the turns of nights circle upon ... Umm Malik, then seek an announcer of death for me.*
*And do not leave me, neither for a hastened death ... nor for survival, you two looking at my remaining.*
*My two friends, no by Allah, I do not control weeping ... if a flag from the family of Layla appeared to me.*
*My two friends, no by Allah, I do not control what ... Allah decreed regarding Layla nor what He decreed for me.*
*He decreed her for another and tested me with her love ... so why not with something other than Layla did He test me?*
*My two friends, if they depart with Layla, prepare ... for me the bier and shrouds and ask forgiveness for me.*
*I testify before Allah that I love her ... so this is for her from me, so what is from her for me?*
*Is Layla beaten for my visiting her ... and taken as a sin for her that she sees me?*
*Right if she was right, and if she was ... left, passion disputes me regarding my left.*
*I see myself when I pray, I turned ... my face towards her, even if the prayer place was behind me.*
*And I have no polytheism, but her love ... is the place of the grief, it baffled the treating doctor.*
*I love of names what agreed with her name ... and resembled it or was close to it.*
*And no namesake of hers from the people ... was mentioned to me except my tear wet my cloak.*

News of Layla al-Akhyaliyyah and Tawbah ibn al-Humayyir
They mentioned that Tawbah al-Humayyir al-Amiri is one of the famous lovers of the Arabs. He was brave, a raider. His companion was Layla al-Akhyaliyyah the poetess. About Tawbah she says:
*I swore I will weep after Tawbah, a dead one ... and care about whom the circles [of calamities] circled upon.*
*By your life, there is no shame in death for the youth ... if shames do not hit him in life.*
She entered upon Abd al-Malik after she aged. He said to her: What did Tawbah see in you when he loved you? She said: What the people saw in you when they appointed you. Abd al-Malik laughed until a black tooth he used to hide appeared.
They mentioned that Tawbah traveled to Syria. He passed by Banu Udhrah, and Buthaynah saw him. She began looking at him. That was hard on Jamil. He said to him: Who are you? He said: I am Tawbah ibn al-Humayyir. He said: Do you want to wrestle? He said: That is up to you. Buthaynah threw a dyed sheet to him, so he wrapped himself in it. Then he wrestled him, and Jamil threw him down. Then he raced him, and Jamil outstripped him. He said: O you, you only do this by the wind (spirit/presence) of this one. But descend with us to the valley. They descended, so Tawbah threw him down and outstripped him.
Tawbah used to see Layla veiled. Then her brothers ordered her to inform them of his coming so they could kill him. So she unveiled to warn him. When he saw her unveiled, he knew that was due to an event, so he turned away. Regarding that he says:
*I used to, whenever I came to Layla, she veiled ... so her unveiling to me in the morning made me suspicious.*

And the Poem which belongs to Tawbah ibn al-Humayyir
*Her house distanced you with Layla, you do not visit her ... and her destination became far and her rope twisted.*
*And her destination lightened from the south of Unayzah ... just as its quiver lightened from the arrows of the archer.*

'And you are the one who, if you wished, made my life miserable... and if you wished, after Allah, you blessed my state. Indeed, I seek to be covered [in sleep] though I have no drowsiness... perhaps a phantom from you might meet my phantom. If my eye is anointed with your eye [seeing you], I cease not... in goodness, and it clears a flood [of grief] from my heart. If I travel in the open land, I see myself... coaxing my saddle to lean towards my direction. May Allah water neighbors of Layla; the distance... has tossed them until they occupied the ruined dwellings. I have exchanged your gift, O Umm Malik... for whispers of worry that attend my pillow. For that which I hoped for, O Umm Malik... has turned my side-hair gray and captivated my heart. So two days: a day in the company of people, muddy... and a day I race the running winds. I count the nights, night after night... while for a time I used not to count the nights. If Time folds you away, O Umm Malik... then it is the affair of the decreed deaths and my affair. My two friends, if the vicissitudes of nights turn against Umm Malik... then seek for me a mourning announcer. And do not leave me, not for a hastened death... nor for a survival where you await my remaining. My two friends, no, by Allah, I do not control the weeping... if a sign from the family of Layla appears to me. My two friends, no, by Allah, I do not control what... Allah decreed regarding Layla nor what He decreed for me. He decreed her for another and tested me with her love... so would that He had tested me with something other than Layla. My two friends, if they depart with Layla, then prepare... for me the bier and shrouds, and seek forgiveness for me. For I witness before Allah that I love her... so this is for her from me, so what is from her for me? Is Layla beaten because I visit her... and is it taken as a sin for her that she sees me? An oath, if it was a right hand (oath), and if it be... a left hand, passion disputes me regarding my left. I see myself, when I pray, I turn... my face towards her, even if the prayer-direction is behind me. There is no polytheism in me, but her love... is in the place of a choke; it baffled the treating physician. I love of the names what matches her name... and resembles it or was close to it. And no namesake of hers was mentioned before me... from among the people, except that my tears wetted my cloak.' News of Layla al-Akhyaliyya and Tawba ibn al-Humayyir. They mentioned that Tawba al-Humayyir al-Amiri was one of the famous lovers of the Arabs. He was brave and a raider. His companion was Layla al-Akhyaliyya, the poetess. Regarding Tawba, she says: 'I swore I would weep for Tawba, dead... and I would care for the one whom misfortunes turned against. By your life, there is no shame in death for the youth... if shameful deeds did not afflict him during life.' She entered upon [Caliph] Abd al-Malik when she was old. He said to her: 'What did Tawba see in you when he loved you?' She said: 'What the people saw in you when they appointed you.' Abd al-Malik laughed until a black tooth he used to hide appeared. They mentioned that Tawba traveled to the Levant and passed by the Banu Udhra. Buthayna saw him and kept looking at him. This distressed Jamil. He said to him: 'Who are you?' He said: 'I am Tawba ibn al-Humayyir.' He said: 'Do you want to wrestle?' He said: 'That is up to you.' Buthayna threw him a dyed sheet, so he wrapped himself in it. Then he wrestled him, and Jamil threw him down. Then he raced him, and Jamil beat him. He said: 'O man, you only do this by the wind (spirit/presence) of this woman. But descend with us to the valley.' They descended, and Tawba threw him down and beat him. Tawba used to see Layla veiled. Then her brothers ordered her to inform them of his coming so they could kill him. She unveiled her face to warn him. When he saw her unveiled, he knew it was due to a new event, so he retreated. Regarding that he says: 'And I used to, whenever I came to Layla, she would veil herself... so her unveiling this morning made me suspicious.' The Poem belonging to Tawba ibn al-Humayyir: 'Her abode has distanced Layla from you; you do not visit her... and her destination has become remote and her rope twisted. Her destination has lightened from the south of Unayza... just as a quiver lightens of the arrows of the archers. Men said: "Her distance does not harm you."... Nay, everything that thins the souls harms them. Does it not harm the eye that it repeats the weeping... and its sleep and joy are prevented from it? I see the day coming without Layla as if... a year and its months came without Layla. For every meeting we meet there is a smile... even if I visit her every day for a year. My two friends, go gently, rightly guided, for... Dariyya and its yoke have come between [me] and the beloved.'

*And men said: Her distance does not harm you ... Yes, everything that thins souls harms them.*
*Does it not harm the eye that it returns weeping ... and its sleep and joy are prevented from it?*
*I see the day come without Layla as if ... a Hajj year and its months came without Layla.*
*For every meeting we meet there is joy ... even if it was a year, every day I visit her.*
*My two friends, go in the evening guided, for there came ... Dariyyah before the beloved, and its yoke.*
*My two friends, there is no hour you stop in ... of the night except a like of it we travel.*
*And needs may go, the youth seeks them ... scattered, and the soul fears what does not harm it.*
*And I used to, whenever I visited Layla, she veiled ... so her unveiling to me in the morning made me suspicious.*
*And avoidance I saw from her made me suspicious ... and her turning away from my need and her frowning.*
*If Layla were in the peaks of a fortress ... in Najran, its palaces would not wrap against me.*
*It delights my eye to see the white camels striving ... with us towards Layla while her braids run.*
*Layla showed us the basins of death and pleased us ... eyes, pure of sides, she turns them.*
*O pure friend of the soul, how do you say it ... if an expelled fearful one sought her protection.*
*I think good of her and I know that she ... will be gracious one day or her captive will be ransomed.*
*And she said: I see you today black, pale ... and where is the whiteness of the face? The heat dragged it.*
*And changed me, if you were blaming my change ... mid-day heats I do not shade from, and their prisoner.*
*If there was a day of hot wind, I walk it ... and her curtains fall short of the hot wind.*
*O pigeon of the belly of the two valleys, sing ... May the rainer of the white morning clouds water you.*
*Clarify to us, may your feathers not cease to be soft ... and may you not cease in a green [tree], abundant its freshness.*
*And Layla claimed that I am a libertine ... for myself is its piety or upon me is its debauchery.*
*So say to Uqayl: What is the talk of a group ... enemies surrounded it, its helper is far.*
*If they do not desist, the horses will be ridden between us ... and galloped with a leg or a wing that flies them.*
*Perhaps you, O goat leaping in a rope ... are Layla's punisher that she sees me visiting her.*
*And a dark [she-camel] from the secrets of the Mahri camels as if she is ... a doe of a herd, other than what her saddle touched.*
*Of the Na'bat (fast ones), walking a Na'b pace as if ... her rein is tied to a trunk of Arak.*
*Of the 'Arkarkiyyat (strong ones), a lean camel as if she is ... a rope of fiber, its twister tightened it strongly.*
*I crossed with her the middle parts of every desert ... its destruction is feared when its dust flows.*
*The weak of the people appear in it as if they are ... tadpoles of water whose pond dried up from them.*
*And the lion of the night which is between its half ... and Isha, its captive is doubted.*
*The multitude of enemies refused that they avoid ... my dogs until their biting ones are provoked.*
*And he does not complain of my ignorance, but my equipment ... you see its sharpening slow against my enemies.*
*Is the doubt of death snatching me while I have not visited ... virgins from Hamdan, white their throats.*
*Rising with heavy buttocks and shanks ... plump, and small feet, their waists.*

News of Suhaym, Slave of Banu al-Has-has
They narrated that Abdullah ibn Abi Rabi'ah al-Makhzumi wrote to Uthman ibn Affan, may Allah be pleased with him: I have bought for you an Abyssinian slave, a poet, so look if you want him. He was presented to him. He said: He is the slave of Banu al-Has-has, who is Ibn Nufathah ibn Sa'd ibn Asad from Asad ibn Khuzaimah ibn Mudrikah. The slave's name is Suhaym. They said: Yes, he is a poet who is desired. He said: I have no need for him, because the poet has no sanctity. The share of the slave poet from him, if he is satiated, is to compose love poetry about their women, and if he is hungry, to satirize them. And he returned him.
They said: So a man bought him. When he departed with him, he recited saying:
*Is it longing while no more than a night has passed ... so how if the riding camels travel with us a month?*
*And I did not fear Malik would sell me ... for anything, even if his fingertips became empty.*
*Your brother and the client of your wealth and your ally ... and who has strengthened among you and lived with you an age.*
When this poetry reached them, they returned him and honored him. He remained among them for a period, until they found him composing love poetry about their women. So they agreed to kill him. They took him while he was drinking, drunk. A woman of them mocked him while he was in that state, gloating over him. He said:
*If you mock me, then oh how many a night ... I made you in it like the slit tunic.*
They said: And the one they accused him with passed by. He extended his hand to her, so they struck him. He said:
*If you kill me, you kill me while there has flowed ... for her sweat upon the bed and water.*
So they tightened the bonds of the slave for killing. He said:
*Tighten the bonds of the slave, let him not escape you ... Indeed life is close to death.*
*And sweat has descended from the forehead of your girl ... upon the back of the bed, and perfume.*
So he was killed. They said: And he had recited to Umar ibn al-Khattab, may Allah be pleased with him:

*Bid 'Umayrah farewell if you prepared departing early ... Gray hair and Islam are sufficient as a forbidder for a man.*
Umar said to him: If you had put Islam first, I would have rewarded you. He said: By Allah, I did not sense (*sa'artu*). He means: I did not feel/realize (*sha'artu*). He also said to him: If all your poetry were like this, I would have improved your reward. When he reached his saying:
*And we spent the night, our pillow to an 'Aljanah (tree) ... and a sand dune, the winds rocking it a rocking.*
He said: You are killed. So he was killed.

The Poem:
*Bid 'Umayrah farewell if you prepared departing early ... Gray hair and Islam suffice as a forbidder.*
*Madness for her, in what we associated, a relationship ... a relationship of love, hidden and apparent.*
*Nights she hunts hearts with coal-black [hair] ... you see it thick, soft of growth, covering.*
*And a neck like the neck of the white antelope, not bare ... of pearls and ruby and beads, adorned.*
*As if Pleiades was hung above her upper chest ... and ember of Ghadha, the wind blew it glowing.*
*When she rushed in a thin cloth and a black garment ... and wrapped the top of the head with a Yemeni cloak.*
*She shows you on the morning of separation a palm and a wrist ... and a face like the Dinar of the mighty ones, pure.*
*And no egg which the male ostrich spent the night surrounding ... and lifting a chest from it, distancing.*
*And placing it between the wing and his side ... and she spreads for it a thick [bed] of feathers, fulfilling.*
*And he lifts from it while it is white, moist ... and has faced a horn of the sun, exposed.*
*Is more beautiful than her the day she said: Are you going ... with the riders or staying with us for nights?*
*If you stay you do not own, and if you become departing early ... take provision and depart from 'Umayrah satisfied.*
*And whoever's love does not remain despite distance ... then 'Umayrah has provided a remaining love.*
*Convey from me to her, may Allah prolong your life O youth ... by the sign of when she came to us swaying.*
*The swaying of a torrent in soft valleys ... when it ascended a hard ground it branched into a valley.*
*And we spent the night, our pillow to an 'Aljanah ... and a sand dune, the winds rocking it a rocking.*
*She pillows me a palm and bends with a wrist ... upon me and bends her leg from behind me.*
*So she returned and did not fulfill what she came for ... and of the need of the human is what is not fulfilling.*
*So my cloak did not cease to be good-smelling from her clothes ... for a year until the cloak wore out, old.*
*I turn her to the two sides and protect ... with her [against] the wind and the cold drizzle from my left.*
*And the North wind blew on us with cold ... and no garment except her gown and my cloak.*
*She gave me a drink on a thirst for water ... May Allah give her drink of the golden morning clouds.*
*O valley which its torrent joined ... to us the intention of the beautiful one, may you be greeted as a valley.*
*Oh would that we and the Amiriyyah meet ... seeking for our families the past meadows.*
*And a trace of her did not cease at the monastery ... and at Al-Jaww until nights dunged it.*
*If you accept with love, I accept with the like of it ... and if you turn away, I go to a worn-out state.*
*Did you not know that I am little of need ... if a thing is not for a thing a protector.*
*And I did not come to her seeking healing by a look ... so I saw her, except I returned with my disease.*
*Nor did the star by which one is guided rise ... nor the morning, until they stirred the memory of my wealth.*
*Except for the dust of the departing [camels] in the evening ... until the Gathering I call the beautiful women.*
*They took the path to Al-Miqrat or to its right ... when I said they refrained, they made a driver dismount.*
*Is it longing while no more than a night has passed ... Gently with passion until it passes nights.*
*And they did not come until he who wished settled and built ... and they said: We passed you and they were first ones.*
*And they came from the furthest houses visiting me ... Indeed some of the visitors are my disease.*
*They gathered from various [places], three and four ... and one, until they completed eight.*
*And they said: O you all, play as long as no slumber ... overcomes us, for we have prolonged the distancing.*
*They played in a leveled ground, fertile its sides ... and threw the cloaks from their sides.*
*And they said to a like of the white antelope: You are the most worthy of us ... to remove the veil when they wanted to reveal.*
*So she stood and threw the veil, coquettish ... the short black women ransoming her a ransoming.*
*They bent until I said: They are not calamities ... and they lowered my fear then he became staying.*

*And they did not leave until the tribe sent a caller ... and until the morning appeared which was following.*
*And until the dawn became clear, white, shining ... as if on its top were Syrian sheets.*
*So they turned back lowering the figures as if ... they killed a killed one or brought calamities.*
*And they became thrown in the houses as if ... they drank wine, not answering the caller.*
*O call in their traces the beautiful women ... they were given poisons to drink, what is for them and what is for me.*
*And my Lord showed them the like of what they showed me ... and heated the irons upon their livers.*
*And a sayer, while the tear descends her kohl ... Is this the one who makes the beautiful women weep out of passion?*
*She pointed with her comb and said to her peer ... Is it the slave of Banu al-Has-has driving the rhymes?*
*She saw a shabby saddle and an old cloak ... and a black one, of what people own, suffering.*
*They comb peoples and leave my hair ... and that is an apparent humiliation that has appeared to me.*
*If I were rose in his color, they would have loved me ... but my Lord shamed me with my blackness.*
*And it did not harm me if my mother was a slave girl ... tying and trimming the ties for the milch camels.*
*They went with my tooth-stick and threw a gilded ... of jewelry onto the smallest finger of my left hand.*
*So I consoled myself and avoided my error ... and brought close a lean one of the white camels, swift.*
*Going in the evening when the day fasted as if ... I clothed my saddle with a pure color, lean.*
*A bull whom the dogs avoided an avoidance ... he is the lion, attacked and attacking.*
*Protected him in the evening a night of cold ... in a soft sand or at Arnan, empty.*
*He stirs and reveals roots as if they are ... the reins of a cobbler, new and old.*
*He pushes dust from a sleeping place and a lair ... a pile like the house of the pharmacist, near.*
*So the archer from Al-Ghawth came to him in the morning ... with his dogs, inciting the trained dogs.*
*So he roamed on his off-side and you think him ... on his back a new Yemeni Sab (cloth).*
*He defends the defense of the five-day thirsty ones when appeared ... their fore-ones of dogs covering.*
*So leave this, but do you see the light of a lightning ... illuminating a accumulated cloud, rising high.*
*Its light illuminates the hills, the hills of Mutali' ... and how beloved is that lightning if it were near.*
*I enjoyed it in mind and became certain that it ... brings down the ibexes and the anchored rocks.*
*So the wind did not move it until I thought it ... at Harrat Layla or at Nakhlah, staying.*
*So it passed over the stream-beds and its rain became thick ... and it split [with rain] long, pouring the water quiet.*
*Accumulated, pouring the water after every milk-gathering time ... as you watered the hoof-injured, barefoot.*
*So it passed over the mountains, the mountains of Tayy ... and left at Al-Qa'yan turbid and pure [water].*
*Hoarse, rumbling, its torrent pushing ... you see the wood of the valleys floating in it.*
*It has separated ones giving birth around it ... bursting in the soft lowlands the burrows.*
*When it hung down to the mountains and their people ... and the people of Euphrates, it crossed the sea passing.*
*It complained its grief and raged until I thought it ... from the distance when the thunder rumbled, a camel driver.*
*So the bulls became drowned and became ... the women of Tamim picking up the horns.*

Ghazal Poem of Jarran al-'Awd al-Numayri
They said: Among the chosen preferred Ghazal poems is the poem of Jarran al-'Awd al-Numayri. He was nicknamed Jarran al-'Awd only because of his saying to his two wives:
*Take caution, O my two neighbors, for I ... saw the Jarran (front neck) of the old camel has almost become fit.*
Meaning a whip he cut from the Jarran of an old camel. Jarran al-'Awd was a flirt, a describer; he describes and exceeds in his amorous poetry. Among what he lied in is his saying:
*So there became, where we met, a spoil ... a bracelet and an anklet and a Mirt (garment) and a Mutraf (cloak).*
*And cut pieces of necklaces they left ... like the ember of Ghadha in some of what is snatched.*

The Poem
*I remembered youth so the eye poured shedding ... and the longing you used to know returned to you.*
*And my heart had sobered, then agitated it ... ash-colored pigeons at Medina, cooing.*
*As if the Hadil, limping of leg in their midst ... from oppression, is a heavy drinker, trilling, drained.*
*They remind us of our days at Suwayqah ... and the two hills of Qasas, and remembering excites.*
*And white women jingling the anklets as if they are ... foster-daughters of the virgin wild cows, familiar.*

*So I spent the night as if the eye is branches of a Sidr tree ... upon it is frost from the dew of the night dripping.*
*I watch a glimpse of Canopus as if it ... when it appears at the end of the night, blinks.*
*It appeared to Jarran al-'Awd while the sea is before it ... and a hunched one from the Sarawat of Himyar overlooking.*
*And there is no like of passion except the like of a day the white camels caught up ... with us, and the driver drives and is violent.*
*They caught up while the foam was as if it was ... in the hands of the Mahri camels and the noses, cotton.*
*And the white camels did not catch up with us until they multiplied ... with us, and the last lagging one followed us.*
*And the white Arhabi [camel] was as if he ... with his rider was a dark one from fatigue, dun-colored.*
*And in the tribe is one with inclined veil as if she is ... a doe in a spacious land of white gazelles, bending.*
*Stubborn ones of youth and intimacy, slender of the waist ... killer of passion if the abode helped.*
*As if their sweet front teeth and their saliva ... and a fragrance in it, wine mixed with them.*
*She infatuates the sturdy of the people until as if he is ... sick, the nursing women despaired of him, emaciated.*
*And a cloud at Najd is not closer than a formation ... upon it a shining [lightning] is revealed.*
*The seeing likener likens it to an egg ... which the clumsy male ostrich went early in the dew away from.*
*In a soft ground of Dhat al-Salasil, meets ... upon it from the 'Alqa plant a vegetation, first-growth.*
*And she said to us while the white camels are small from the nose-rings ... and their hooves throw the hard stones.*
*And they are leaning, listening as if ... shaved them from the pulling of reins a fodderer.*
*You were praised to us until some of us wished for you ... and you are a man whom praise visits and you are known.*
*High of rank in every east and west ... and that saying of yours is the enduring, received.*
*And in you when you meet us is arrogance ... many times, and she does not obey one who is arrogant.*
*The world sways with you and passion overcomes you ... as the soft sand dune, collapsing, sways.*
*And we are met as if we are a spoil you have gathered ... and you desire away from the abundant gift so you exceed.*
*So your appointment is the bank which is between our family ... and your family until you hear the rooster crowing.*
*And suffice you as traces of us where we meet ... tails we efface with them and a cloak.*
*And a dragging place of sheets over that and a gown ... fringes and a hem of it drive the pebbles.*
*So we become such that we are not sensed except that they ... upon every suspicion swear and we swear.*
*And the mother of the one who night-traveled with us said to them ... For them regarding night travel is more deliberate and weaker.*
*And if our mother witnessed us the night of Al-Naqa ... and the night of Rumh, she would have trembled when we tremble.*
*So when the night rose over us I came secretly ... to her appointment, ascending the hills and going behind.*
*I came from the side which they did not fear ... and my furthest side from fear is inclining.*
*And they approached walking slowly, swaying ... short of steps, of them is rising and crawling.*
*When we met they said: He has become empowered ... so let not this gentle visitor exceed.*
*And they said: Enjoy this night of Allah ... for you are stoned tomorrow or put to the sword.*
*And they secured from me every waist-band knot ... of theirs, and the decorated Nawfali fell.*
*So we spent the night sitting and hearts as if they were ... sandgrouse facing the traps from what is feared.*
*Upon us is dew at times, and at times sprinkles us ... a drizzle that traveled from the end of the night, pouring.*
*And we spent the night as if a perfume container spent the night with us ... of musk, or a wine weak of wind.*
*They dispute with us a delicious, soft [talk] as if it is ... raindrops of a rain the summer wind drove.*
*Thin of sides, if a monk heard ... at Butnan a saying like it he would remain trembling.*
*A speech that if the herbs were given the like of it ... the herbs would grow and the half-graying tree would turn green.*
*It is eternity in the world for whoever can handle it ... and a killing for the owners of ardor, instant.*

*And when they saw the morning they raced its light ... the pace of the sandgrouse of the valley or they are quicker.*
*So they caught up with ends of the night after ... the worshiper turning away established the prayer.*
*And they did not appear until they said: Would that we were ... dust, and would that the earth swallowed the people.*
*If we escape this and they do not sense us ... indeed some good was approaching then turned away.*
*So they became lying down in the chambers while between us ... are the spears of enemies and the feared side.*
*Every correspondent conveys to them the need ... long of the stick or a cripple crawling.*
*And a guarded, ash-colored one they do not lower her ... a correspondent who throws [at] the dogs and pelts.*
*She saw a white paper so she tightened her belt ... for it, so she is sharper than Sulayk and kinder.*
*And the white virgins like dolls will not be infatuated by ... a stupid one and a heavy sleeper of the night, of mixed lineage.*
*Nor a Jabala (heavy?), a shepherd, swollen of the sciatic nerve ... hairy of the nape, huge of the stick, drooping-eared.*
*An ally to the two skins of a large wooden bowl ... great of the blackness of figure and the wood is hollow.*
*But a companion in youth, swaggering ... light, quick, long of the tail, slender.*
*A youth of the tribe and guests if they descend at his place ... wary of the forenoon, playful, proud.*
*He sees the night in their needs as a spoil ... when the counterfeit stupid one sleeps from them.*
*He visits like the visit of the falcon to the sandgrouse ... and faster than it in snatching when he snatches.*
*And there became in where we met in the morning ... a bracelet and an anklet and a striped garment.*
*And cut pieces of necklaces they left ... like the ember of Ghadha in some of what is snatched.*
*And I became the singer of the forenoon, they have loved me ... with longing, and the curls of lovers excite.*

News of Al-Kumayt ibn Zayd and Nusayb al-Qurashi
They narrated that Al-Kumayt ibn Zayd recited to Nusayb al-Qurashi one day while he was listening to him, until he recited to him:
*And we have seen in it houris, soft ... white, coquetry and luster of teeth were complete in them.*
Nusayb bent his little finger. Al-Kumayt said to him: What are you doing? He said: I am counting your mistake against you. Do you not see how you distanced in your saying: "Coquetry and luster of teeth were complete in them"? Why didn't you say as Dhul-Rummah said:
*Dark-lipped, in her two lips is a dark color, gum-color ... and in the gums and in her canines is luster.*
Then he recited in another poem:
*As if the clamor of its running is ... the Rajaz poems of Aslam satirizing Ghifar.*
Nusayb said: Aslam never satirized Ghifar. So Al-Kumayt was ashamed and fell silent.

Poem of Dhul-Rummah
And he is Ghaylan ibn Uqbah ibn Buhaysh
*What is wrong with your eye, the water pours from it ... as if it is from kidneys pierced, leaking?*
*And a leather bucket from a Gharaf tree, its seams pierced by ... a pouring [water] wasted between them by the stitching?*
*Did the riders originate a news about their factions ... or did a joy return to the heart from its joys?*
*From a relic the East wind blew palm leaves from it ... as the books are spread after the sealing.*
*A flood of the sand dune covered its landmarks ... a crosswind drags its top so it is dragged.*
*Nay, rather it is the longing from a house, betrayed it ... a passing of clouds and a passing of a dusty hot wind.*
*Appears to your eyes from it, while it is old ... a trench and a worn-out fireplace and a wood-gathering place.*
*To signs of traces of tents ... as if they are sheaths embroidered, new.*
*By the side of Al-Zurq, its landmarks were not obliterated by ... the passers of dust and rains and eras.*
*The dwellings of Mayyah when Mayyah aids us ... and the like of her is not seen by non-Arabs nor Arabs.*
*Shining of the neck and the upper chest, clear ... as if she is a doe led to a wide space by a breast-collar.*
*Between the day and the night of a necklace ... on its sides are the lank hair and the eyelashes.*
*Large-buttocked, firm, slender-waisted, loose ... from her is the sash, and beauty and the cane were complete.*
*The adornment of clothes, and if her clothes are stripped ... on the mattress one day, the stripping adorned her.*
*She shows you the image of a face not base ... smooth, having no mole nor scar.*
*If the brother of the pleasure of the world lines it ... and the house above them at night is veiled.*
*She smelled with a good nose-tip, her nose ... with musk and Indian ambergris is dyed.*
*She increases in delight to the eye if she unveils ... and the eye is restricted in her when she veils.*
*Dark-lipped, in her two lips is a dark color, gum-color ... and in the gums and in her canines is luster.*
*Black-eyed in widenss, yellow [pure] in whiteness ... as if she is silver touched by gold.*
*And the earring in the free part of the ear-rear is hung ... the rope distanced from it so it shakes.*
*That girl whom you were attached to accidentally ... Indeed the noble and the possessor of Islam is snatched.*
*Nights amusement entices me so I follow it ... as if I am striking in a flood, playing.*
*I do not think Time wears out newness ever ... nor do branches divide a single branch.*

*The phantom of Mayyah visited a sleeper, played ... with him the deserts and the Mahri camels, the noble ones.*
*Stopping for rest in the whiteness of the morning, his stop ... and the rest of the travel except that is pulled.*
*A brother of deserts who dozed at a changing [she-camel] ... smooth of the side, from her chest-girth is a scab.*
*She complains of the nose-ring and the place of the two straps just as ... the sick man, his visitors are pain.*
*As if she is a camel of concern and nothing remained ... except the spinal muscle and the bones and the nerves.*
*She does not complain of a fall from her, while danced ... with her the deserts until her back is humped.*
*She trots with a torn shirt, swift ... like the sword when its companions changed color.*
*And the white camels of a walker at night or a trotter ... are pushed from her two sides while she is snatched away.*
*She inclines when he tightens her with the saddle, leaning ... until when he settles in her stirrup she leaps.*
*The leap of the wild ass from herds of a suspended [land] ... as if he is clear of doubt or a side.*
*Driving lean ones, similes, compact ... ash-colored of trousers, in their colors are streaks.*
*He has upon them at Al-Khalsa' a spring camp ... then the two Fudaj, then the two sides of Wahif are clamor.*
*Until when the intensity of summer blew on him ... with a heat, the water and the wet dates sizzled.*
*And the vegetation dried up by a moaning [wind] brought by ... a hot south wind, in its passing is deviation.*
*And he caught up with the remaining of his reservoir ... and of their reservoirs, and the run was sniffed.*
*Erected around him a day watching him ... are deserts, smooth stones in their bowels are domes.*
*Until when the horn of the sun yellowed or neared ... he entered evening and proximity was serious in his soul.*
*So he went swiftly driving his wives ... the nearest of his throwing is galloping and trotting.*
*He ascends the rugged grounds with them at times to tire them ... the resemblance of harm (a second wife), so fatigue does not harm him.*
*As if he, whenever his group scattered ... at the back, from his biting their croups is a dog.*
*As if they are camels a group escapes with ... from others who raided a raid of clamor.*
*And the concern is the spring of Uthal, disputes him not ... from his soul for other than it as a watering place a need.*
*So she went in the darkness and the pillar of morning is split ... from her, and the rest of it in the night is veiled.*
*A spring mossy of sides, overflowing ... in it frogs and fish clamor.*
*A stream initiates it like the sword, swift ... among the palm trees, the palm branches rose around it.*
*And on the lefts of Jallan is a hunter ... vile of clothes, hidden of person, lurking.*
*Prepared blue [arrows] he guided, rods chested ... smooth of backs, feathers and sinew drove them.*
*She was, when her likes trusted him ... then some of them from the thousands are branching off.*
*Until when the wild beasts in the lowlands of her watering place ... disappeared, a doubt from fear made her suspicious.*
*So she exposed, free, her necks in fear ... then the murmuring of the water pouring attracted her.*
*So the wild ass approached and the livers rising ... above the rib cartilages from her bowels beat.*
*Until when she slipped from every throat ... to the burning thirst and gulps did not satisfy it.*
*He shot and missed, and destinies are overcoming ... so they turned away and woe is his habit and war.*
*They fall at the foot [of the mountain] from what they saw of him ... a fall, the pebbles of the rugged ground almost ignite.*
*As if they are the secondary feathers of a masterful eagle ... the male bustard turned to outstrip him in the stony ground.*
*Is that or a speckled with embroidery, his shanks ... dark of the cheek, going early, energetic, young?*
*He summered in the sand until shook his succession ... the coming of the cold, there is no rank in his life.*
*Rabl plants and Arta trees, his braids exiled from him ... the stars of heat until the flames died.*
*He entered evening at Wahbayn passing his pasture ... from Dhu al-Fawaris, the Riba plants call his nose.*
*Until when she made him between her backs ... from the knots of sand, middles having streaks.*
*Darkness gathered its cloak on the wild one ... and a goer from the clouds of Aquarius pouring.*
*So he spent the night a guest to an Arta tree of a piled ... of the dune, having warmth and a veil.*
*Inclined from the mine of wild cows, distant ... their droppings on its targets are heaps.*
*And a changing [wind] from the dust of the year, its wandering ... around the mounds in its colors is grayness.*
*As if shook the loads a ink-well ... on its sides the mulberry and the grape.*
*As if it is the house of a perfumer including ... baskets of musk he contains and are plundered.*

*When a rain poured upon him, it scented ... the resting places of the wild cow until the wood was scented.*
*The lightnings reveal a crouching white one ... as if he is a wearer of a cloak, celibate.*
*And the rain flows from the top of his path ... the flow of pearls running in its string, the holes.*
*It covers the shelter with its two horns and demolishes it ... from the pouring sand, collapsing and pouring.*
*If he wanted to bury himself in it, appeared to him ... before the root, from its ropes a rope.*
*And a desolate, sharp one sensed a sound ... with the pulse of sound, there is no lie in his hearing.*
*So a dampness kept him uneasy and kept him awake ... the blowing of the wind and the whisper and the rain.*
*Until when a dawn cleared from his face ... his neck in the ends of the night is erect.*
*Darknesses of a full night, his visitor was ... the confusion of clouds until he has no opening.*
*He went early as if there were Jinn in him scaring him ... from all his sides he fears and watches.*
*Until when she has in the wall and took ... the sun of the day a ray between it are streaks.*
*And a bright one appeared, famous by his white mark ... as if he, when he ascends a barren tract, is a flame.*
*Hungry, blue-eyed, green ones were roused for him ... lean ones, starvation and the side emaciated them.*
*Drooping-eared, wide of jaws, trained ... like wolves, in their necks are the straps.*
*And a feeder of game, a gainer for his desire ... he found his father earning that earning.*
*Bare-headed, ragged of clothes, he has nothing ... but the hunting dogs and but their game, wealth.*
*So his wild side turned and they swooped ... stripping [flesh?], the sought and the seeking do not slow.*
*Until when they circled in the earth, returned to him ... a pride, and if he wished flight would have saved his soul.*
*A shame overtook him after his roaming ... from the side of the rope, mixed with it anger.*
*So he refrained from his sharpness, and the drooping-eared ones hear it ... behind the hair, from exertion wailing.*
*They wetted with him, neither reckless nor trembling ... when they roamed in a battlefield where destruction is feared.*
*So he returned snatching a stab in their chests ... as if he counts the reward in the advancing.*
*So at times he shakes the necks from the side ... a shaking, and the lungs and bubbles are pierced.*
*He leans to them the edge of a horn, he hollows with it ... a state, and pierces a state, a sharp spearhead, long.*
*Until when they were restrained by a penetrating [stab] ... and a dying one, and both his horns were dyed.*
*He turned shaking a defeat in their middle, lively ... joyous, the distresses have cleared from his fright.*
*As if he is a star in the track of a dust-colored ... marked in the blackness of the night, swooping.*
*And they are of a treader bending his intestine ... and a sobbing one, and the disobedient of the belly are bleeding.*
*Is that or a dyer (ostrich) in Al-Siyy is his pasture ... father of thirty, he entered evening returning.*
*Lean of the shanks, like the tent the rest of him ... of hair-cloth, huge, tall, thick.*
*As if his legs are two poles of 'Ushar wood ... two poles, the bark has not peeled off them.*
*A' and Tannum plants distracted him, and his sequel ... is of the apparent Marw stones, and the pasture has a consequence for him.*
*So he remained humble appearing so you deny him ... a state, and rising sometimes so he is attributed.*
*As if he is an Abyssinian seeking a trace ... or from tribes in whose ears are piercings.*
*Tall, went in the evening in a black velvety ... of velvet, the top of his garment is fringes.*
*Or a rushing one, the weakest of bellies saddled him ... yesterday, so the two sacks and the saddle delayed.*
*Two shepherds of Kalb lost him, returned ... from a seek, and the necks of the necks tremble.*
*So the young camel became alone from his companions ... seeker of sweet plants whose rear parts are bark.*
*Upon him provision and worn clothes and coverings ... the bag almost cut them from his back.*
*Each from the top view has a resemblance ... this and these two, the measure of the body and the scabs.*
*Until when the male ostrich entered evening, he sought his chicks ... and they are neither despairing distantly nor near.*
*He runs in the shadow of a quiverer and chases him ... the rustle of a wind whose front is gravel.*
*A bald, output, humble one vies with him ... so the desert before the daughters of the eggs is plundered.*
*As if she is a bucket of a well whose drawer strove ... until when he saw her, the rope betrayed her.*
*And woe to her a return, and the wind is violent ... and the rain is rumbling and the night is approaching.*
*They do not save a remainder from penetrating ... until the skins almost tear off them.*

*So whenever they descended from a limit their round ... of places, wonder is done with it.*
*They are not safe from the beasts of the earth or cold ... if they darken before children who have clamor.*
*They came from the eggs, scant-haired, having no clothes ... except the soft earth and a kind mother and a father.*
*So as if they were split from in a barren land ... skulls, dry, or colocynth, ruined.*
*From what cracked from crooked, bent ones ... as if a mange includes their skins.*
*Their mouth-corners like the cracks of Nab' wood in peaks ... like rounded stones, down has not grown in them.*
*As if their necks are leeks of a sandy ground ... its wraps flew, or Hyashar plant, stripped.*

News of Al-Farazdaq and the Ansari Boy
They narrated from Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Sa'd ibn Abi Waqqas, that he said: Al-Farazdaq ibn Ghalib ibn Sa'sa'ah came to Medina. He said: I, Al-Farazdaq, and Kuthayyir Azzah were sitting in the mosque reciting poetry to each other and mentioning the days of the Arabs. A boy appeared, slender, dark-skinned, in two reddish-yellow garments. He headed towards us until he reached us, did not greet, and said: "Which of you is Al-Farazdaq?" Ibrahim said: I said to him, fearing he might be from Quraysh: "And thus you speak to the master of the Arabs and their poet?" He said: "If he were so, I would not have said this to him." Al-Farazdaq said to him: "Who are you, may you have no mother?" He said: "A man from the Ansar, then from Banu al-Najjar, then I am the son of Abu Bakr ibn Hazm." He said: "I am Al-Farazdaq, so what is your need, may you have no mother?" He said: "It reached me that you claim you are the most poetic of the Arabs, and Mudar claims it. Our companion Hassan ibn Thabit has said poetry, so I wanted to present it to you, and give you a year for it. If you say the like of it, then you are the most poetic of the Arabs, otherwise you are a lying plagiarist." Al-Farazdaq said: "Bring it, woe to you." So he recited to him the saying of Hassan:
*Did you not ask the new quarter that spoke ... at the flow of Ashdakh then the sandy ground of Azlam.*
*We have the white bowls shining in the forenoon ... and our swords dripping blood from bravery.*
*Whenever we are weighed from Ma'add against a group ... and Ghassan, we prevent our basin from being demolished.*
*Our doing of good refused that we speak obscenity ... and our sayer of kindness except generosity.*
*We begot Banu al-Anqa' and the two sons of Muharraq ... so how noble we are as maternal uncle and how noble is this as a son.*
Until he came to the end of the poem, and said: "I have given you a year in it." Then he left. Al-Farazdaq stood up angry dragging his cloak, not knowing where its end was, until he exited the mosque. He turned to Kuthayyir Azzah and said: "May Allah fight the Ansari! How eloquent is his dialect and how clear his argument." He said: We did not cease in their talk for the rest of our day. Until when it was tomorrow, I went out from my house to the mosque, and sat in the gathering I was in yesterday. Kuthayyir came to me and sat with me, and we were remembering Al-Farazdaq and saying: Would that I knew what Al-Farazdaq did. Suddenly he appeared to us in a suit of striped cloth, having two locks of hair, until he sat in his place of yesterday. Then he said: "What did the Ansari do?" We criticized him and insulted him. He said: "May Allah fight him! I have never been pelted with his like, nor heard the like of his poetry ever.
