I parted from you two and came to my house, and began ascending and descending in every art of poetry, so I was as if I were silenced, never having said poetry. Until when the Muezzin called for Fajr, I saddled my she-camel, then took her rein and led her until I came to Dhubab. Then I called at the top of my voice: Answer your brother Abu Lubayna. So my chest boiled as the cauldron boils. I hobbled my she-camel, then pillowed on her arm. When I stood up, I said one hundred and thirteen verses." While Al-Farazdaq was reciting, the Ansari appeared. He approached us until when he reached us, he greeted then said: "Behold, I did not come to you to rush you from the deadline I set for you, but I loved not to see you except I ask you what you did." Al-Farazdaq said to him: "Sit, may you have no mother." Then he recited to him:
*You abstained at A'shash and you almost did not abstain.*
When he finished it, he said to him: "You have heard, may you have no mother. So you and what you heard." The Ansari stood up dejected. When he disappeared, his father, Abu Bakr ibn Hazm, appeared to us in a group of Sheikhs of the Ansar. They greeted us and said: "O Abu Firas, you have known our state and our place from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, and his recommendation of us. It has reached us that a fool of our fools exposed himself to you with what we, by Allah, hate, and with you and from it we are above. We ask you by Allah for what you preserved of the recommendation of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, regarding us, that you gift us to him, and that there be nothing from you that does not befit you." Ibrahim said: So I and Kuthayyir began speaking to him, and people from the sides of the mosque spoke: "O Abu Firas." When they increased upon him, he said: "I have gifted you to this Qurashi," meaning Ibrahim ibn Muhammad.

The Poem, poem of Al-Farazdaq

*You abstained at A'shash and you almost did not abstain ... and you denied of Hadra' what you used to know.*
*And abandonment persisted with you until as if ... you see death in the house you used to be familiar with.*
*A persistence of cutting off, not connection, indeed ... the brother of connection is who approaches and is gentle.*
*When Hadra' woke up from the sleep of forenoon ... she called, and upon her was a shift of silk and a cloak.*
*With a green [stick] from Nu'man, then she polished with it ... the front teeth called a scent when sipped.*
*And shying ones of hearts as if they are ... wild cows around their newborns turning.*
*You see them from excess of shyness as if they are ... sick of consumption or perishing bleeding women.*
*If they drop the speech [speak], it is as if it is ... the harvest of bees or the first of vine picked.*
*Preventers of secrets except to their people ... and they fail what the drying jealous one thought.*
*And they grant after despair without suspicion ... conversations that heal the sick ones and infatuate.*
*When the black Qunbudhat (women?) circled in the forenoon ... the curtained canopies slept over them.*
*And if the maids woke them after ... the day of summer ascended or almost reached half.*
*They called for branches of Arak which ... the riders gathered for them from Nu'man the days they stood at Arafat.*
*So they wiped with it sweet saliva, its edges ... are thin, and the top where it was fixed is lean.*
*They wore the Khosrowani sword-sheath under it ... signs of the striped silk of Iraq.*
*So how about an imprisoned one who called me while before him ... are paths and doors and a palace elevated.*
*And reddish-bearded ones planting their spears ... they have shields under the upper spears arranged.*
*And trained [dogs] that nothing passed but they shared it ... upon them a wader to the suspicion, rushing.*
*Conveying to us from her without her speech ... to us from the palace, the dyed fingertip.*
*I called the One whose hands leveled the heavens ... and Allah is closer than my jugular vein and kinder.*
*To distract her husband from me with a chronicity ... that bewilders him from me and from her so she aids.*
*With what is in our hearts of worry and passion ... so the broken of heart, the sick one heals.*
*So He sent into his eyes water that covered them ... and they knew that I am more medically skilled and knowing.*
*So I treated him for two years while she was near ... I see her and she approaches me often so I sip.*
*The extract of a eyelid mixed with it a leftovers ... on her lips and the musk mixed.*
*Oh would that we were two camels, not arriving ... at a settled tribe except we are driven and pelted.*
*Both of us have mange whose infection is feared ... upon the people, coated with tar, scabbed.*
*In a land empty alone, and our clothes ... are of thin cloth and brocade, a shift and a wrap.*
*And no provision except two leftovers of extract ... and white from the water of the cloud, wine.*
*And remains of meat of bustards hunted ... if we wished, by a companion familiar.*
*We have what we wished of life as long as ... cooing doves called a mate at Nu'man.*
*To you, Commander of the Faithful, threw us ... the worries of wishes and the desert traveled blindly.*
*And a time bit, O Ibn Marwan, it did not leave ... of wealth except erased or swept away.*
*And swaying of upper arms, reddish-white, as if ... upon them from fatigue is the pounded saffron.*
*They rose with us from the sword of the sand of Kuhaylah ... and in them are remnants of vigor and arrogance.*
*So they did not reach until their step became short ... and their humps perished and the toe-pads were bleeding.*
*And until the slow driver walked driving them ... they have a bloody skin-abrasion and a peeled back.*
*And until we killed ignorance from them and they were sunken-eyed ... when they were made to kneel and the tears were shedding.*
*And until we sent them and there was nothing in a hand of theirs ... when a rope was untied from them, and they were shackled.*
*If we showed them the reins they approached ... us with the heat of cheeks turning away.*
*If untied from them, fought from their backs ... large camels like crescents, lean.*
*They crossed with us what is between Yabrin, its width ... to Syria, hills and plains meet them.*
*So their wading with us the night annihilated the joy of the Da'iriyyah ... when the wrapped heavily-clothed one slept.*
*When the horizons of the sky turned dusty and tore ... the covers of the houses of the tribe a strong wind, cold.*
*And the stallion of the milkless camels came before their young ... hurrying, and she went in the evening after him while she was hurrying.*
*And every Dhafrah (strong camel) tore the tent ropes ... having a high hump from the shoulder of fat, maned.*

*And her shepherd touched the fire with his chest ... and his palms the heat of the fire, not turning away.*
*And the dog of the tribe fought for the fire of his family ... to lie in it while the fire is surrounded.*
*And the whiteness of frost became as if it was ... on the backs of the old camels, teased cotton.*
*And Sirius kindled its fire with the night ... and its skin became barren, peeling.*
*I found the moist earth in us when the earth dried ... and he who hopes for his favor, the guest.*
*You see our neighbor among us giving protection even if he committed a crime ... so he is not harmed by what harms the neighbor.*
*And our master defends, even if he was distant ... with us, his neighbor from what he fears and disdains.*
*And we used to, if Kulayb slept from hospitality ... walk to the guest with fresh meat and cover.*
*And the neighbors have known that our pots ... are guarantors of provisions while the wind is whistling.*
*We hasten for the guests in the drought with hospitality ... pots with fresh meat extended and ladled.*
*Emptied into wooden bowls as if their basins ... are basins of cisterns, of them full and half-full.*
*You see around them the seekers as if they are ... upon an idol in the Jahiliyyah, retreating.*
*Sitting, and behind the sitters are their halves ... standing, and their hands are frozen and dripping.*
*And no ignorance untied the waistbands of our forbearing ones ... nor is the speaker of good among us scolded.*
*And no stander of us stood in our club ... and spoke except with that which is more known.*
*And I am from a people by whom enemies are warded off ... and mending of the rift and the feared side.*
*And guests of a night, we transferred their hospitality ... to them, so we destroyed deaths and they destroyed.*
*We hosted them and the polished white [swords] before it ... The Ayzani and the straightened [spear] pour the veins.*
*And released [horses] like locusts, driving them ... a strong one, the folded hide strengthened him.*
*So the displaced of them became where we met ... killed and bound of hands and killed instantly.*
*And we used to, if the guest was forced by hospitality ... the upper spears came to him while they bled with poison.*
*And we do not rest the horses until we return them ... so our enemies know them while they are returning.*
*Likewise our horses were once seen ... fat, and sometimes they are led so they become lean.*
*Upon them from us are the breakers of their vengeances ... and they with the burdens of death are saddled.*
*Sharp until they come to the screamer who ... called while he is at the frontier which is most fearful.*
*And a pot, we cooled its boiling after it boiled ... and another we stoked with upper spears used as trivets.*
*And all the hospitality of guests we serve from spears ... and an envied one, his humped camel is cut.*
*We found the mightiest of people the most of them in number ... and the most noble of them who is known by noble deeds.*
*And both of them are in us for us when we meet ... bands, the announcer met between them.*
*Dismounting from the back of the few is our many ... when the possessor of wealth, the followed, calls.*
*We peeled the pebbles from him which are on his back ... with the dreams of ignorant ones when they frowned.*
*Upon a revolution until as if its mighty one ... was thrown from between two peaks a cliff.*
*And ignorance with forbearance, we raised its madness ... and it would not have been, were it not for our might, removed.*
*We outweighed them until they regained their dreams ... by us after the spears were breaking.*
*And women were extended with their hands and there was not ... for a possessor of lineage from his people a lagger.*
*We sufficed them what befell them with our dreams ... and our wealth, while the people with white swords were approaching.*
*And the strings directed the notches of their arrows ... and the fangs of their fools ground from rage.*
*So no one among people equals our push ... with might, nor has he might when we incline.*
*Corners are heavy upon him, heavy ... like the corners of Salma or mightier and thicker.*
*Ours is the unyielding might and the number which ... upon it, if the pebbles are counted, swears.*
*Of the superior, veiled from him is his tongue ... he surpasses, and the sick surrounded one protects him.*
*And if the sick dogs drank our blood ... it would heal them and the possessor of madness who is sicker.*
*He will know, who rivaled Tamim when fell ... its legs in the sea, who lags behind.*
*For Sa'd is the mountains of glory and the sea is Malik ... so neither does Hadan wear out nor is the sea drained.*
*We have, where the horizons of creation meet ... the number of pebbles and the Qaswari (Lion), the Khandafi.*
*And of us is the one in whose presence people do not speak ... but he is the one asked for permission, the served.*

*You see them sitting around him and their eyes ... lowered their sights, not turning.*
*And two houses: The House of Allah, we are its guardians ... and a house at the top of Ilya' (Jerusalem), honored.*
*When the people descend Al-Muhassab from Mina ... the evening of the Day of Sacrifice from where they stood at Arafat.*
*You see the people, as long as we march, marching behind us ... and if we signal to the people, they stop.*
*And there is no might but our might is conqueror of it ... and the humiliated asks us for justice so he is treated justly.*
*Thousands of thousands of men and of spears ... and horses like the prime of locusts and rough ground.*
*If Darim gathers for me at a goal ... I ran to it the run of one who is proud.*
*And if they are tempted one day, we strike their heads ... upon the religion until the reconciled one accepts.*
*For you, when you strive to overtake Darim ... you are indeed the suffering, O Jarir, the burdened.*
*Do you seek from the heaven its place ... with saliva and a donkey whose back is peeled?*
*And two Sheikhs who have screwed eighty years ... this large and lean one came to them.*
*Refused for Jarir a clan of evil, humiliated ... and a mean honor stopped for shames.*
*And a mother, her womb settled from Atiyah ... with the matter her womb was absorbing.*
*I turned the war upon you, for I am, if slackened ... the brother of war, a returner against the peer, turning.*
*If Umamah stripped her shift from her ... and pleased her a raised [belly] to the stomach, high.*
*Short, as if the Turk in it are their faces ... strangling to the necks of rats, exposed.*
*She says, and struck the heat of my two cheeks, angry ... at the husband, burning, she does not cease to sigh.*
*Is there not from Kulayb, if he has no ... two female donkeys, one who is rich and does not refrain?*
*If a female donkey went away from me with my husband ... there is no regret for the wind of the Kulaybi.*
*For the wind of a slave who did not come like what came ... a worshiper nor from the people of Maysan, uncircumcised.*
*She weeps for Sa'd, and Sa'd is residing ... at Yabrin, she almost fainted over the people.*
*And Sa'd is like the people of the Dam, if opened upon them ... they would surge as locusts surge and circle.*
*For they balance the earth; were it not for them, it would meet ... upon the people or almost move and be blown away.*
*And if Sa'd came from their land ... the nights would come to Yabrin crawling.*

Jarir's Answer
So Jarir ibn Atiyah ibn al-Khatafa answered it. It is said that Jarir is the starter, and the first is more likely, because of what Jarir used to say that he never satirized except answering and victorious.
The narrators mentioned that Jarir came to Basra during the emirate of Al-Hakam ibn Ayyub ibn al-Hakam ibn Abi Aqil, the deputy of Al-Hajjaj. He said praising Al-Hakam:
*You came from Najran or the two sides of Khaym ... on young camels like the ropes of Salam trees.*
*Their bellies were folded the folding of leather ... digging a digging like the lost of servants.*
*If they crossed a landmark, a landmark appeared ... until we reached the door of Al-Hakam.*
*The deputy of Al-Hajjaj, not the accused ... in the mine of glory and the center of generosity.*
He recited it to him and spoke about him. His wit and poetry pleased him. So he wrote to Al-Hajjaj: That a Bedouin, a calamity, a devil of the devils, came to me. He wrote back to send him to me. So he came to him, and he honored him, clothed him, and lodged him. He stayed for days, then he sent for him after his sleep. The messenger said: Answer the Emir. He said: I will wear my clothes. They said: We were ordered to bring you to him in the state we find you in. So his mind went. He was wearing a thick shirt and a dyed sheet. When a man of the messengers saw what was with him, he said: No harm on you, the Emir only called you for conversation. Jarir said: When I entered upon him, he said: "Well, O enemy of Allah, you insult the honors of people." I said: "May Allah amend the Emir, indeed I, by Allah, do not wrong them, but they wrong me so I defend myself. What do I have, may Allah amend the Emir, with Ibn Umm Ghassan? And what do I have with Al-Ba'ith? And what do I have with Al-Farazdaq? And what do I have with Al-Akhtal? And what do I have with Al-Taymi?" He said: "I do not know what you have with them." I said: "I inform the Emir. As for Ghassan ibn Dhuhayl, he is a man from my people; he satirized me and my clan, and he was a poet." He said: "So what did he say to you?" He said: I said: He said to me:
*By my life, if Bajila was adorned by ... Jarir, indeed her Jarir has disgraced Kulayb.*
He said: "So what did you say to him?" He said: I said:
*If only I knew about Sulayt, did not ... Sulayt find other than Ghassan a neighbor to protect her?*

He said: "Then Al-Ba'ith, what do you have with him?" I said: "He intercepted for Ghassan preferring him over me." He said: "Then Al-Farazdaq, what do you have with him?" I said: "He helped Al-Ba'ith against me." He said: "So what did you say to him?" He said I said:
*Men from Tamim wished destruction for me ... and no defender defended their honors like me.*
*As if they do not know my positions ... and they have tested that I am the preceding, the tester.*
*If my people wished, my forbearance would be among them ... and my ignorance would be upon the ignorant of their enemies.*
*And they claimed that Al-Farazdaq is a snake ... and no one killed snakes like my killing.*
He said: He kept saying: "Then who?" So I informed him and recited to him until the morning dawned, and we rose. He who was sitting with him informed me that he said: "May Allah fight him as a Bedouin! He is indeed a pup of rough fighting."

And his contradictory poem (*Naqidatuhu*)
*O merry, burdened heart ... wake up, perhaps your passion becomes distant and aids.*
*I remained, while you were informed that I am not anxious ... for a quarter at Salmanin, your eye shedding tears.*
*With my family were the people of the house when they inhabited it ... and a spring and summer rain was generous to you from a house.*
*I heard the ash-colored pigeons in the splendor of the forenoon ... at Dhu al-Ramth from the valley of Al-Maradin cooing.*
*So I was like the one with the stuffed skin (camel), she knows its scent ... and bends over it at times then turns away.*
*Do you claim that separation does not excite the youth ... Yes, like my separation on the day of Lubnan excites.*
*And long was my caution of the alienation of separation in distance ... and a story from a hater tracking.*
*And if Umamah knew my knowledge she would have belied ... the saying of him who transgresses against me and is violent.*
*I looked in front of me a look led by passion ... and the jaws of the Mahri camels on the day of Usfan trembling.*
*You see the sturdy, strong she-camel, her soles bleed ... and she is given shoes while the toe-pads bleed.*
*We extended for the Possessor of oppression until were cut ... her walks and the fed Shadqami camel.*
*They kicked the pebbles of the desert until their eyes ... are sunken, their sights shedding.*
*As if dwellings between the humps of Al-Naqa ... and between the hills of Al-Nahizah are a Mushaf.*
*And I am not forgetting what a pigeon sang ... nor what stayed between the wings, whistling.*
*Dwellings of the tribe whom I loved ... the time of hospitality and the screaming distressed one.*
*Upon them from the Maziy (armor) is every ample ... smooth one, having a fortified tail and fringe.*
*And Mujashi' did not witness the Day of Al-Ghabit ... nor Dhu Nujub the day the spearheads bled.*
*Did you not see that Allah disgraced Mujashi' ... when the definer gathered the groups of pilgrims.*
*The riders of the pilgrims spoke about their neighbor ... when they descended from the two Nakhlahs and hurried.*
*For indeed the disciple whose rope you deceived ... for him the moon is dull and the stars are eclipsed.*
*And the day of Mina Quraysh called out about your neighbor ... and the day of gifts they were at the rituals retreating.*
*And a sayer: What is with Al-Farazdaq not seen ... upon age dispensing nor abstaining.*
*And you ceased not to be stopped at every shame ... and you are at the house of shameful deeds, stopped.*
*Did you not see that the Nab' wood hardens its stick ... and it is not equal to the breaking castor oil plant.*
*And the root of the Kuzum is not equal to a Saw'ar ... and the possessor of the crown under the banner bearing a sword.*
*You knew for us the white predecessors before you ... and your two smiths had the lagging silence.*
*Our horsemen are the Protector and the frontier is before them ... and our followers are the Given and the Served.*
*Do you equate a cave whose forts are not sought ... with a collapsing cliff, its side breaks.*
*I wondered at an in-law relationship that drove you, family of Dirham ... to the in-law relationship of smiths, blamed and boasted of.*
*Two mean ones: This one Ibn Dirham claims her ... and this is the son of a smith whose skin peels.*
*And you opposed them for baseness, O family of Dirham ... the opposition of Christians to the religion of the Hanif.*
*They say: Nay, the smith has no conqueror ... Yes, indeed the striking of the smith with the smith is known.*
*You were gentle with the two bellows, O smith of Mujashi' ... and you are more violent in shaking the Mashrafi sword.*
*And the smith of Mujashi' mentions the shaking of the sword ... and the bound vessel knows his palms.*
*May Allah curse him whose sword is blunt in his hand ... and him who enters the whorehouse in the anklet, shackled.*
*If you were of us, O Farazdaq, it would not be blunt ... but the pure iron, thin, would have passed.*
*For you are the sons of the weak one, your striking is known ... and your mothers are wide of feet and Khaydaf (?).*

*Brother of baseness as long as the Ghadha is around 'Ajlaz ... and as long as a curved one is watered in Ramadayn.*
*Is it baseness and silence upon every shame ... and there is no turning away for shames from Qufayzah?*
*May Allah curse Layla, the wife of Sa'sa'ah who ... loves Bashar the smith, and the smith is generous.*
*I am the son of Banu Amr and Sa'd and Malik ... I am the son of the core, not of Washiz (mixed) who allied.*
*If Amr struts behind me and the masters of ... Banu Zayd meet, rising and turning away.*
*Tamim protects whoever protects the sanctuary for it ... and he protects Tamim who knows that for him.*
*So the client of Tamim when he seeks shelter with them ... even if there is the wealth of might in them, is treated justly.*
*Banu Malik, the smiths brought a mongrel ... to a predecessor running and not burdening himself.*
*And I did not forget from Sa'd at Quswan a scene ... nor Al-Adma as long as the eye blinks.*
*The dwellings of Banu Sa'd, and no Sa'd after them ... were effaced except dunes at Yabrin playing music.*
*And Sa'd, if the enemy shouted at their herd ... refused to calm down for the shouting so they marched.*
*Do you praise Sa'd when the voice of Sa'd disgraced ... Mujashi' while the tent was thick?*
*If the vanguards of Sa'd rode their horses ... and the horsemen of Sa'd, the earth remained trembling.*
*If you tasted from us the taste of a bitter war ... we turned the war upon you and the war turns.*
*You dodge, and they have disgraced you in every place ... as the monkey of the Harrah dodging dodged.*
*And the smiths have known that their girl ... was humiliated in riding every state that turns.*
*So you are not fulfilling with Al-Zubayr and his saddle ... nor are you fair with Al-Saydan in the tribe.*
*And the curtain of the House hates the smith of Mujashi' ... and its doorkeepers and the circumambulator staying.*
*And the bet was extended for the smith so he returned him ... from glory, a dull one from Qufayrah, mongrel.*
*And the guests do not praise the aid of Mujashi' ... if a moaning wind of the night went in the evening, cold.*
*If the milkless camels came and the stallion before them ... and they are small of humps, lean.*
*We bite the armored kings with our swords ... and your side from the blower of the bellows is more crooked.*
*Do you praise Sa'd after you spent the night seeking refuge ... and Ja'than spent the night crawling at Al-Niyatil.*
*And she spent the night behind the riders of Minqar, they galloping her ... so her rear, the ridden, was lost among them.*
*And they tasked her with the sand, the sand of Mu'abbir ... she says: Is this the walking of angry ones, snatching?*
*And they returned her at dawn as if ... Ja'than had a fever from the fever of Medina.*
*And they skinned with thrusting the skin of her perineum ... so a sore in her buttock almost did not peel.*
*And witnesses what they bloodied for Ja'than, a delivery place ... and the glans of the mongrel Minqari witnesses.*
*And there was in what flowed of the sweat of her buttock ... a clarification, and the scraped kneecaps.*
*Did you not see how Taym shoots Mujashi' ... strong of the ropes of the two catapults, casting.*
*The pilgrims of the House exiled you from every ritual place ... as the possessor of two bad coins, the counterfeit, turned back.*
*And when they saw the two eyes of Jubayr belonging to Ghalib ... Jubayr of adultery, the recognizing, made clear.*
*For Ja'than at Al-Saydan, they know him ... skinning places of her that do not perish and a dragging place.*
*And if he settled in Banu Sa'd, the straying [camels] ... from the belly of Al-Hawari would not have disobeyed, bleeding.*
*Banu Minqar dragged the girl of Mujashi' ... and Ibn Dhayyal attacked while your horses stopped.*
*Why did you not scold, O sons of the foam of her buttock ... vultures that saw his limbs so they stopped?*
*And they left the daughter of the smiths as if ... the remainder of what they left is a hollow hyena den.*
*And she spent the night calling Ghalib as if she was ... at the heated stone from the embers of stoves, being heated.*

News of Al-Ra'i Al-Numayri
They mentioned that Al-Ra'i, who is Ubayd ibn Husayn ibn Jandalah ibn Qatan al-Numayri, came to Abd al-Malik complaining to him about the charity collectors. He recited to him:
*So repel injustices that have impoverished our sons ... from us, and save our eaten limb.*
*And if I remain, I will surely call for a stab ... that leaves the obligations at Al-Shurayf few.*

Abd al-Malik said: "And where is Allah and the Sultan, may you have no mother?" He said: "O Commander of the Faithful, from an agent to a hastener, and a collector to a collector." So he did not obtain anything from him, as Abd al-Malik was heavy of soul towards him due to his people's siding [with Ibn al-Zubayr], and all of Qays was Zubayrid. It was said that Al-Ra'i had some of Uthman's camels. So he returned to him the next year and recited to him:
*As for the poor man whose milch-camel was ... sufficient for the family, he left no fur for him.*
*And the possessor of wealth became deficient, and the rich, there remained ... upon the hardships from their wealth, knots.*
*If you raise a head by them, you revive them ... and if they meet the like of it next year, they spoil.*
Abd al-Malik said: You are this year more intelligent than you were last year.

The First Poem:
*What is with your side on the bed, humbled ... is there a mote in your eye or did you want a departure?*
*When she saw my sleeplessness and the length of my turning ... at night and my connected night.*
*Khulaydah said: What befell you, and you were not ... after sleep, about tears, an asker.*
*O Khulaydah, indeed your father, two worries hosted his pillow ... they spent the night as a side and an intruder.*
*They knocked, so those are my concerns, I entertain them ... with young camels, pregnant like bows, and yearlings.*
*High of withers, their upper arms inclined ... reddish-white, resembling Shadqam and Jadil.*
*Hawoziyyah, folded upon their breaths ... the folding of bridges, they have split [teeth] a splitting.*
*Their elbows were built upon a slippery place ... the tick cannot find a resting place in it.*
*They were noble camels of Mundhir and Muharriq ... their mothers, and their stallions knocked them.*
*So as if their untamed one, when you eased her ... was accustomed to the saddle, submissive.*
*And as if there butted on their chests ... mountain goats at Shabwah that completed and wailed.*
*The casting of the morning when they go early for a need ... the crawling of the evening when they want a return.*
*Led [camels] measuring the distance of every desert ... the measuring of weavers, twisted and unraveled.*
*In a wasteland their heads were anxious in it ... the anxiety of axes when they want removal.*
*So if the desert presented itself, it left ... dust-colored [ostriches] trotting behind it a trotting.*
*Loud of song, as if in his chest ... are reeds, and persuasive of yearning, hasty.*
*And when the forenoon dismounted, she cast him ... so they outstripped his sequel, so he remained trotting.*
*They follow a fast-handed, brisk she-camel ... she cast a fetus in the crossing of winds.*
*She came with a possessor of a last breath of six months ... he had died or choked on life a little.*
*She shook off her armor with a black [tail] for the evening ... the shaking of the ostrich its wet feathers.*
*They do not take, when they ascend a desert ... except the whiteness of the two Farqads as a guide.*
*Until they arrived at the completion of five, passing ... very much, the spears inherited it, heavy.*
*Stagnant [waters], if the buckets sought their drops ... they encountered overlooking the water-source, holes.*
*They gathered ropes from what their saddles contained ... diverse of origin, you see in them a connector.*
*So they watered thirsty ones hearing in the evening ... for the water in their bellies a jingling.*
*Until when the buckets cooled their panting ... and they placed under their girths a remainder.*
*And they flowed after their refraining with a cud ... from Dhu al-Abariq when they grazed Huqayl.*
*They sat on their saddles so there followed ... the clamor of the echo, the mutilated of peaks, a walker.*
*Smooth of pebbles, she spent the night listening above it ... to the noise of sandgrouse at the two banks, descending.*
*Until when the darkness cleared and she turned ... she saw wild beasts grazing in trackless lands.*
*And the mirage ran and attached their rears ... a rope whose falling would be a loosening.*
*And it ran on the hump of the stones so they chased it ... the chase of the stolen herd in Al-Samawah, long.*
*Convey to the Commander of the Faithful a message ... a complaint to you, overlooking, and a wailing.*
*From a distant one, his worries multiplied upon him ... if he could find a way to the meeting.*
*The turning and Time were long, and he was suspicious of ... laziness, and he hates to be lazy.*
*Worries hosted his pillow and avoided ... a quenched one who becomes heavy in sleep.*
*So he folded the heart on the decree of a determination ... sharp, and took resolve as a friend.*
*And gray hair topped his peers, and eras have passed ... undoing his twisted rope.*
*As if his bones are hooks of Nab' wood ... crooked, old, for they wanted emaciation.*
*Like the iron of the Indian sword, its sheath became ... worn, and it was not in the bones recoiling.*

*Its iron is boiled and denies its color ... an eye that saw it in youth polished.*
*Indeed I swore a righteous oath ... I do not lie to the Caliph today in speech.*
*I did not visit the family of Abu Khubayb obediently ... a day wanting a change for my allegiance.*
*Nor did I come to Nujaydah ibn Uwaymir ... hoping for guidance, so he increases me in error.*
*From the grace of the Merciful, not from my trick ... indeed I count Him having favors upon me.*
*And I hated every fluctuating hypocrite ... who found earthquakes [seditions] his religion, defective.*
*Weak of trust, his young she-camel does not cease ... among the Kharijites, shaking and trotting.*
*From all of them he entered evening visiting a church ... the wiping of palms taking turns on the handkerchief.*
*O Caliph of the Merciful, indeed we are a group ... Hanafis (monotheists), we prostrate morning and evening.*
*Arabs, we see for Allah in our wealth ... the right of Zakat sent down a revelation.*
*Indeed the collectors disobeyed you when you sent them ... and came with calamities, if you knew, and a ghoul.*
*They wrote the dark calamity of enmity against an honored ... enemy wanting treachery and fraud.*
*The treasure of the bag, if you encompassed his news ... you would have left of him a separated limb.*
*They took the Arif (monitor) and cut his chest ... with whips while he stood shackled.*
*Until when they left no meat on his bones ... nor for his heart an intelligence.*
*They came with their deed and a hunchback ... from whom the whips left a reed, fleeing.*
*He forgot the trust out of fear of pregnant camels ... stubborn, they left his goods cut off.*
*They took his load-camels so he became sitting ... unable to move from the dwellings.*
*He calls the Commander of the Faithful while before him ... is a desert in which the winds drag tails.*
*Like a hoopoe the archers broke his wing ... calling on the middle of the road a 'Hadil'.*
*The spring fell and its step became close ... and he saw in his courtyard a slipping offspring.*
*Like the smoke of a hasty one at the top of a hill ... hungry, he kindled wet Arfaj wood.*
*Clear of flanks, in him is a resemblance ... bitten of the chest, you think him hobbled.*
*O Caliph of the Merciful, indeed my clan ... their grazing herds entered evening apart, so were it not for.*
*A people upon Islam, they would not prevent ... their kindness and waste the Tahlil.*
*They arrived at Yamama driving as if they were ... a people who hit wrongdoers with a dead man.*
*Driving humped, leaning [camels], their nobles ... in every near distance leave a group.*
*Until when she was detained, she picks her ways ... and the shepherds bent her sifted small plants.*
*The two months of Rabi', their milch-camels do not taste ... except sourness, indigestion, and withered plants.*
*And Yahya came to them and tightened upon them ... a covenant the Muslims see as heavy.*
*Books that left their rich possessor of need ... after richness, and their poor emaciated.*
*So I left my people dividing their affairs ... Is it to you or do they wait a little?*
*You are the Caliph, his justice and his judgment ... and if you wanted punishment for a wrongdoer.*
*So repel injustices that have impoverished our sons ... from us, and save our eaten limb.*
*So you see the gift of that, if you gave it ... from our Lord a favor and from you abundant.*
*Indeed those whom you commanded to be just ... did not take a wick of what you commanded.*
*They took the pregnant camels from the young camels forcibly ... unjustly and they are written for the Emir as young camels.*
*And if I remain safe, I will surely call for a stab ... that leaves the obligations at Al-Shurayf few.*
*And if Quraysh kindled their fires ... and bent grudges between them and vengeances.*
*Then your father is their master and you are their strongest ... in the time of earthquakes, roaming in earthquakes.*
*And your father fought in Medina alone ... a people, they left the whole scattered.*
*They killed Ibn Affan the Caliph while he was refraining ... and he called, and I have not seen the like of him, forsaken.*
*So their staff split from that day ... into pieces and their sword became drawn.*
*Until when the dust of a blind sedition descended ... its writing was done.*
*Umayyah weighed its affair and called for it ... one who was not inexperienced nor unknown.*
*Marwan is the most prudent of them when the hardship of ... matters befalls him, and the best of them when asked.*
*The days he raised his tail in Medina ... and he indeed sees crops in it and palms.*
*And dwellings of a king which a sedition ruined ... and a lofty palace in which the pigeon is shading.*
*The times of my people and the community were like what ... necessitated the saddle to incline an inclination.*

News of Ka'b ibn Zuhayr

They narrated that Ka'b bin Zuhayr bin Abi Sulma Al-Muzani wrote to his brother Bujair—who was in Medina with the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him), having preceded him in converting to Islam and finding guidance—scolding him with these verses:

'Who will convey a message to Bujair from me? ... Woe to you! Is what I said acceptable to you?
You drank from a cup with the family of Muhammad ... And the Trusted One [Al-Ma'mun] gave you a first and second drink from it.
So you opposed the reasons of guidance and abandoned it ... To what thing—woe to other than you—did he guide you?
To a nature upon which you found neither a mother nor a father ... And upon which no father of yours was found.'

They said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said: 'Indeed, he found neither his father nor his mother upon it.'

Bujair answered him, saying:
'Who will convey to Ka'b: Is the path acceptable to you ... Which you blame falsely, while it is the most prudent?
To Allah alone—not Al-Uzza nor Al-Lat ... You will be saved, if there is to be salvation, and be safe.
On a Day when no one will be saved or escape ... From the Fire, except the pure-hearted Muslim.
For the religion of Zuhayr is nothing but distinct from it ... And the religion of Abu Sulma is forbidden to me.'

Ka'b had insulted the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) in some of his poetry. When the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) returned from the conquest of Ta'if, he intended to kill those among the polytheist poets who used to hurt him, such as Umayyah bin Khalaf, Ibn Al-Zib'ara, and Ka'b bin Zuhayr.

So Bujair sent word to him: 'Take caution and save yourself by fleeing the land, for he has intended to kill those who hurt him with their poetry, unless you come to him as a repentant Muslim.'

Ka'b went to the Muzaynah tribe, but they refused to shelter him. He proceeded until he reached Medina and stayed with a man he knew. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) passed by, and the man said, 'This is the Messenger of Allah; go to him and ask for security.' Ka'b went to him until he sat before him, placed his hand in the Prophet's hand—and the Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him) did not recognize him—and said: 'O Messenger of Allah, Ka'b bin Zuhayr has come to ask for your security as a repentant Muslim. Will you accept it from him if I bring him to you?' He said, 'Yes.' Ka'b said, 'I am, O Messenger of Allah, Ka'b bin Zuhayr,' and he recited to him:

The Poem of Ka'b bin Zuhayr:

'Su'ad has departed, so my heart today is lovesick ... Enslaved after her, unransomed and shackled.
And what was Su'ad, on the morning of separation when they departed ... But a gazelle with a nasal twang, with lowered eyes heavily organized with kohl.
She reveals side-teeth of distinct darkness when she smiles ... As if it is a watering place mixed with wine.
Mixed with cold water from a bend in the valley ... Clear, in a pebbled riverbed, which the north wind has chilled.
The winds banish floating debris from it, and it is overfilled ... By the downpour of white passing clouds.
Oh, what a friend she would be if she were true ... To her promise, or if advice were accepted [by her].
But she is a friend in whose blood is mixed ... Pain, deception, breaking promises, and fickleness.
She does not remain in a state she is in ... Except as the Ghoul changes colors in her clothes.
She does not hold to the vow she claimed ... Except as sieves hold water.
So let not what she wished and promised deceive you ... For hopes and dreams are misleading.
The consequences of Urqoub were a proverb for her ... And her promises are nothing but falsehoods.
I hope and expect that her affection will draw near ... But meant for them throughout time is no attainment.
Su'ad has ended up in a land that cannot be reached ... Except by noble, swift, thoroughbred she-camels.
And nothing will reach her except a strong she-camel ... That trots and paces despite fatigue.
From every sweater behind the ears; when she sweats ... Her intersection implies a road whose markers are obliterated and unknown.
She looks at the unknown with the eyes of a solitary white oryx ... When the rocky terrain and the milestones burn with heat.
Huge is her neck, sturdy are her fetlocks ... In her creation, she surpasses the daughters of the stallion.
A lean camel, whose brother is her father from a noble sire ... And her uncle is her maternal uncle; long-necked and swift.
The tick walks upon her, then slips ... Off her due to a smooth chest and smooth flanks.
An onager-like camel, flesh is thrown off her sides ... Her elbow is twisted away from the ribs of the chest.
It is as if what lies between her eyes and her throat ... From her nose and jawbones is a pickaxe.
She passes like a palm branch with clusters ... In a barren udder not betrayed by milkers.
She has a hooked nose; in the tips of her ears to the one who sees her ... Is a clear nobility, and in the cheeks is smoothness.
She trots on left legs while she overtakes ... With withered legs that have barely touched the ground.
Brown shanks that leave the pebbles scattered ... With four hooves not hindered by the hills, hard as horseshoes.'

'[On] a day when the chameleon remains baking in the sun ... As if its exposed part is roasted by fire.
As if the movement of her forearms when she sweats ... Is the movement of a gray-haired woman mourning, draped in rags.
And the camel driver said to the people when ... The 'leaves' of the locusts began to kick the pebbles: 'Take a midday nap.'
[Her arms move] like the movement of the hands of a bereaved, gray-haired woman wailing ... She stood up and was answered by miserable, bereft mothers.
A wailer, with flabby upper arms, who has no ... Rationality left when the announcers announced the death of her firstborn.
She tears at her chest with her hands, and her garment ... Is torn from her collar into tatters.
The slanderers strive against my sides, and their saying is ... 'Indeed, you, O son of Abi Sulma, are surely killed.'
And every friend whom I used to hope in said: ... 'I will not distract you; indeed, I am busy away from you.'
So I said: 'Clear my path, may you have no father [an expression of scolding] ... For everything the Most Merciful has decreed will occur.'
Every son of a female, even if his safety lasts long ... Is one day carried upon a humpbacked instrument [a coffin].
I was informed that the Messenger of Allah threatened me ... Yet pardon from the Messenger of Allah is hoped for.
Gently! May He guide you, the One who gave you the gift of ... The Qur'an, in which are exhortations and detail.
Do not punish me for the sayings of the slanderers, for I ... Have not sinned, even if the rumors about me are many.
Indeed, I stand in a station that if ... An elephant stood in it, seeing and hearing what I hear,
He would remain trembling, unless there was for him ... From the Messenger, by the permission of Allah, a granting of safety.
Until I placed my right hand, without disputing, ... Into the palm of an Avenger whose word is the final word.
For he is more feared by me when I speak to him ... And it was said, 'Indeed you are examined and questioned,'
Than a lion from the forest thickets, whose den ... Is in the belly of 'Aththar; thicket upon thicket surrounds it.
He goes out early and feeds two lion cubs whose sustenance is ... Flesh from the people, covered in dust, cut into pieces.
If he attacks an adversary, it is not lawful for him ... To leave the adversary unless he is broken.
From him, the wild donkeys remain silent ... And men do not walk in his valley.
And there remains in his valley a trusted brother [prey] ... Whose weapons and tattered clothes are cast aside, eaten.
Indeed, the Messenger is a sword to be illuminated by ... Drawn from the swords of Allah, sharp.
In a group from Quraysh, whose spokesperson said ... In the valley of Mecca when they converted: 'Depart.'
They departed, but no weaklings departed, nor those defenseless ... At the meeting [of battle], nor those who lean away unarmed.
High-nosed [proud], heroes, their clothing is ... From the weave of David; shirts of mail in battle.
White, ample armor, whose rings have been pierced ... As if they are the rings of the Qaf'aa plant, woven together.
They walk the walk of white camels; protecting them is ... A strike when the black, short men flee.
They do not rejoice [arrogantly] if their spears hit ... A people, nor are they anxious if they are hit.
The stabbing does not fall except in their throats ... They have no hesitation from the basins of death.'
